Court of Appeals in Washington has set a nearly impossible standard for prosecuting high-profile cases that demands exposure as well as punishment.

LEAD: The governing board of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. decided by voice vote today to remain neutral on the abortion issue but said it resented government intrusion into personal matters.

Ryan Wins No. 300
Nolan Ryan, at age 43, captured his 300th major league victory last night, going seven and two-thirds innings in the Texas Rangers' defeat of the Brewers at Milwaukee.


Golf;   Shoal Creek Club Agrees To Begin Admitting Blacks
LEAD: Bowing to pressure from civil-rights leaders and an increasing number of corporate sponsors who have withdrawn television advertising from next week's P.G.A.
Championship there, Shoal Creek Country Club agreed today to accept black members into its previously all-white membership.
In return, the civil rights leaders agreed to call off picketing of the championship.

Jamaica and Barbados Offer Force to End Trinidad Unrest
LEAD: Jamaica and Barbados have offered assistance to the Government of Trinidad to help it restore public order after the widespread looting and violence produced by an attempted coup.

LEAD: Scores of anti-Government demonstrators rallied tonight in University Square in the capital's center, the site of a 53-day demonstration that was violently broken up by the police in mid-June.


Steinbrenner Whine Fails 'Smell Test'
LEAD: George Steinbrenner's reign of tyranny as the Yankees' principal owner was also a reign of propaganda.
Whatever the problem, he shouted loud enough and long enough that it was always somebody else's fault.
When the team stumbled, it had to be the fault of the dismissed manager, the dismissed pitching coach or the dismissed players.


THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   The Power Of Account Planning
LEAD: NEW YORK has always been a tough market for small agencies.
To succeed, most rely on their creative reputations for producing the innovative work not usually found at many larger agencies.


Hiroshima Study Finds No Genetic Damage
LEAD: A 40-year study of thousands of Japanese who survived the atomic bombs dropped on Hiroshima and Nagasaki shows radiation exposure did not cause genetic damage that could lead to human mutations, a researcher said today.

Priscilla L. Loomis, 99; Active in Charity Work
LEAD: Priscilla Lockwood Loomis, who received an award from Mayor Edward I. Koch in 1981 for 75 years of volunteer charity work, died on Saturday at a nursing home in Huntington, L.I.
She was 99 years old and formerly lived in Manhattan.


Platinum Rises $10 an Ounce On Signs of Japanese Buying
LEAD: Platinum futures prices surged more than $10 an ounce yesterday amid several bullish factors, including signs of buying by the Japanese, the world's biggest platinum jewelry consumers.


Corrections
LEAD: An article on Monday about a bombing in Israel misidentified the hometown of a Canadian tourist killed in the explosion.
It is Willowdale, a suburb of Toronto.

LEAD: The South African military announced tonight that it had disbanded a clandestine unit held responsible by its adversaries for the assassination of political dissidents.


Navy Finds an Object That May Be Jet Door
LEAD: Navy searchers using a remote-controlled deep-sea submarine have found what could be the cargo door that was torn off a United Airlines jumbo jet last year, hurling nine people to their death over the Pacific.


In Wisconsin, Indian Feasts The Way They Used to Be
LEAD: HELEN SAGLIN, a Chippewa, remembers childhood meals of wild rice, game, cornmeal soup and fry bread.
Now, as a member of the Tekakwitha Club, a Roman Catholic women's organization on the Lac du Flambeau Reservation in north-central Wisconsin, Ms.
Saglin is cooking similar meals for tourist groups interested in American Indian foods.

LEAD: THE Tokyo stock market, once again, is tumbling.
And as in the 30 percent plunge from January to April, the villians are high interest rates, a weak yen and higher oil prices.


Donald L. Ranard, 73, U.S. Aide Who Disclosed Seoul's Lobbying
LEAD: Donald L. Ranard, a longtime Foreign Service official who played a key role in uncovering the role of South Korean lobbyists in Washington in the mid-1970's, died on Saturday at Georgetown University Hospital.
He was 73 years old and lived in Centreville, Va., and Romney, W. Va.
Mr.
Ranard's family said he died of leukemia.

LEAD: The Cuban Government calls him a terrorist.
A goodly number of Cuban exiles in Miami call him a patriot.

Gull Disease Closes 4 Islands
LEAD: Four privately-owned islands in Lake Champlain will be quarantined because of a mysterious disease that killed 4,000 to 5,000 ring-bellied sea gulls, a state official said today.
The birds, almost all fledglings, died of a disease that seems to have subsided, said Bob Inslerman, a wildlife manager for the State Department of Environmental Conservation.

LEAD: Gunmen from a militant Muslim group released the wounded Prime Minister of this Caribbean island nation today, but they continue to hold other members of the Government who were taken hostage four days ago.

LEAD: Bridge and other intellectual games are excluded from the Olympics, but the organizers of the Goodwill Games in Seattle have proved more flexible.
Twenty-five Soviet players are there, and will compete today and tomorrow against players from the Seattle area.

LEAD: The Environmental Protection Agency proposed far-reaching pollution-control measures today for the Los Angeles area, with some to be used if new state and local efforts failed to bring pollution levels within legal limits.

LEAD: The executive editor and president of The Philadelphia Inquirer, Eugene L. Roberts Jr., announced unexpectedly yesterday that he would retire on Sept. 1.

LEAD: Faced with a lawsuit filed by four major newspapers, John E. Frohnmayer, chairman of the National Endowment for the Arts and its advisory body, the National Council on the Arts, today decided to open to the public the entire four-day meeting, beginning tomorrow, at which the council will review grant applications.


The Media Business;   House Passes Airwaves Bill
LEAD: The House of Representatives approved a bill late Monday night that would help ease overcrowding of the airwaves by transferring many radio frequencies from the Federal Government to private users and state and local governments.
The House passed the bill on a voice vote without dissent.


Swinging Briefcases by Day, Rock Guitars by Night
LEAD: ERIC ONORE is a typical young American lawyer.
He wears wing-tip shoes and pin-stripe suits.
He specializes in civil law and divorce.
Most days are as exciting as watching Wite-Out dry. ''I've evicted a family,'' he said, when asked about recent accomplishments.


Prices on Treasury Bonds Ease
LEAD: Prices of long-term Treasury bonds eased yesterday in lackluster trading, causing rates to edge up.
Dealers described the market's mood as indecisive.
Some dealers said a pause was normal after two sessions of sharp advances, but others described the market as confused and contended that the recent price gains had left the market vulnerable to any determined selling.


Heath Is Suspended
LEAD: Mke Heath, the Detroit Tiger catcher, was suspended for two games by the American League yesterday for bumping Umpire John Hirschbeck.


Metropolitan Diary
LEAD: THE Broadway Barber Shop, between 103d and 104th Streets, and Kay Demetriou, its owner, have been Upper West Side fixtures for four decades.
Three generations of families have had their hair cut by Mr.
Kay, as he is called, and six days a week for more than 40 years passers-by have been rapping on the shop's window and waving to its proprietor.


Endowment Restriction Is Called Unwise
LEAD: Six constitutional law experts today told a commission reviewing the policies of the National Endowment for the Arts that it was unwise to demand that recipients of grants certify under oath that they would not use Federal money to create obscene works.


RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:
TENNIS
Saved by the Rain
Rain saved Horst Skoff of Austria from defeat and three West German players advanced at the Austrian Open tournament at Kitzbuhel, Austria.
Skoff, one of the favorites, trailed Christian Saceanu of West Germany, 4-6, 4-5, when the match was interrupted by a thunderstorm.

LEAD: Dr.
Norman Pleshette, an obstetrician and gynecologist in Manhattan for almost 60 years, died on Monday at his home in Manhattan.
He was 87 years old.

Corrections
LEAD: A chart in Business Day yesterday, headed ''The Favorite Stocks,'' misstated the performance of several stocks.
BellSouth closed on Monday at $53.50 a share, up 87.5 cents; Bell Atlantic, $47.625, up $1.25; Nynex, $75, up 87.5 cents; Ameritech, $59.75, up $1.625; Pacific Telesis, $41.75, up 12.5 cents; U S West, $36.125, up 25 cents; General Motors, $47.375, unchanged; Bell Canada, $32.50, unchanged, and Sears, Roebuck, $33.875, up 12.5 cents.

LEAD: Yields on certificates of deposit and money market accounts have fallen for the ninth consecutive week, and some analysts say they expect further declines.

Microwave Cooking
LEAD: SALADS are not the first thing that springs to mind when you're considering the capabilities of the microwave oven, but for the robust salads of summer, it can be an efficient, cool helper.
For variety, vegetables can be cooked in one dish, rather than separately timed in a plethora of little pots of boiling water.


Evolution in Europe;   Soviet-Albanian Ties Restored
LEAD: The Soviet Union and Albania have agreed to normalize relations, which were severed in 1961 during Moscow's rift with Beijing, the Soviet press agency Tass reported.
The Albanians sided with China in the ideological dispute.
The agreement was reached during talks in Bulgaria in June and in Tirana Monday, Tass said.


GENE TREATMENTS FOR HUMAN ILLNESS MAY BE TRIED SOON
LEAD: The revolution in human gene therapy, so long ballyhooed and debated, began today in earnest as a Government panel approved experiments with two therapies designed to treat human disease by inserting new genes into cells.


COMMUNISTS WIN MONGOLIA BALLOT
LEAD: The Communist Party won a majority in this country's first free legislative elections but will invite opposition groups to join the Government, the party chairman said today.
The election was held Sunday.


Shootings Jolt Children to New Views of Guns
LEAD: The closest Leonardo Laziza has come to a real gun was when he saw one, at eye level, on a police officer's hip, tucked inside a holster.
But Leonardo, a 6-year-old from Boerum Hill in Brooklyn, said he could identify two kinds of firearms, ''a pistol and a bazooka,'' both from movies and cartoons.

Evolution in Europe;   East Germans Tell How Bonn Paid for Prisoners
LEAD: East Germany's Interior Minister said today that the former Communist Government had released 33,000 political prisoners to West Germany from 1964 to 1989, against indirect payments from Bonn that started at the equivalent of $10,000 a head and ended up at about $60,000.

LEAD: The rejection of Karen Finley and three other experimentalists for grants from the National Endowment for the Arts has made the term ''performance artist'' the subject of considerable debate and wide attention.
People who have no conception of the range or purpose of the form now use the words with alacrity, as a synonym for anything outrageous.

LEAD: Imo Industries has grown so much in the three years since it was spun off from the Transamerica Corporation that it has created the posts of president and chief operating officer.

I.R.A. Says It Killed Tory M.P. in Britain
LEAD: The Irish Republican Army said today that it killed Ian Gow, a Conservative member of Parliament, because he was a close friend of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's and helped to develop British policy in Northern Ireland.


Brett Out With Injury
LEAD: George Brett of the Kansas City Royals, who was knocked down while covering first base during a play on Monday night in Cleveland, is expected to be out of action for several days, according to the Royals' trainer, Mickey Cobb.
The 37-year-old infielder was bounced to the ground by Mitch Webster of the Indians, who was attempting to beat out an infield roller, and suffered a sprain and a bruise near his right collarbone.


BLAME IS PLACED FOR VALDEZ SPILL
LEAD: Drinking by the ship's captain, a fatigued and overworked crew and inadequate traffic control by the Coast Guard all contributed to the enormous oil spill by the Exxon Valdez off the Alaskan coast last year, the National Transportation Safety Board ruled today.

LEAD: Despite the threat of a veto from President Bush, the House overwhelmingly voted today for changes in the troubled Federal Housing Administration insurance program, which has been losing $4 billion a year because of bad loans.


Earnings Drop 47% At Chrysler &lt;
LEAD: The Chrysler Corporation today reported a 47 percent decline in second-quarter profits, reflecting lower vehicle shipments and the increased cost of offering bigger incentives to car and truck buyers.


The Talk of Greenwich;   Vandal? Indubitably. But Barbarian? Hardly
LEAD: Rene Anselmo, like many residents here, is a man of wealth and taste.
He drives a Bentley.
He modeled his mansion on the Petit Trianon in Versailles.
He has donated money to plant thousands of daffodils and tulips along local roads.
He even replaced the chain-link barricade at a nearby elementary school with a rail fence more in keeping with this town's country flavor.

Review/Film;   Emilio Estevez in Reprise of Billy the Kid Role
LEAD: ''Kid'' is the operative word in describing the ''Young Guns'' approach to the Billy the Kid legend, since these films regard Billy as more of a gun-toting cut-up than a true desperado.
As played again by Emilio Estevez in ''Young Guns II,'' Billy tends to giggle at tense moments and, during important ones, to mumble.

LEAD: For the first summer in 75 years, English will be officially spoken today on the Middlebury College campus.

Defendant In Jogger Case Takes Stand
LEAD: Rejecting furious pleas from his fellow defense lawyers, the lawyer for one of the defendants in the Central Park jogger trial called his client to the witness stand yesterday before a jury in a Manhattan courtroom.


Business Technology;   Storing Summer's Solar Heat for the Winter
LEAD: The biggest problem with solar heating systems is that the sun shines most in the summer, when the heat is not needed, and least in the winter, when it is.
But a team at the University of Massachusetts at Amherst has found a storage medium that will hold July's heat for February: the ground.


F.A.O. Schwarz Toy Stores Bought by Dutch Company
LEAD: F.A.O.
Schwarz, the 128-year-old toy store that has delighted generations of children, has been acquired by the Netherlands' leading department store chain for an undisclosed amount.


Jockey's Remains Identified
LEAD: Body parts that washed up in a garbage bag at Seven Presidents Park beach have been identified as the remains of a New York jockey.
Crews removing timber and other waste from beaches on Thursday discovered the bag, which contained a head, arms and legs.
The Monmouth County authorities used fingerprints to identify the dead man as Pedro Ortega, 26 years old, of the Bronx, an apprentice jockey who rode at New York's Acqueduct and Belmont Park race tracks.


Review/Music;   The Rorem Reverse: Singsong for Voice As Instruments Sing
LEAD: Ned Rorem's ''Auden Poems,'' a song cycle that was given its world premiere on Sunday evening at the Santa Fe Chamber Music Festival, is a study in esthetic schizophrenia.
Mr.
Rorem proves again and again in his setting of seven W. H. Auden texts of great musical potential that he is quite capable of writing richly expressive, eminently singable music.


U.S. Is Suspending Hearings On New Disability Payments
LEAD: With money for administrative expenses running short at the end of the fiscal year, the Social Security Administration has suspended hearings in September for people seeking disability benefits.

Ms.

LEAD: Freeport-McMoran Inc. agreed to acquire the publicly held shares of its Freeport-McMoran Oil and Gas Company affiliate in a stock swap worth about $241 million.
Holders of the stock will get about three shares of stock in the parent company for every 10 shares held, the company said.
Freeport-McMoran valued the oil and gas unit at $10.50 a share.

Slide of the Yankees
LEAD: George Steinbrenner has always been a quotable man, nearly always at someone else's expense.
But his most revealing remark may have been an unintended commentary on himself.
It was 1981.
He had just fired Gene Michael as the manager of the New York Yankees and offered him a front-office job. ''Why would you want to stay manager and be second-guessed by me,'' he said, ''when you can be one of the second-guessers?


Rig Count Falls in Week
LEAD: The number of working oil and natural gas rigs in the United States dropped last week by 26, to a total of 996, according to a widely watched index of drilling activity released on Monday by Baker Hughes Inc.
The oil industry toolmaker said the total was still well above the 870 of a year ago.
The count reflects the number of rotary rigs exploring for oil and gas as of last Friday.

LEAD: Giving one of his bleakest forecasts to date, the chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation said today that ever-weakening real estate markets and a near-record number of bank failures were likely to produce the third consecutive annual loss for the fund that insures deposits at commercial banks.

Working Less in Japan
LEAD: More Japanese companies have switched to a five-day workweek as the country moves to erase its workaholic image, a Labor Ministry survey showed today.
The nationwide survey of 5,000 companies with more than 3,000 employees showed 58.4 percent had gone over to the five-day week, an increase of more than five percentage points from a year ago.

LEAD: THE death of a family pet may be a child's first experience with the loss of a person or animal he loves.
In some ways it is more emotionally complex than coping with the death of a human being; for instance, the animal may be younger than the child, or may have been with the family since before the child was born.

LEAD: The Procter &amp; Gamble Company, which has previously fought rumors that its 108-year-old moon and stars trademark is a satanic symbol, said this week that it had sued a Kansas couple for claiming the company was associated with satanism.
The suit, filed Monday in Federal District Court, contends James and Linda Newton of Parsons made libelous and malicious statements about Procter &amp; Gamble by saying it supports ''the church of Satan.

LEAD: It's been said that only God can make a tree.
But now mere mortals are stepping forward to argue about who owns a tree's image.

LEAD: WHEN it comes to global bond investing, sometimes all that matters is getting the currency right.
In July, the principal determinant of profit was investing in bonds denominated in almost any currency other than the dollar.

Although the 70-foot-long loft had a 13th-floor view of the Hudson River and the skyscrapers of midtown Manhattan, it was just 12 feet wide.

LEAD: Doug Jennings, a pinch-hitter, broke up a pitching duel with a run-scoring single in the 11th inning and Dave Stewart went the distance as the Oakland A's defeated the Seattle Mariners, 1-0, today.

LEAD: The longest and most expensive criminal proceeding in American history came to an official end today when a Superior Court judge dismissed all charges against Raymond Buckey, a central figure in the McMartin Pre-School child molestation case.

International
A3-9


Canadian Output Down
LEAD: Canada's economy shrank in May, marking the first back-to-back monthly decline since the 1982 recession, the Government said on Tuesday.
Gross domestic product in May fell two-tenths of 1 percent after declining one-tenth of a percent in April, Statistics Canada said. ''It reflects the fact that we're close to the edge of recession,'' said George Saba, an economist at Montreal Trust.


REBELS IN TRINIDAD FREE ALL HOSTAGES
LEAD: A violent, five-day drama that saw the Prime Minister and half of the Cabinet taken hostage by heavily armed Muslim militants ended peacefully today when 112 gunmen and their religious leader laid down their weapons and freed their remaining 46 hostages.


Review/Music;   Philip Glass Ensemble Plays for a Silent Film
LEAD: The hazards and delights of cultural interchange were on abundant display on Friday at Alice Tully Hall, where the Philip Glass Ensemble performed his score for a showing of the otherwise silent film ''Powaqqatsi.'' The title, a Hopi word, means ''an entity, a way of life, that consumes the life forces of other beings in order to further its own life.


Corrections
LEAD: An article on the Company News page in Business Day yesterday about the Walt Disney Company's plans for a theme park in Long Beach, Calif., misstated the company's business relationship with two attractions on the site in some copies.
Disney leases and operates the Queen Mary ocean liner and the Spruce Goose airplane; it does not own them.


The Media Business;   Chargeurs Buys Pathe
LEAD: A French industrial group, Chargeurs S.A., today bought Pathe-Cinema S.A., the film company that the Italian financier Giancarlo Parretti tried to buy earlier this year.


Pan Am's Losses Shrink
LEAD: The Pan Am Corporation yesterday reported a net loss of $49 million for the second quarter, about half the size of last year's $101 million second-quarter loss.
The New York holding company for Pan American World Airways attributed the narrower deficit to sharply higher airline revenue.
Pan Am's revenues for the quarter rose 12.2 percent, to $1.02 billion, from $909.4 million a year earlier.


Met Opera Appoints a General Director
LEAD: Joseph Volpe, who began 26 years ago as an apprentice carpenter backstage at the Metropolitan Opera, was appointed the company's chief administrative officer yesterday, effective immediately.
He succeeds Hugh Southern, who was forced to resign in June after only seven months as general manager.


Kodak Profits Rise Sharply
LEAD: The Eastman Kodak Company said today that its earnings had risen nearly fivefold in the second quarter from results that were depressed by a large restructuring charge a year ago.


Company News;   Fiat Disclosure
LEAD: Fiat S.p.A. has an option to buy the Ford Motor Company's 20 percent stake in their new farm vehicles venture, Fiat's managing director, Cesare Romiti, said in a newspaper interview to be published on Thursday.
Fiat and Ford said on Tuesday that they were placing their tractor, farm and industrial equipment businesses into a new company 80 percent owned by Fiat and 20 percent by Ford.


Islanders Sign Two
LEAD: Jari Gronstand, a defenseman, and Bill Berg, a left wing, signed multiyear contracts with the Islanders yesterday.


Currency Markets;   Dollar Makes Some Gains, But Traders Remain Wary
LEAD: The dollar regained some ground in foreign exchange trading yesterday, but traders warned that the United States currency remained weak.

LEAD: Seven members of UB40, the British reggae group, were deported from the Seychelles Islands yesterday after being arrested on suspicion of possessing marijuana.

LEAD: A former employee of the Arbitron Company attempted to give confidential information about the company's television ratings to its principal rival, the A. C. Nielsen Company, the Department of Justice charged yesterday.

LEAD: The Government's main gauge for forecasting the direction of the economy did not budge in June, the Commerce Department said today in a report that analysts said was a sign of a listless economy in the months ahead.

Outdoors Is Indoors As Garden Decor Moves to the Parlor
LEAD: FROM Manhattan to Berkeley, Calif., and from Atlanta to Newport, R.I., green thumbs and greenhorns are patronizing stores with names like the Potted Plant, the Elegant Earth, Victory Garden and Devonshire.
Following in the path of mail-order businesses like Smith &amp; Hawken and Gardener's Eden, which have already spread the word on the well-honed garden, this new breed of shop is bringing the sweet smell of earth (or at least the illusion of it) indoors.

LEAD: The Daily News asked a Federal court yesterday to stop a State Board of Inquiry from examining negotiations between the paper and its unions.


Topics of The Times;   Melons at the MOMA
LEAD: At the entrance to ''Matisse in Morocco,'' on display at the Museum of Modern Art until Sept. 4, is a National Geographic magazine photograph of Tangier in 1906.
The city is sun-baked, steamy and tired.
Just beyond it is the Tangier painted by Matisse.
Fertile, colorful, exuberant, the city is paradise.

LEAD: The nation's death rate from asthma has increased by more than 30 percent in seven years, and nearly 10 million Americans are now affected by the disease, Federal health officials say.

LEAD: The Massachusetts Mutual Life Insurance Company said today that it would take part in the acquisition of the Oppenheimer Management Corporation from British and Commonwealth Holdings P.L.C. for about $150 million.

Health;   Pet Owners Go to the Doctor Less
LEAD: Elderly people who own pets visit their physicians less often than those who do not have pets, and dog owners have the fewest visits of all, a study has found.


Nationwide Reunion Celebration For Blacks
LEAD: TERI SMITH looks forward to family reunions.
They are times for her aunts, uncles, cousins, sisters and brothers to gather to talk of their new babies, travels, childhoods, deceased relatives and dreams.
Ms.
Smith will also learn more about families from a broader perspective at the six Black Family Reunion Celebrations being held in various cities around the country.

LEAD: The Senate tonight passed the first major campaign finance bill since the Watergate era, a comprehensive package that would bar political action committees from Federal campaigns, infuse public money into Congressional campaigns and offer candidates vouchers for television advertising.

LEAD: The Nynex Corporation plans to spend at least $100 million to build a second cellular telephone network in Manhattan by Christmas of next year, company officials said yesterday.

LEAD: Worries that a $4.4 billion employee-led bid for the parent of United Airlines may be crumbling because of financing difficulties sent the shares of the UAL Corporation tumbling for the third straight session yesterday.
UAL's stock slid $4.125 a share, to close at $135.875, in active trading on the New York Stock Exchange.

LEAD: Japanese stock prices fell sharply in afternoon trading today and the yen fluctuated wildly against the dollar after Iraq invaded Kuwait.

Helping Hands Change Tire on Road to Airport
LEAD: To the Editor:


Senate Roll-Call on Campaign Financing
LEAD: Following is the 77-to-23 roll-call vote by which the Senate voted today to prohibit its members from accepting speaking fees from special interest groups.
A yes vote was a vote to prohibit such fees and a no vote was a vote to permit them.
Voting yes were 53 Democrats and 24 Republicans.
Voting no were 2 Democrats and 21 Republicans.


Cardinals Pick Torre To Replace Herzog
LEAD: To the surprise of hardly anyone, Joe Torre was named manager of the St.
Louis Cardinals yesterday.
The hiring ended a monthlong search for a successor to Whitey Herzog, who, in the middle of his 11th season as skipper, resigned on June 6 with the Cardinals in last place in the National League East.

LEAD: Air traffic controllers took the unusual step Tuesday night of declaring a fuel emergency on an Avianca Airlines flight headed for Kennedy International Airport because of confusion over how much fuel it had left, one of the controllers and Federal aviation officials said last night.


Review/City Opera;   A Solid 'Figaro' Opens A Season
LEAD: In its 46-year history, the New York City Opera has had many mandates, sometimes conflicting ones.
It has been a home for young American singers, a champion of American opera, a forum for innovative productions, a source of unusual repertory.
But one of its humbler jobs has been to present solid, competent performances of standard-repertory operas in conventional productions at moderate prices.

LEAD: THE decorative arts of Africa are usually chronicled in books about masks, bronzes, jewelry, textiles and tools made by men.
In ''African Canvas: Art of West African Women'' (Rizzoli, $60), the photographer and journalist Margaret Courtney-Clarke documents a lesser-known form: the art of rural dwellings.

Fact one: Imports accounted for a record 50 percent of the oil consumed by the U.S. during the first half of 1990.
Fact two: The oil cartel, the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, this week raised its target price for oil by 17 percent.

Home Improvement
LEAD: LINING a closet with cedar paneling helps keep moths and insects away from woolen clothes.
Cedar's aroma, which is pleasant to people, is a repellent to insects.
Cedar is also safer than chemical repellents, like mothballs, which can be accidentally eaten by children.

Puppy Killing Brings Prison
LEAD: A man convicted of killing a puppy with a butcher knife was sentenced Tuesday to three and a half years in prison under the state's recently toughened law on cruelty to animals.
Everston Eugene Webb, 22 years old, was sentenced for aggravated cruelty.
Testimony at his Circuit Court trial indicated he killed the dog on May 11 because it was tearing up his yard.

LEAD: The Acura NSX sports car that will be roaring down American roads later in August has swooping lines, a heart-stopping 168-mile-an-hour top speed and a long list of other characteristics that the Honda Motor Company says a competitive ''super car'' should have.


Company News;   Washington Bank
LEAD: Washington Bancorporation filed for protection under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code.
The company listed known liabilities of $61.7 million and assets with undetermined market value.
The company said its main banking unit, the National Bank of Washington, would be unable to restore its capital to required levels.

LEAD:
The Economy


Roll-Call in Senate On Speaking Fees
LEAD: Following is the 77-to-23 roll-call vote by which the Senate voted today to prohibit its members from accepting speaking fees from special interest groups.
A yes vote was a vote to prohibit such fees and a no vote was a vote to permit them.
Voting yes were 53 Democrats and 24 Republicans.
Voting no were 2 Democrats and 21 Republicans.

LEAD: Stocks fell slightly yesterday, with bank shares giving ground amid fears that the industry could be facing difficult times.

LEAD: Richard G. Darman, Director of the Office of Management and Budget, has agreed to release $5 million to let the Social Security Administration hold hearings next month for people seeking disability benefits, White House officials said today.


Tigers Pound Hawkins
LEAD: The summer is still not over for Andy Hawkins.
There are two months remaining, perhaps a dozen or so starts left for him to remove the memory of his strange season.
He should want to forget the whole thing right now, but he doesn't.


The Talk of Saratoga;   Horse Season Opens (Oh, and Races Too)
LEAD: In August, people come to Saratoga for more than the horses, or the waters (mineral).
They come to soak up the romance of the track: Costume balls, tip sheets, barber shop quartets, racing forms, champagne breakfasts at the morning workout, sunshine and a glimpse of Mellons, Vanderbilts and Whitneys being put through their social paces.

LEAD: Japanese stock prices fell sharply today and the yen fluctuated wildly against the dollar after Iraq invaded Kuwait.

LEAD: A Liberian rebel leader, Charles Taylor, said today that he would let President Samuel K. Doe's army help him crush a rival rebel chief before moving in to oust Mr.
Doe himself within 10 days.


Corrections
LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article in Sports Pages yesterday about Donald Trump and boxing misstated Bill Cayton's managerial relationship with Mike Tyson, the former heavyweight champion.
Although estranged from Tyson, Cayton is still formally his manager.

Group of Blacks Sees Hiring Bias By Morgenthau
LEAD: A group of prominent black legislators, clergy members and leaders of community groups asserted yesterday that District Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau of Manhattan was systematically excluding blacks from policy-making roles in his office.


Purchasers Report Fall In Growth
LEAD: A monthly survey released yesterday by the National Association of Purchasing Management indicated a steep decline for the nation's manufacturing economy in July, reversing a three-month growth trend.
Economists said the survey gave more credence to assessments that the economy is slowing, perhaps slipping into a recession.

LEAD: Confidence in the nation's economy among consumers was about the same in July as in June, according to a monthly study.

He was 75 years old.
While pitching for the Boston Braves in 1944, he faced 27 batters and threw only 58 pitches in a 2-0 victory over the Cincinnati

LEAD: The glare from all those bright lights that have followed Nolan Ryan and the Texas Rangers for the last two weeks will shine elsewhere for a while.

LEAD: Players waited and reporters waited and photographers waited, but there was no George Steinbrenner yesterday.

Close to Home
LEAD: THE bus was going east on 57th Street, and when it reached Madison Avenue, I took my eyes off my paperback and peered out the window.
We were passing the building in which I worked at my first job.


Company News;   MCI-Telecom Deal
LEAD: The Federal Communications Commission has approved the $1.25 billion merger of the MCI Communications Corporation and Telecom USA Inc.
MCI said the merger to be completed before the end of the month, pending state regulatory approvals.
MCI plans to acquire all of Telecom's outstanding common shares for $42 each, or about $1.25 billion.

LEAD: Because of two missing words, and a law that puts a premium on the absurd, an insurgent candidate is working hard to invalidate scores of nominating petitions in the Bronx.
The spectacle makes one more eloquent argument for reform of New York State's notoriously niggling Election Law.

LEAD: A front-page article yesterday about a Senate subcommittee hearing on the savings and loan crisis misidentified a lobbyist who used his Washington contacts to help buyers of insolvent savings and loan associations.
He is Robert J. Thompson.

Mr.
Karner also repairs many small items with sentimental value. ''But they say it was their grandmother's and they want it,'' he said.
So he fixes it.

Pentagon Drafts Strategy for Post-Cold War World
LEAD: The Pentagon has drafted a blueprint for United States military strategy in the 1990's with the assumption that once Soviet forces withdraw from Eastern Europe it would take Moscow up to two years to mobilize for a major invasion.

LEAD: Chauffeur-driven cars, drinks by the swimming pool, year-round tans and bottomless expense accounts may not be the happy fate of most American expatriates.
But to a good many people back home at least, those are just some of the privileges they think are enjoyed by their fellow Americans abroad.

LEAD: After months of denials from Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. that he had ever used illegal drugs before his arrest in January, his lawyer's acknowledgment to the jury on Wednesday that the Mayor had been an occasional cocaine user may have seemed a startling admission.

Corrections
LEAD: An article on July 26 about Soviet staff members of the United Nations Secretariat misstated the position of Gail Bindley-Taylor, vice president of the United Nations staff union.
She said the status of the Soviet staff members was confused; she did not say they were ''secretive.''

LEAD: Presented with tons of documents every year and not enough room to store them, state court administrators are embracing computer technology that they hope will eliminate the need for case files.


The Iraqi Invasion: Global Reverberations
LEAD:
OIL PRICES Spot market prices surged, with the American benchmark crude rising to $23.11 a barrel, up $1.57.
The invasion stirred fears of slower economic growth, higher inflation and OPEC domination of the world oil market.
But price increases should be limited by a near-record stockpile worldwide.


Dow Slumps 34.66 Points, But Oils Soar
LEAD: Inflation fears touched off by the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait pushed most stock prices lower yesterday, including airlines and other users of petroleum products, but sent oil and oil-service stocks sharply higher.


Review/Art;   African and Other Portraits, Side by Side
LEAD: Within the art world, there has been a tendency for some time to approach the art of other cultures in one of two ways.
One way is based on an assumption that aspects of art are universal and that what one culture values in art is a standard by which the art of other cultures can be measured.
Behind the second is a conviction that other cultures are so radically different from our own that no common ground exists and that any attempt to measure the art of those cultures in anything other than its own terms is unjust.


Editorial Notebook;   East Germany's Hero City
LEAD: To understand the swift collapse of East German Communism, see Leipzig.
There one can dine in the fine restaurant in the Gewandhaus symphony hall, facing what is still called Karl-Marx-Platz, the epicenter of the upheaval that ended four decades of Marxist rule.

LEAD: The other day, West Germany's deputy chief delegate to the United Nations walked up to the front door of a forbidding gray mansion at 58 Park Avenue, rang the bell and was admitted.

LEAD: Lee Trevino will play in the P.G.A.
Championship next week in Shoal Creek, Ala., but without wearing shirts bearing the Toyota name after the Toyota Motor Corporation pulled its commercials from the telecast in protest of exclusionary membership practices at the Shoal Creek Country Club, the tournament site.


Review/Art;   The Genius And Panache Of Africa's 'Parisians'
LEAD: DURING the last six years, New York City has been treated to several outstanding, and sometimes provocative, exhibitions of African art, thanks to the Museum of Modern Art, the Brooklyn Museum and especially the Center for African Art.
Now the American Museum of Natural History is being heard from, and its ''African Reflections: Art From Northeastern Zaire'' is equal to the best of its predecessors.


Review/Film;   Spike Lee's Middle-Class Jazz Musician
LEAD: SPIKE LEE is an exhilarating mix of brilliance and bravado, of artist, businessman and preacher.
In his stylized visions of our racially tense society - the small-scale sexual comedy ''She's Gotta Have It,'' the inventive musical ''School Daze'' and the astounding political and moral drama ''Do the Right Thing'' - he dares viewers and the Hollywood establishent to keep up with his honesty and humor, his passion and visual flair.

LEAD: Eugene Istomin will be the soloist with the Mostly Mozart Festival Orchestra in Mozart's Piano Concerto No. 21 in C (K. 467) at Avery Fisher Hall tonight at 8.
The program, to be conducted by Gerard Schwarz, also includes Schubert's Eighth Symphony and his incidental music for ''Rosamunde.'' The program will be repeated evening at 8 P.M.

Company News;   Trims at Midland
LEAD: Midland Bank P.L.C. said it was cutting 4,000 jobs from its work force of 33,000 by the end of 1991 through attrition and voluntary departures.
Midland also reported a profit of about $:22 million, or about $40.5 million, in the first half of the year.
That compared with a net loss of $:383 million in the corresponding period in 1989, when the bank raised its provisions for bad loans to third world countries.

LEAD: The assets of the nation's 521 money market mutual funds increased $800.1 million, to $395.42 billion, for the week that ended on Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.

The assets of the 251 general purpose funds were up by $541.5 million, to $136.44 billion.

U.S. Boxers on Roll

World Bank Aids Poland
LEAD: The World Bank said on Wednesday that it would lend $300 million to Poland to help that country shift from Communism to a market-oriented economy.
The loan will be used to finance imports of basic goods and to provide unemployment compensation, training and employment services to workers who lose their jobs.

New Arianespace Chief
LEAD: Arianespace this week named its Director General, Charles Bigot, to the post of president, replacing Frederic d'Allest as head of Europe's commercial satellite launching program.
Mr.
D'Allest announced his retirement last week.
Mr.
Bigot, who is 58 years old, had served in the consortium's second-highest post since 1982.

LEAD: Mark Gubicza, the Kansas City Royals pitcher, had arthroscopic surgery yesterday to repair a tear in his right rotator cuff.
The right-hander is expected to recover in time for spring training, said Steve Joyce, the team physician, who did the surgery.


Company News;   Factory in France For Allied-Signal
LEAD: Allied-Signal Inc. announced it would build a $160 million plant in France to manufacture polyester fiber for passenger car tires, seat belts and other products.
The company said the plant would be built in Longwy, a city near the Belgian border, for $160 million.
It is expected to begin operating by 1993 and employ about 300 workers.

Review/Opera;   Tale of Judith, Updated
LEAD: As soon as the lights go up on the set of ''Judith'' we know where we are, and it definitely is not Israel in Biblical times.
We are in the grim land known as German Expressionism, and any doubt as to where the composer, Siegfried Matthus, and the director, Davis Alden, have brought us is erased at the appearance of a black-faced executioner who busies himself hacking off the heads of prisoners with a meat cleaver.

Economic Scene;   On Measuring Living Standards
LEAD: THE revolutions in Eastern Europe have been driven by people's conviction that their standard of living rotted under Communism.
You cannot find evidence of this decay in the official data. ''Under the Communist regimes, data have simply been faked in some cases, and collected on a very inadequate conceptual basis in other cases,'' according to David Lipton and Jeffrey Sachs, American economists who have been serving as economic advisers to Solidarity in Poland.

Fruit of Appeasement
LEAD: Saddam Hussein of Iraq has answered with a roar the long, dithering argument over whether it was wiser to indulge him or try to isolate and block him.
That is why his blitzkrieg invasion of Kuwait, proving his insatiable ambition, has led so many European commentators to remember Hitler.
The same kind of argument went on through the 1930's, until it was too late.

A yes vote was a vote to pass the bill.
Voting yes were 240 Democrats and 32 Republicans.
Voting no were 12 Democrats and 142 Republicans.
X denotes those not voting.

Guidepost;   The World of Plums
LEAD: Summer offers plums in staggering variety.
Most are sweet and juicy, but some, notably the Santa Rosa, can be tart and astringent near the pit.
Plums are ripe when the skin yields to pressure but is not soft.
Clingstone varieties have pits that cling to the flesh; pits in freestone plums do not.

16 Are Seized in Sales Of Stickers for Autos
LEAD: Sixteen people have been arrested on charges of selling hundreds of counterfeit state automobile inspection stickers to motorists.


Sign Vandal Offers New Highway Signs
LEAD: A millionaire who was arrested last month for spray painting For Sale signs he thought cheapened this wealthy suburb now says he's willing to pay to replace metal highway signs with more attractive wooden ones.


Thomas M. Macioce, 71, Is Dead; Former Chairman of Allied Stores
LEAD: Thomas M. Macioce, a lawyer and former chairman and chief executive officer of the Allied Stores Corporation, died yesterday at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center.
He was 71 years old and lived in Brookville, L.I.

LEAD: Fourteen American oil workers are missing in Kuwait, and there are reports that at least some of them may have been taken into custody by invading Iraqi troops and moved across the border into Iraq, Bush Administration officials said today.

Frohnmayer Is Asked To End Written Pledge
LEAD: The advisory council to the National Endowment for the Arts voted overwhelmingly today to recommend the elimination of an anti-obscenity pledge that artists and arts institutions have been asked to sign before they can receive grants from the endowment.

Choctaw Pursuing Justin Industries
LEAD: Choctaw Securities L.P. has engaged the New York branch of Creditanstalt-Bankverein to consider providing financing for a possible effort to gain control of Justin Industries Inc.
Choctaw, an investment partnership in Kansas City, Mo., now controls 11.6 percent of Justin's 8.5 million shares outstanding.

Congress Authorizes $875 Million To Fight AIDS in Hard-Hit Areas
LEAD: House and Senate negotiators agreed today on a bill that would authorize $875 million next year to provide health care to people with AIDS in cities and states hardest hit by the epidemic.

LEAD: Powerful Iraqi forces wheeled into position for a possible attack on Saudi Arabia today, while the United States and its allies continued to search, without discernible success, for a way to force Iraq to pull back from its rapid conquest of Kuwait on Thursday.

LEAD: The Federal jury weighing the 14 drug and conspiracy charges against Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. met for five and a half hours today without reaching a verdict.


Corrections
LEAD: A music review on Thursday about a performance by the Philip Glass Ensemble on July 27 at Alice Tully Hall misidentified a children's choir whose recorded music was used in presenting Mr.
Glass's score for the film ''Powaqqatsi.'' It is the Hispanic Young People's Chorus from Brooklyn, not a South American group.

LEAD: New York City transit police officers will be allowed to carry a more powerful handgun that has long been resisted by officials here because of its possible danger to the public, transit police officials announced yesterday.

OBSERVER Huzzahs for George
LEAD: Humans need to hate a little.
It's too bad, but so is their compulsion to uglify everything that's beautiful.
We are a superb species, all right, just not quite perfect.
Since we must hate, the sensible thing is to hate in moderation.
For this reason, I have always hated the New York Yankees.

Senegal's Spicy Noonday Feast
LEAD: Flying to Senegal from New York, some visitors get their first glimpse of West Africa even before the coastline comes into view.

Isolate Iraq
LEAD: Iraq's Arab neighbors have canceled the summit meeting scheduled for today; they can't bring themselves even to try to stop Saddam Hussein's million-man army and undo his conquest of Kuwait.

Michael Porter Redux: Yes, but . . .
LEAD: In an article on the July 22 Forum page, Michael E. Porter, a professor of business administration at the Harvard Business School, discussed the issue of American competitiveness (''Japan Isn't Playing by Different Rules'').
Professor Porter believes that the United States has been moving away from one of its fundamental principles - faith in competition - having been seduced by a mistaken view of the reasons for Japan's success in the world marketplace.

And Ariel Sharon as Prime Minister?

Creator vs. Re-creator: Who Wins?
LEAD: Beethoven was, undeniably, the great liberator of Western music.
If only symbolically, his insistence on the composer's right to be treated as an equal by the aristocracy and to control his own music made possible the whole Romantic tradition of artistic freedom and independence.
We know what riches that movement produced.


Boris Yeltsin, Man of the Hour?
LEAD: Vladimir Kvint, Professor of Political Economy of the U.S.S.R. and a former professor at the Communist Higher Party School in Moscow, is a member of the ''Siberian school'' of market-oriented economists.
Professor Kvint, who is currently a distinguished lecturer at Fordham University, spoke with Joel Kurtzman of The New York Times through an interpreter.


Criminal Type Captures Whitney
LEAD: Criminal Type continued to prove himself the country's top race horse by more than default when he scored a thoroughly professional 1 1/2-length victory over Dancing Spree today in the $234,400 Whitney Handicap at Saratoga Race Track.

Paradise Imposed
LEAD: Imagine a luxury resort in the middle of a lava field.
Imagine sod laid on top of the lava and mowed so low you could practically play pool on it.
Imagine white sand on the shore, trucked in at hundreds of dollars per load and manicured as carefully as a wealthy woman's hands.

Center Offers Support on Alzheimer's
LEAD: FEW diseases are as difficult to live with as Alzheimer's, a degenerative brain disorder that is both progressive and irreversible.
For the families involved, the personality changes that the afflicted suffer on a day-to-day basis can be devastating.


Church and State
LEAD: Representative Floyd H. Flake served church and state and abused both, Federal prosecutors said last week.
Mr.
Flake, pastor of one of the largest black churches in New York City, was indicted on charges of misappropriating $75,200 from a federally subsidized housing complex built by his church and with evading taxes on $66,700 of the church's money that he and his wife put to personal use.


Worlds Apart
LEAD: TEACHERS are jugglers, balancing competing interests, and, sometimes, competing ideologies, to deliver to their students enough accurate information to help them make reasoned judgments.

Principals Take To Pulpits
LEAD: ONE Sunday morning James Robinson, 14 years old, watched with surprise from a wooden pew as his Baptist preacher called to the pulpit an unexpected guest: the principal of his old elementary school in Arlington, Va., Marjorie Tuccillo.


Belong Now, Pay Later
LEAD: Notice to ambitious lawyers: Want to be a Federal judge someday, or high official in the Justice Department?
Now's the time to quit that country club or eating club that refuses to admit minorities or women.
Either quit now or at least start compiling a record of agitation for change.
That's the message of the Senate Judiciary Committee, which confirms (and sometimes rejects) nominees for judgeships and high


Pastimes;   Coins
LEAD: The price of rare coins is rising as investors seek unique coins in the highest conditions.
The latest to be sold is an ultra-high-relief example of a 1907 $20 gold piece.
The MTB Banking Corporation reports that it sold the coin for more than $1.5 million.


Generations of Poison and Lies
LEAD: Never have so many human beings been exposed to so much radiation over so long a time - while so few knew about it.
Now, more than 40 years after it began, we are just beginning to learn what the U.S. government's Hanford nuclear weapons plant in Washington state has done to thousands of citizens who unwittingly drank radioactively contaminated water, breathed radioactively contaminated air, and fed milk laced with radioactive iodine to their children.


When Imitation Isn't the Sincerest Form of Flattery
LEAD: IF America's armchair quarterbacks ever voted for their favorite piece of furniture, chances are they might elect the La-Z-Boy recliner.
With huge cushions that gently mold to the supine contours of the heftiest fan and a footrest that stretches obligingly forward to prop up weary feet, the La-Z-Boy has become an icon of middle-class creature comforts.


In Defense of Detectors In the Courthouse
LEAD: While some complain about sensitive metal detectors at the entrance to the Richard J. Daronco Westchester County Courthouse [''The Pros and Cons of Security Often Lie in a Beep,'' July 8] , all who use the courthouse should feel reassured to learn that the magnetometers are effective enough to detect any object containing metal.


The Australian Ballet: En Route to a Tradition
LEAD: Surely but not slowly, the Australian Ballet won the hearts of a supposedly jaded audience in New York during one brief and indisputably successful week at the Metropolitan Opera House last month.


Roll-Call on Spending Limits
LEAD: Following is the vote of 255 to 155 by which the House of Representatives on Friday approved legislation to place a limit of $715,000 on how much House candidates can spend on their election campaigns.
Voting ''yes'' were 240 Democrats and 15 Republicans.
Voting ''no'' were 3 Democrats and 152 Republicans.

LEAD: They have kept 11th Avenue in their baleful gaze since the early 20th century, but the four giant steer heads on the top of the New York Butchers' Dressed Meat Company slaughterhouses will soon be removed.


Fashion;   New Textures Are Crisp, Lush and Light
LEAD: If your seersuckers feel sodden and your linens have gone limp, hang on.
Men's wear arriving in stores now offers crisp new textures in relatively lightweight fabrics.


Top Capitalist
LEAD: In these times, a Bulgarian can take a quick and unconventional route to the top of national politics.
Zhelyu Zhelev, a philosophy professor, took over a group called the Club for the Support of Glasnost and Perestroika, became leader of the main opposition coalition and as of last week is Bulgaria's President.

Wojciech Jaruzelski today to quit the post within weeks.

LEAD: An article on July 22 about the Jasna Gora Monastery in Poland misidentified the Roman Catholic holy day celebrated on Aug. 15.
It is the Feast of the Assumption, not Ascension Day.

A Dedicated Sentry Guards a Watershed
LEAD: IN rural Cornwall Bridge, at the crossing of two winding country roads with the Berkshire Hills as a backdrop, a white farmhouse serves as the home of the Housatonic Valley Association.
The organization is a self-appointed sentry, standing guard over the vistas that stretch southward through Connecticut, as it works to protect the environment.

Caring for Children at the Work Site
LEAD: ASK any group of working mothers what they lack the most and the majority will say child care.
Women make up more than 60 percent of the work force in the county and their voices will grow stronger if their number increases, as expected, 10 to 15 percent by the end of the decade.

Corrections
LEAD: A picture caption in the Travel Advisory column on July 15 about the Chateau de Chambord in France misidentified its builder, Francois I. He was the father-in-law of Catherine de Medici, not of Eleanor of Aquitaine.

THE THUNDER OF HOOFS, THE RING OF COMMENTARY
LEAD: I was foaled at Saratoga Hospital.
Ruined my first sports coat, a red corduroy that ran like a thoroughbred in the rain, selling tip cards at Saratoga Raceway (trots).
Got scared of the dark peddling the Pink Sheet, with its nationwide race results, outside Saratoga Lake's gambling hells.
Met my first rich people covering Saratoga Race Track (flats) for the daily Saratogian.

'Red Desert' Showing
LEAD: Michelangelo Antonioni's first color film, ''Red Desert'' (1964), is to open a two-week run at the Public Theater on Aug. 31.
One of the Italian director's stories of alienation, the film stars Monica Vitti and Richard Harris.
The new print, struck from the negative, will be shown nightly except Mondays at 5:30, 7:40 and 9:50, with a Saturday and Sunday matinee at 3:15.

Capturing a Taste for 'Adorable Bad Music'
LEAD: ''Don't analyze music; love it,'' said Francis Poulenc.
It was a characteristic remark.
Celebrated for his wit and elegance (however loud his tweeds), Poulenc was not a graduate of the Paris Conservatory, but of the Sorbonne.
Hence his academic foundation was not musical but literary, and his professional outlook was libertarian: ''For Poulenc composing was a game,'' wrote his fellow Frenchman, the composer and conductor Manuel Rosenthal.


Champlain's Hideaway Islands
LEAD: Maybe it's myopia, or maybe just the glare off Lake Champlain on a sunny day, but a lot of people turn a blind eye to the tiny archipelago off the lake's northeastern shore.
Drivers tend to rush right through, seeing these three islands as little more than a highway from Vermont to Canada.
They hurry west across the sand bridge that became the islands' first land link to the mainland in 1850, twist up Grand Isle and North Hero, ignore the turnoff to Isle La Motte and leave the state and country at Rouses

LEAD: ''Providing a Home for Those on the Run'' [July 15]  profiled the Emergency Shelter for Runaway and Homeless Youths and its services to county youngsters.

LEAD: WHEN the Allstate Insurance Company wanted to lower the cost of automobile insurance in Chicago, it knew that a prime obstacle was rapidly escalating pay for body-shop technicians.

LEAD: Manhattan has been mistaken for a lot of things over the years, but rarely for a county fair.

Bib overalls, of course, can be every bit as useful on Madison Avenue as in the milking barn, what with all those pockets and all that room.

LEAD: ALL the things an adolescent can be,'' laments Thomas S. Anthony, ''is reduced to a three-digit number'' - the Scholastic Aptitude Test score.
Mr.
Anthony, dean of admissions at Colgate University in Hamilton, N.Y., believes that students give too much weight to this number when gauging their chances of being accepted at a particular school.


Golf Strikes Sensitive Nerve
LEAD: The last time Louis J. Willie used his golf clubs, he played on a public course in Birmingham, Ala.
Willie's most vivid memory of the day was having to tee the ball up on every shot to avoid breaking his clubs on rocks that dotted the course.
That was in 1970.
Twenty years later, as the result of a bizarre chain of events that has shaken the golf establishment, Willie is able to play the silklike greens and picture book fairways of the Shoal Creek Country Club in Shoal Creek,

A Ton of Passion and 100 Grams of Patience
LEAD: For a short while, Nicolas de Stael was a name on many lips.
Having lived in poverty during the 1940's on the fringes of a Parisian art scene that was itself beginning to seem marginal, de Stael found himself suddenly, in the early 50's, unable to satisfy the demands of his New York dealer for new paintings.

LEAD: FOR years now President Saddam Hussein of Iraq has been the bad boy of Arab politics, a classic bully who lived by the credo that crime pays and absolute crime pays absolutely.
The Iraqi strongman was at it again last week, invading his neighbor Kuwait, holding up the whole country for its oil and gold, and then daring the world to do something about it.

But if the designs of new buildings or of those built or renovated within the last few years are any indication, bland-looking vestibules are a thing of the past.

World Markets;   The Unsettling Iraq Factor
LEAD: SADDAM HUSSEIN, the President of Iraq, bet that Kuwait was vulnerable and it was.

Players Sued
LEAD: Two police officers who were on plainclothes duty in Madison, Wis., the night of June 28 say things got pretty rough when they tried to subdue a man who they say was acting obscenely outside a tavern and his two companions intervened.
Indeed, according to a series of civil damage suits the officers filed Friday, the three, Chris Chelios of the Chicago Blackhawks, Gary Suter of the Calgary Flames and David Lundeen, a former teammate of the two pros at the University of Wisconsin, ''showed a complete disdain and disregard'' of the officers' ''inherent dignity as human beings.


Flashcard
LEAD: THERE were 40,407,540 students enrolled in 83,165 public elementary and secondary schools in the United States during the school year 1988-89.
California is home to the most public schools, 7,312 of them, while Delaware, with 168, has the fewest.

As the Crow Talks
LEAD: For people who notice such things, there has recently been an unaccustomed hush in nature.
The wind sighed and other birds called, but nature's great conversationalist, the crow, was hardly uttering a caw.
With young crows not long out of their nests, the parents were keeping quiet, lest predators discover their fledglings.

No Headline
LEAD: By midsummer, when Israelis seek relief from the Middle East's sweltering heat, Jerusalem is the only truly comfortable spot in the country.

LEAD: A country club with an all-white membership is an indictment of racism.
A PGA Tour event in an all-white country club is an endorsement of prejudice.
Simply stated, the PGA Tour needs to evaluate its position on prejudice and racism.
NEAL SCHNEIDER
New Paltz, N.Y.

Demolition Next Door
Question: I have received notice that the house attached to mine will be demolished.
My home is brick and I am worried that after this building is torn down I could have water seepage and other problems.
What steps must be taken to insure that the party wall will be restored?


Playing Himself
LEAD: As a starstruck 17-year-old, David Hampton feared he would never win stage fame on his own, so he latched onto someone else's.
It began one night in 1983 when he simply had to get into Studio 54 and hit upon the ruse of posing as Sidney Poitier's son.
It worked so well he used it again - for a free meal in a trendy restaurant - and again and again to gain access to the homes of some wealthy and well-known New Yorkers.

Some Memories Of Life With Father
LEAD: The recent article ''A Man Who Doesn't Know His Son Is Married'' (Opinion page) brought back not too far-off memories of my own life with my father.

Plagued by his own insecurities, as his children grew and matured, he felt threatened and left behind.


Vermont's Classic Villages
LEAD: There is a Vermont we carry around in our imagination, and a Vermont that really exists, and it's in the hill towns of the state's back roads where vision and actuality coexist best.
A white church steeple framed by sugarloaf hills of maple and birch; weathered red houses progressing backward into connected red barns; a stream bending around the village in a line of alders; freshly cut meadows rising up from the town's back; a general store selling insulated boots in August, sunflower seeds in March.

Flashcard
LEAD: HIGH school football and basketball games are the mainstay of sports attendance in the United States, according to a Gallup Mirror of America poll conducted in February.
More Americans attended high school football games during the previous year than either college or professional football games.
The same held true for high school basketball.

At Play on a Working Farm
LEAD: There is something almost mythic about a farm: the sun setting on rolling green pastures, the swoop of barn swallows on their way to the nest, the new life (newborn calves, lambs, kittens, puppies) that seems to crowd the small corners of the cavernous barn.
It is the place to view The Farmer - that embodiment of the work ethic - on the job, and to have a glimpse of the livelihood that, as Americans, seems somehow our birthright.


Talking: Roofs;   Making Decisions On Repairs
LEAD: Literally at the top of most maintenance programs for a single-family house should be its roof.
A leaky or damaged roof can be the source of a multitude of water problems.
A roof that is worn or buckled or has missing tiles can also be an eyesore - and a visual barrier to quick or easy sale.


Answering The Mail
LEAD: Q. My house has a forced-air furnace that is about 14 years old.
A heating contractor the heat exchange unit is badly rusted and he recommends replacing it because the heat exchanger is so bad and because the old unit had insufficient air flow.
He says that the new furnace would have 90 percent efficiency and would save about 40 percent in gas costs.

Flashcard
LEAD: MORE than half of all public libraries in the United States do not have any librarians on staff whose primary responsibility is attending to children, who are major users of public library resources and services.
Four out of ten public libraries have fewer than two full-time employees, which means librarians must be generalists.


Races to Watch
LEAD:
WASHINGTON
Jolene Unsoeld, a freshman Democrat elected by just 618 votes in 1988, is running in a tough environment: the designation of the Northern spotted owl as a threatened species could eventually cut thousands of logging jobs in her district, the Third.
Her opponent, former State Representative Bob Williams, advocates weakening the Endangered Species Act to permit continued logging.


Pastimes;   Stamps
LEAD: The quality of United States stamp production is excellent.
Mistakes are seldom made, and when they are, stamps that come off the presses lacking perforations or some colors, or with part of the design upside down, are almost always found by postal inspectors and destroyed.
That's almost always.
There has been a mini-epidemic of errors in the production of the Lighthouse booklet, the strip of five 25-cent stamps.

A New Taste (Afghani) in Huntington
LEAD: HISTORIC Huntington Village now has an Afghani restaurant.
Incongruous as that might seem, it is not a bad fit.
Huntingtonians have long demonstrated their love for Greek food by supporting three storefront Greek restaurants within two blocks of each other.
There are some similarities between the two cuisines: souvlaki becomes shish kebab and baklava translates to bughluva.

The Endangered Civil Service
LEAD: However well-intentioned and enlightened its policies, any government, from the White House to the local motor-vehicle registration office, is only as good as its workers.
For the Federal Government, this undeniable truth has recently spelled trouble.
It seems to be getting ever harder to staff top-flight political positions, where the turnover rate on average has been about 18 months.

LEAD: Organizers for the 1992 America's Cup regatta in San Diego have set residency limits on sailors and yacht designers to prevent individuals from working for more than one country.

Resisting Hitler
LEAD: To the Editor:


Flashcard
LEAD: DURING the last 14 years the number of college degrees awarded to women has increased on all levels.
In this same period, the number of degrees earned by men has declined; the exception is associate degrees.
In 1989 women earned the majority of associate's, bachelor's and master's degrees as well as more than a third of doctorates and first-professional degrees, such as medical, law, dentistry or theological degrees.

Works in Progress;   The Lady and the Tiger
LEAD: Siberian Tigers are the largest of all cats, weighing up to 700 pounds, and white Siberian tigers might be the rarest.
First bred successfully four years ago by Robert Baudy at the Rare Feline Breeding Center in Florida, there are now six in the world.
Five are with Baudy; the sixth, Kita, (above and right), lives in Westfield, Ind.

LEAD: This hamlet in Orange County, N.Y., squeezes about 60 galleries and shops into one main street less than half a mile long.
But there is no big billboard heralding that fact, and the galleries themselves, in 200-year-old houses, look like the long-time residences they are, except for their own tiny hand-painted signs, often camouflaged by overgrown trees.

Horned Owl Is Rare on L.I.
LEAD: The report on the Activities of Volunteers for Wildlife (June 10) was of such good will and so helpful to our cause we hesitate to reply lest we seem ungrateful.

This species is common on Long Island.


Argentina's Glittering Trove
LEAD: Excited by stories of a mountain of silver, the colonizing Spanish in the early 16th century gave the name Rio de la Plata - River of Silver - to the great South American river system that ends at Buenos Aires.
In the Andes, along the continent's western rim, their dreams would be fulfilled.
So abundant was the supply of the glittering metal that in the 17th century, in Potosi alone - now part of Bolivia - more than 3,000 mine shafts were opened.


IN SHORT: NONFICTION
LEAD:
KEEPING WATCH: A History of American Time.
By Michael O'Malley. (Viking, $19.95.) In tracing the ways timekeeping has evolved in the United States, Michael O'Malley quotes Lewis Mumford's claim that ''the clock, not the steam engine, is the key machine of the modern industrial age.'' There were clocks in the American colonies as early as 1638; by 1700, roughly one white adult in 50 owned a clock and one in 32 a watch.

Catching Guadeloupe's Beat
LEAD: On a trip to Guadeloupe last June, I stopped at a roadside chicken stand somewhere on the well-paved southern coastal road between Ste.-Anne and St.-Francois.
The small outdoor restaurant was empty but as the sun was setting six men came along.
One started playing a large drum.
Another responded with livelier rhythms on a smaller drum.


PRINCE CHARMING COMES BACK
LEAD: In ''Prince Charming Comes Back'' (Hers, July 15), Daphne Merkin notes that men are bewildered or angry about the movie ''Pretty Woman.'' But she doesn't bother to examine why.
We women, she writes, ''still need our myths, our amatory fictions; they help us endure.'' However, I doubt Merkin would be sympathetic to men who ''need'' to fantasize about physically beautiful, intellectually inferior, sexually submissive women to help them endure.

Tech Notes;   NASA's New Hydrogen Ramjet
LEAD: RAMJETS don't have turbines, so they can't ''breathe'' and can't carry a plane aloft.
But once in flight, these simple jets ''ram'' air into their engine compartments, where it is mixed with fuel and burned.
At high speeds, ramjets are lighter and more efficient than conventional jet-turbine engines.

LEAD: As far as any bridge historian can remember, there has never been a tie in the final of a National Knockout Team Championship.
Never, that is, until two weeks ago in the Grand National in Boston.
The event began at grass-roots level nine months earlier and was down to two teams.
At stake was a major title and the right to compete in playoffs to determine the United States representatives in the World

Mr.

LEAD: OVER half the public radio stations in the United States - 200 in all - are operated by universities, as are 92 public television stations.

Fashion;   LEGS!
LEAD: It's not that leggy fashions are exactly new - after all, the short skirt has been around so long that it's almost ancient.

With a skintight fit and wild patterns in bold colors, they are bound to start leg legends anew.
The eye-boggling bodysuit, or cat suit as it is sometimes called, is a style trend that has been taken up by designers and comes in every price range.

Hosteling Through Europe
LEAD: Hosteling is a frame of mind, an alternative psychology of travel.
As a hosteler you carry your house on your back: your bedroom is a soft white envelope of top sheet, bottom sheet and pillowcase sewn together and called a sheet sleeping sack; your kitchen is a water bottle, a blue enamel cup, a cheap stainless steel spoon and a Swiss army knife; your bathroom is a toiletries bag and a towel; your desk a notebook and several foreign stamps.

INTERNATIONAL
Iraq Marches, Kuwait Crumbles and the Markets Convulse

LEAD:
CLASSICAL
Chopin: 24 Mazurkas
Charles Rosen, piano. Globe CD GLO 5028. CD only.
Chopin composed more than 50 mazurkas.
On this disk Charles Rosen presents a cross-section from the very earliest to the last.
The mazurkas are amazing works in which Chopin far transcends superficial nationalism.

Question Box
LEAD:
An Old Refrain
Q.
Back in 1957, when Walter O'Malley was threatening to move the Dodgers to Los Angeles, a song was recorded imploring them not to leave Brooklyn.
What was the song and who sang it?
A.
The song, ''Let's Keep the Dodgers in Brooklyn,'' published by Famous Music Corporation, was made popular by Phil Foster, a comedian from Brooklyn who viewed O'Malley's intention as no laughing matter.

Seifert Makes 49ers His Own
LEAD: GEORGE SEIFERT stuck his hands into everything.
He coached his players and he coached his coaches.
He was not a good listener.
His teams won 3 games and lost 15.
He was fired. ''It was a learning experience, for sure,'' said Seifert, recalling his stint as Cornell's head coach in 1975 and 1976, a time when he possibly grew the most as a coach but was still nearly run out of town by alumni who were never in favor of his selection.

GOLF
Kite Rolls In $6 Million: Tom Kite rolled in a 15-foot birdie putt on the first playoff hole yesterday to defeat John Cook in the St.
Jude Classic in Memphis and become the PGA Tour's first $6 million man.
Kite hit a fairway iron to the green on the 13th hole, the first of sudden death, while Cook's approach landed in a leftside bunker.

LEAD: Alan Rothenberg, a Los Angeles trial lawyer who has had no formal ties to soccer for more than six years, was elected today as president of the United States Soccer Federation.

The Author, On 'Grapes Of Wrath'
LEAD: In 1953, as a student at Columbia, I wrote a paper on the ''Grapes of Wrath'' for a literature course.
Although I knew John Steinbeck only through his novels and stories, I mailed the critique to him.
To my surprise and delight, I received a letter from him by return post.
It was handwritten (so was the 200,000-word ''Grapes of Wrath'' manuscript) on a yellow tablet.

LEAD: The Times Mirror Company said on Thursday that it had agreed to purchase 50 percent of La Opinion, one of the nation's largest Spanish-language daily newspapers.

LEAD: If Israelis are hard on the outside and sweet on the inside, as local folk wisdom says, then a good part of their toughness probably comes from the constant struggle against a battered economy, where taxes are all-encompassing, prices are higher than in Manhattan, and meager salaries seldom stretch to the end of the month.

Editors' Note
LEAD: An article and a chart about food magazines on the Media Business page of Business Day on July 23 unfairly portrayed a 1986 circulation loss at Gourmet.
Gourmet's editors point out that the magazine acquired the subscription list of a defunct publication, Cuisine, in 1984 and filled the unexpired Cuisine subscriptions.

George Stavrinos, 42, Artist and Illustrator
LEAD: George Stavrinos, a graphic artist and illustrator who helped revive interest in finely drawn representational art, died Friday at Beth Israel Hospital in Manhattan.
He was 42 years old and lived in Manhattan.
He died of complications of pneumonia, his sister Lydia said.
Mr.
Stavrinos graduated from the Rhode Island School of Design in 1970, and his drawings and illustrations soon began to appear in The New York Times, Gentleman's Quarterly and Cosmopolitan.


Record 44th Homicide Listed in Bridgeport
LEAD: Bridgeport has listed its 44th homicide this year, matching the record set in all of 1988.


Naturalists Split by Panther Sightings in East
LEAD: PEOPLE say they are seeing panthers in New England and neighboring areas of Canada.
But do the sightings, even if authentic, mean the stealthy big cat is breeding again in the Northeast decades after its presumed extinction there?
The question has split naturalists into fervent believers and skeptics demanding foolproof evidence.

LEAD: Pittsburgh's Randy Tomlin pitched a five-hitter in his major-league debut tonight, but he didn't have time to enjoy it.

LEAD: The Board of Education offered yesterday to put back on the street more than 100 police officers now giving instruction in police work and crime-prevention to pupils in New York.


Review/Opera;   Bilingual New Production of 'Ariadne auf Naxos'
LEAD: ''Ariadne auf Naxos'' is an opera about compromise, composed by a man of the theater who believed in the tactics of accommodation and who practiced them in his art and his life.
During World War II Richard Strauss let himself be used by the Nazis in the belief that he was using them, with unhappy effects on his reputation.

LEAD: Prices of ''junk bonds'' dropped sharply yesterday as investors worried that many of the low-rated companies that have issued such high-yield securities would have trouble meeting their obligations if higher oil prices caused a recession.

Yesterday morning Mr.
Walker pulled up to the curb and Elvi dashed from the car, leaving the door open.

Mr.
Marsalis and Mr.
McLean seared the melody of Mr.
McLean's ''Bird Lives,'' tearing through the tune with two impressively assured improvisations so bursting with ideas and momentum that the piece barely held them.

Careers;   When Going To Executive Search Firms
LEAD: The role of management recruiters, also known as ''headhunters'' and ''search consultants,'' seems to confuse many executives, especially those who have suddenly lost their jobs.
In desperation, they deluge recruiting firms with resumes and telephone calls demanding interviews immediately.
