LEAD: *
Allen P. Adamson has been appointed senior vice president and group director at Ammirati &amp; Puris.


Genentech Agrees To Delay Merger
LEAD: Roche Holding Ltd. and Genentech Inc. agreed to a United States Government request to extend until Aug. 31 the waiting period required under Federal antitrust law for review of their proposed $2.1 billion merger.
The Federal Trade Commission had requested more information on the merger on March 23, and the two companies said in a joint statement that they were now in ''substantial compliance'' with that request.


More Speed From Muscle Power
LEAD: IN a race of muscle-powered watercraft on Saturday, a light hydrofoil built mostly of aluminum achieved a speed of 17.45 miles an hour, believed by race organizers to be a world record for its class.


Lotus Is Cutting Its Marketing Staff
LEAD: The Lotus Development Corporation has imposed a cost-cutting program that will result in the layoff of about 40 workers, mostly from the company's marketing department.
The company, which employs 3,100, said that it was still hiring in some areas and that the net reduction in workers would be about 20 people.


Climate Roller Coaster In Swedish Tree Rings
LEAD: NEW evidence from Sweden reveals that the average summer temperature in far northern Europe has fluctuated almost seven degrees over the last 1,400 years, illustrating how widely the earth's climate varies naturally and suggesting that in the northernmost parts of the world, the effects of any global warming will be hard to feel for a long time.


Bar Group Votes Neutrality on Abortion
LEAD: Lawyers at the American Bar Association's annual meeting called upon the group's policymaking body today to abandon its stance favoring abortion rights and return to neutrality on the issue.


Rig Count Off in Week
LEAD: The number of rigs exploring for oil and natural gas in the United States dropped by 30 last week, to a total of 966, Baker Hughes Inc. reported today.
A year ago the count stood at 874.
The decline was attributed to weak gasoline prices in the last few months.


Trader Settles Anti-Fraud Charges With the S.E.C.
LEAD: Salim B. (Sandy) Lewis, a former leading Wall Street trader, settled Federal civil anti-fraud charges today that he had manipulated the price of a stock in 1986.
Mr.
Lewis was also barred from the securities business.


Dow Plunges by 93.31; Stocks Slide in Tokyo
LEAD: Stock prices plunged again yesterday as continuing tensions in the Middle East pushed up oil prices, leading to investor fears that inflation will heat up.


Investor Increases Stake in Henley
LEAD: The Lebanese investor Toufic Aboukhater has raised his stake in the Henley Group Inc. to 9.11 percent from 7.67 percent.
He disclosed late last month that he had asked Government regulators for permission to increase his holdings in the Hampton, N.H., manufacturing concern to more than 15 percent.


Bodyguard Is Convicted in Case With Links to Drug Agent's Death
LEAD: A Federal jury in Los Angeles has convicted the last of a group of four defendants charged with a number of crimes that included the kidnapping and killing of a United States drug agent in Mexico.

Mr.
Agee succeeds Frank M. Adams, who died on May 27 in an airplane crash.

LEAD: The police today defused a bomb they believe was planted by the Irish Republican Army in an attempt to kill a retired British official.


Long-Term Treasury Yields Soar
LEAD: Prices of long-term Treasury bonds took their worst battering yesterday since the days just before the 1987 stock market crash, although bargain hunters prevented the interest rate on the benchmark 30-year bond from moving higher than its level of May.


New British Sports TV
LEAD: British Aerospace Communications Ltd. said today that it would start a satellite television sports service for British pubs and bars.
The sportscast service, which is a unit of British Aerospace P.L.C., will initially concentrate on showing live British rugby league matches on Sundays, with highlight programs on Monday and Tuesday evenings.

LEAD: CONCERN has been increasing over the possibility of adverse health effects from computer monitors.


Savings Deal Questioned By Senators
LEAD: After hearing James M. Fail acknowledge that he made incorrect disclosures to Federal regulators in 1988 when he purchased 15 insolvent savings and loans, members of a Senate panel said today that they were seriously troubled by the deal's inadequate disclosures and questionable finances.

LEAD: Because of an editing error, a short article with a listing headed ''Movies This Week'' in the Television section on Sunday misidentified an actress in ''The Baker's Wife,'' which will be shown at 1 o'clock tonight on Bravo.
The runaway young wife is played by Ginette Leclerc; Marlene Dietrich does not appear in the movie.


U.S. and Vietnam Hold Talks on Cambodia
LEAD: The first formal talks on Cambodia between the United States and Vietnam were held yesterday in New York, and both sides called them useful, although they were evidently inconclusive.

Odor Flashbacks
Q.
Occasionally one smells an odor and then smells it again hours later.
Are odor molecules still in the nose, or is it psychological?
A. ''It could happen either way, but in most cases it is probably psychological,'' especially if it is a very bad odor, said Solomon H.


A.T.&amp;T. Is Adding To Its Stake in Sun
LEAD: Sun Microsystems Inc. agreed to sell about 4.6 million shares of common stock to the American Telephone and Telegraph Company for $191.8 million.
The sale, when completed, will increase the amount of Sun stock that A.T.&amp; T. has acquired directly from the Mountain View-based computer company to 14.7 percent.

FACING BOYCOTT, IRAQ SLOWS OIL: THE IRAQI INVASION;   BLOCKADE IS HINTED
LEAD: American and British officials said today they would be prepared to organize an international naval blockade of Iraq to insure enforcement of economic sanctions imposed on the country by the United Nations.


Psychologist's Tapes Can Be Used in Trial In Couple's Murder
LEAD: Conversations between a psychologist and two brothers after their parents were slain can be used as evidence in their murder case, a judge ruled today.


Repairing the Blink
LEAD: Surgeons have devised a procedure in which a tiny gold weight implanted in the eyelid restores the blinking ability to patients with facial paralysis, researchers say.
The pull of gravity on the weight mimics nerve function and allows people who have a weakened or damaged facial nerve to close their eyes in an almost natural fashion.


Grubb &amp; Ellis
LEAD: The Grubb &amp; Ellis Company, a real estate broker, said it would close some offices, cut back some operations, eliminate a number of jobs and reduce travel and advertising spending to save about $7 million during the rest of 1990 and $11.5 million in 1991.
The company said it was closing commercial real estate brokerage offices in southeast Denver; Detroit; the Atlanta area; Princeton, N.J., and New York.

Mitsubishi Assists Venezuela Venture
LEAD: The Mitsubishi Motors Corporation will provide technical assistance for a joint venture to produce its passenger cars in Venezuela beginning in September.
A Mitsubishi spokesman, Kyoichi Shimada, said the joint venture, MMC Auto Motriz de Venezuela S.A., would produce 800 passenger cars this year primarily with parts shipped from Japan.


Jury Trials Not Needed in Drunken Driving, Court Rules
LEAD: The New Jersey Supreme Court ruled today that motorists accused of drunken driving are not entitled to jury trials, even though those convicted for the third time can be jailed for six months, fined $1,000, pay thousands of dollars in insurance surcharges and lose their right to drive for 10 years.

HORSE RACING
Majesty's Time Prevails Majesty's Time outfought favored Candid Cameron through the stretch to carry Jorge Chavez to a 2 1/4-length victory in the $85,200 Albany Handicap for horses 3 years old and up at Saratoga.
Candid Cameron, with Dave Penna up, was easily second best in the five-horse field, finishing 15 1/2 lengths ahead of Applebred and Jean-Luc Samyn.


Only a Bruise for Swift
LEAD: The Seattle Mariner pitcher Bill Swift, struck on the forehead by a line drive at the Kingdome while pitching against Minnesota on Sunday night, was released yesterday from a hospital after undergoing tests.
Swift, who was sprawled on the mound for four minutes after being hit by a drive off the bat of Gary Gaetti, suffered only a bruise and was expected to make his next start on Saturday.

LEAD: The productivity of American workers improved for the first time in six quarters, climbing in the second quarter at an annual rate of 1.6 percent, the Labor Department said today.


Bethlehem Sells Vessels
LEAD: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation said today that it would sell two Great Lakes ore vessels and would recognize a gain from the transaction.
The company said it had signed a letter of intent to sell the Lewis Wilson Foy and the Sparrows Point to the Oglebay Norton Company.
After the deal is completed, Bethlehem Steel will be left with a fleet of two 1,000-foot vessels used to ship iron ore pellets from Minnesota to the company's Burns Harbour, Ind., plant on Lake Michigan.

LEAD: The Firstar Corporation and Banks of Iowa Inc. said today that they had agreed to merge in a stock swap valued at about $200 million.

Magellan Nears Venus in Trip to Map Surface
LEAD: AFTER a 15-month voyage from Earth, looping the Sun one and a half times, the Magellan spacecraft is approaching Venus.
Scheduled to arrive Friday, it is primed to conduct the first detailed mapping survey of the planet's mysterious surface, which lies beneath a perpetual covering of dense, acrid clouds.

LEAD: The economic fallout from the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait has quickly filtered to the airline passenger, with higher oil prices already translating into higher air fares.
Two airlines will add surcharges or raise fares on Thursday to offset their higher fuel costs, and several others are considering a similar move.

Chevron in Bolivia Pact
LEAD: The Chevron Corporation said today that its Chevron International Ltd. (Bolivia) unit had signed an agreement with the Government of Bolivia to explore for oil and gas in a 2.5-million-acre area in the Andean foothills.
Chevron said it would evaluate the feasibility of drilling exploratory wells at the Caipipendi block, 400 miles southwest of La Paz and 200 miles south of Santa Cruz, the country's oil center.

LEAD: Nothing marked the euphoric and triumphant march of the Reagan Administration into Washington in 1981 more than two policies - a ''free market'' in oil (in lieu of energy independence) and a massive strategic weapons buildup.
Last week, nine years and $1 trillion later, we found ourselves threatened by our dependence on Middle East oil and unable to mount a quick and effective military response to the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait.

Iraq Jams Voice of America
LEAD: Iraq has been jamming the Arabic-language broadcasts of Voice of America for three days, the radio network said today.
The network, run by the United States Government, said it would try to beam its programs to Iraq through satellite television tonight.
The jamming has affected much of Voice of America's broadcasting to the Middle East, including the Persian Gulf and Jordan, said the network's deputy director, Robert Coonrood.

Farm Land Values Up
LEAD: The value of farm land in the Midwest continues its climb in the second quarter of 1990, a new survey indicates.
The survey of 420 agricultural bankers in Illinois, Indiana, Iowa, Wisconsin and Michigan indicates that farmland values rose 1 percent in the April-to-June period.
That means farmland values are up 33 percent from their lows more than three years ago, said Peter Heffernan, an analyst for the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago.

The bra is back in swimsuits.


Futures Chief's Severance Pay
LEAD: The former chairman of the Chicago Board of Trade, Karsten Mahlmann, who stepped down amid charges that his trading firm had misused customer's funds, will get $120,000 in severance pay, officials of the futures exchange said on Tuesday.


Council Questions Brown on Efforts to Fight Crime
LEAD: The New York City Council aggressively questioned top Dinkins administration officials yesterday about their efforts to fight crime, with one committee chairman saying New Yorkers now know ''how the average Roman felt while Rome burned and Nero fiddled.''

LEAD: Joe Morris reads it in the newspapers and hears it on television and radio.
He hears people say he is not the runner he was, that his job is in danger, that when the pro football season begins in less than five weeks he may no longer be a Giant.

LEAD: The most serious charges filed against a 33-year-old messenger who the police identified as the so-called Dart Man were reduced to misdemeanors yesterday by the Manhattan District Attorney's office.

LEAD: To the Editor:


Confrontation in the Gulf; Strategy: Embargo;   U.S. Bets Its Troops Will Deter Iraq While Sanctions Do the Real Fighting
LEAD: By sending American troops to Saudi Arabia, President Bush moved to deter an Iraqi invasion and committed the United States to a long stay in the Middle East kingdom, gambling that a steady tightening of economic pressure will force President Saddam Hussein out of Kuwait, Administration officials said today.


Ex-Jet Is Barred as Broker
LEAD: William H. Mathis, the captain of the New York Jets football team that won the Super Bowl in 1969, was barred today from the securities business for two years for his role in an insider trading scandal in 1984.


Review/Television;   Pessimistic Look at Parole System
LEAD: If there is any promising element in America's system for dealing with criminals, parole is not it.
That is the message of ''Convicts on the Street: One Year on Parole,'' tonight's streetwise documentary, at 10:45 on the HBO cable network.


Ex-Nynex Worker Tells Of Purchases
LEAD: The Nynex Corporation made previously unacknowledged purchases from employers of two men who helped organize lewd parties in Florida for the company's purchasing managers, according to testimony filed yesterday with the New York State Public Service Commission by a former Nynex executive.


Arthur Tildesley, 58, A Priest in New Jersey
LEAD: The Rev.
Arthur H. Tildesley, an Episcopal priest, died on Saturday at his home in Fair Haven, N.J.
He was 58 years old.


Jets Will Rely on Former Chargers
LEAD: The reconstituted Jets, so new in so many ways, will be unveiled for the first time in an exhibition game on Saturday night against the Eagles in Philadelphia.
No one will remember for long who wins or loses, but there will be a close inspection of the various new parts of the New York team.


Smithsonian Agrees to Share Sculptor's Estate With Town
LEAD: A highly publicized dispute between the town of Rockport, Mass., and the Smithsonian Institution has been resolved in a settlement that declares the town to be the rightful beneficiary of a $1 million bequest from a local millionaire's estate.


Metro Matters;   Life Goes On: Shrugging Off Crime and Fear
LEAD: Rosemary Baker hummed to herself on the No. 5 train to the Bronx on her way to work at a construction site.
She shrugged off fears of crime, even after the rash of violence in recent weeks that has left four children dead.


Jury in Barry Trial Reviews Videotape Of Mayor at Hotel
LEAD: The jury weighing the Government's drug and perjury case against Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. took another look today at an 84-minute videotape that shows him smoking crack and being arrested in a room at the Vista Hotel here last January.
But the Federal panel recessed without announcing any verdict.


Profit Up 47.5% At SmithKline
LEAD: SmithKline Beecham P.L.C., the British-American health and household products company, said today that its second-quarter profit jumped 47.5 percent from the period a year ago because of continued sales growth, strong operating profits and large debt reduction.

LEAD: John T. Wilson, a former president of the University of Chicago, died Saturday at Rush Presbyterian St.
Luke's Hospital in Chicago.
He was 76 years old.

Lawyers Shift on Abortion
The American Bar Association's policy-making body abandoned its stand favoring abortion rights and instead embraced neutrality.


Corrections
LEAD: An article yesterday about remarks by Justice John Paul Stevens before the American Bar Association misstated his educational background.
His undergraduate degree is from the University of Chicago; his law degree is from Northwestern University.


A New Kind of Crisis
LEAD: For the first time in many years, an American President has discussed a grave international crisis and the serious actions it requires of him without issuing a call to arms against Communism or raising the old, familiar cold war fears.


Baseball Notebook;   Brewers Fighting Yankees for Last
LEAD: Until a couple of weeks ago, even the possibility would have been unthinkable.
Now, however, the Yankees are within sight of sixth place and have a legitimate chance of escaping a last-place finish.
They owe it all to the Milwaukee Brewers.
The Yankees, who have been in last place for two and a half months, since late May, were nine and a half games from sixth as recently as July 26.

LEAD: The entertainment and electronics giant Thorn EMI P.L.C. said today that it was buying a British music publishing company with rights to such musical titles as ''Stormy Weather'' and ''Itsa Itsy Bitsy Teeny Weeny Yellow Polka Dot Bikini.''

LEAD: The Lincoln Center Out of Doors festival offered a tantalizing glimpse of a fine young company when it presented Ballet Concierto de Puerto Rico on Tuesday at the Damrosch Park Band Shell.
In its first Manhattan performance, the 12-year-old company presented a tasteful selection of classical and modern ballet pieces, several of them featuring Diana Perez, a 15-year-old who won a gold medal at the 1990 International Ballet Competition in Jackson, Miss.

LEAD: Iraq said today that Israel was preparing to attack it using planes painted with American colors.

Parent &amp; Child
LEAD: A 4-YEAR-OLD boy threw torn pieces of bread at the seagulls that greedily swooped to claim the free meal.
One gull was more aggressive than the others and was clearly getting the most food.
The boy looked at the bird sternly and sharply admonished him with the words he had apparently been hearing at home: ''You're not sharing!

Prescott A. Tolman, Executive, 80
LEAD: Prescott A. Tolman, a retired vice president of the E. F. MacDonald Incentive Company and a sport fisherman, died on Friday at St.
Luke's Hospital in Bethlehem, Pa.
He was 80 years old and lived in Swiftwater, Pa.
He died of leukemia, his family said.
Mr.
Tolman joined MacDonald, the Plaid Stamp company that is now part of the Carlson Marketing Group, in 1952 and was vice president for international relations when he retired in 1982.


Currents;   Highchair For Future Lifeguards
LEAD: CHILDREN can now eat in a highchair that looks like a lifeguard's chair.
Its designer, Caleb Kercheval, calls it the Hampton Highchair.


British Airways Net Up
LEAD: British Airways P.L.C. said Tuesday that its first-quarter profits rose 79 percent despite a slower rise in sales.
British Airways' profits for the three months that ended June 30 came to $:111 million, or about $194 million, up from $:62 million in the corresponding period a year earlier.
The carrier's sales rose 14 percent, to $:1.33 billion, or about $2.3 billion, from $:1.17 billion.

LEAD: Two months after voting to deny unemployment benefits to thousands of temporary census workers, Congress has decided to reverse itself.

Washington at Work;   Modern Cassandra With a Message That Angers but Still Wins Support
LEAD: A basic tenet of Washington politics is that bad news doesn't sell.
Jimmy Carter found that out in his now-infamous ''malaise'' speech, when he painted a picture of a country entering a moral and economic decline, a speech that many analysts say was the beginning of his political demise.


Dean Witter to Appeal
LEAD: Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. said this week that it would appeal a court ruling ordering it to pay $23.4 million to Daniel Waite, a former commodities broker who was dismissed in 1982.
Mr.
Waite contended that Dean Witter, a unit of Sears, Roebuck &amp; Company, had libeled and slandered him in filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission and in a statement to a potential employer.

For Higher Gas Prices, Many Villains to Blame
LEAD: Paul Evantoff paid 5 cents a gallon more this morning to fill his gas tank at Fred's Chevron than it did last week, a development he attributed to the eagerness of the big oil companies to cash in on the turmoil in the Middle East. ''It's really greed with a capital 'G,' '' Mr.
Evantoff said.

LEAD: The United States briefed its NATO allies today on its decision to send troops to Saudi Arabia and encouraged them to participate in an international force being formed in response to Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, NATO officials said.

LEAD: The East German Parliament raised new doubts about the timetable for unification today when it failed to ratify an accord outlining procedures for joint elections with West Germany.

LEAD: Think of the worst pain you ever experienced.
Now double it.
That is how one sufferer with cluster headaches described the pain that accompanies his attacks, which occur about five times a day for two or three weeks at a time, then mysteriously disappear for six months or more.

RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:
SKIING
Roth Wins Opening Race Peter Roth of West Germany overcame 13 rivals with a sizzling second run and won the opening slalom race of the 1990-91 World Cup season by a hundredth of a second over Michael Tritscher of Austria yesterday in Mount Hutt, New Zealand.
The victory was the 29-year-old Roth's first in 12 years on the World Cup circuit.


Jamaica Swaps Debt for Equity
LEAD: Jamaica said last week that it had agreed with Mexico on a debt-equity swap program that would reduce the island's Government debt by $30 million.
The program means Mexican citizens can buy Jamaican Government debt at 42 cents on the dollar.


Confrontation in the Gulf;   Cuomo Says Air Guard Unit Is to Join Forces in the Gulf
LEAD: Governor Mario M. Cuomo said tonight that a unit from the New York Air National Guard will join United States forces in the Persian Gulf.


Underpaid in Salary Scheme, 21 Sailors to Get $32 Million
LEAD: In what shipping industry officials call the largest wage award in maritime history, a Federal district judge has ordered that 21 Filipino sailors be given $32 million to make up for a wage system in which some were paid only a fraction of what was reported by ship owners.


Burmese Forces Said to Fire On Marchers Led by Monks
LEAD: Burmese security forces opened fire today on a peaceful dawn march led by Buddhist monks in Mandalay, killing at least four people, Western diplomats in Rangoon said.


Farm Credit Bank's $275 Million Issue
LEAD: The Federal Farm Credit Bank is offering $275 million in system bonds due in 1995 through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley &amp; Company.

LEAD: Fay Vincent, the commissioner of baseball, said yesterday that any attempt by George Steinbrenner to revise an agreement that limits the control of the Yankees' principal owner over the team could lead to further serious sanctions against him.

LEAD: The Federal Bureau of Investigation has settled a lawsuit against it by a black agent who complained he had been a victim of racial discrimination, the bureau said today.

LEAD: To the Editor:


Karl Weber, 74, Dies; Actor and Guild Leader
LEAD: Karl A. Weber, an actor and former president of the Screen Actors Guild of New York, died on July 30 at New England Baptist Hospital in Boston.
He was 74 years old and had homes in Fort Myers, Fla., and Edgartown, Mass.


Savings Bond Sales Up
LEAD: Americans bought $629 million worth of United States savings bonds in July, up 4 percent from the period a year earlier and 2 percent from June, the Government reported on Tuesday.
The Treasury Department said July's purchases brought total sales for the first 10 months of the 1990 fiscal year to $6.58 billion, up from $6.57 billion in the corresponding period of 1989.

LEAD: Under heavy pressure from state officials, New York City today legally committed itself for the first time to a broad series of water-conservation measures.

LEAD: A caption in some copies of Sports Pages yesterday about the New York Jets training camp misidentified the coach shown.
He was Bruce Coslet, the head coach.

LEAD: Tamara Deutscher, a writer and editor who with her husband, the late Isaac Deutscher, researched the leaders of Soviet Communism, died on Tuesday in London, where she lived.
She was 77 years old and, according to family friends, had suffered from emphysema.

LEAD: A United States District Court judge in New York ordered a conservative religious organization yesterday to distribute a correction to a pamphlet used to press its view that the National Endowment for the Arts is supporting pornography.

LEAD: The use of common sunscreens may increase the risk of developing melanoma, a deadly skin cancer, two researchers have suggested.
But other dermatologists caution that the theory is speculative and remains to be proved.

LEAD: Japanese stock prices fell sharply today, wiping out all of the Tokyo market's gains from yesterday.

LEAD: A Queens bank chairman was arrested yesterday on charges that he had bribed a Federal tax agent to end an investigation of his finances and then prompted the agent to investigate three of the bank's customers.

LEAD: FOR contrarian investors in bank stocks, willing to fight the downward trend in prices and steady flow of bad news, the problem in recent months has been to know just which hour is the darkest one that precedes the dawn.


New Drug From an Old Preparation Offers Hope Against Bladder Cancer
LEAD: Last year at the American Urological Association meeting, 1,500 physicians signed a petition to the Food and Drug Administration extolling the virtues of a tiny germ that causes tuberculosis in cows.
The germ has emerged as an effective, if unlikely, weapon against certain bladder cancers that might otherwise require surgery to remove the organ.

LEAD: A Swiss Red Cross worker who had been held hostage in Lebanon for 10 months was freed today and handed over to Swiss authorities, officials and witnesses said.

LEAD: To compensate for rapid increases in fuel prices, the Interstate Commerce Commission said yesterday that trucking companies could increase shipping rates with only three days' notice, rather than the seven days normally required.

LEAD:
THE OIL JOLT
Oil prices fell and financial markets steadied around the world after the U.S. decision to send troops to Saudi Arabia and reports that the oil-rich kingdom will increase its production.
But the calm seemed tentative, with the economic outlook hinging entirely on the uncertain prospect of developments in the Middle East.

LEAD: Nearly one-third of Americans are ''shelter poor,'' spending so much of their income on housing that they cannot afford other necessities, a study released today said.

Jacques Soustelle, Leader in Fight For a French Algeria, Dies at 78
LEAD: Jacques Soustelle, an anthropologist and former Cabinet minister who was one of the leaders of an underground movement that fought against Algerian independence, died Tuesday in the Paris suburb of Neuilly-sur-Seine.
He was 78 years old.
The cause of death was not reported.
Dr.
Soustelle, who was named to the Academie Francaise in 1983, was one of Europe's foremost experts on pre-Colombian civilizations in Mexico, on which he wrote several authoritative studies.

LEAD: A bulletproof vest stopped a shot that could have killed a 24-year-old police officer in the South Bronx yesterday morning, officials said.
The officer, Joseph T. Dietrich, was listed in stable condition at Jacobi Hospital with a blunt trauma wound to his abdomen.
The bullet, from his own gun, was said to have been fired by an auto-theft suspect.

LEAD: The New York State Public Service Commission said yesterday that poor training of Consolidated Edison workers led to the explosion of an asbestos-lined steam pipe in Gramercy Park last year that killed three people and injured 30 others.

Eugene F. Black, 87, Ex-Justice in Michigan
LEAD: Eugene F. Black, a former Michigan Supreme Court justice, died Saturday at his home in Port Huron, Mich.
He was 87 years old.
The cause of death was not announced.
Justice Black was a member of the State Supreme Court from 1955 until 1972, when he returned to private practice.
He was Attorney General of Michigan from 1946 to 1948.

LEAD: Wade Omer Martin Jr., Louisiana Secretary of State for 32 years, died Monday at his home in Baton Rouge, La.
He was 79 years old.
The cause of death was not given.
Mr.
Martin, a lawyer, was elected Secretary of State in 1944 at the age of 33.
He quit in 1976 to run for governor.
After defeat in that race, he retired to private practice and served as a consultant to the Louisiana Elections Integrity Commission.

Home Improvement
LEAD: CEDAR closet lining, which repels moths without the need for chemicals, is not difficult to install as long as the surfaces are suitable.
As noted last week, there are two types of lining; sheets are less expensive and easier to install, but many people find them less attractive than strips.
Either kind can be fastened to flat, smooth walls, or to furring strips if the wall has bumps or hollows.

Economic Scene;   How Hussein Miscalculated
LEAD: The crisis in the Persian Gulf struck at a time when demand for oil was weakening and prices sagging.
In fact, Saddam Hussein's decision to gobble up Kuwait was driven by his need to shore up Iraq's failing economy, undermined by the long war with Iran.
So he has put his unemployed, million-man army back to work, both to grab his neighbor's oilfields and refineries and also to panic the world oil market into a steep run-up in price.

Soviet Lake Offers Look at Evolution
LEAD: Scientists probing the depths of Lake Baikal in the Soviet Union have discovered heat escaping from cracks in the lake bottom to support rich communities of exotic life, much like those around hydrothermal vents in the midocean ridges.
It is the first time such a phenomenon has been found in fresh water.

Court Suspends Whistleblower In Corruption
LEAD: A lawyer who played a major role in exposing corruption in New York City government by disclosing he had paid kickbacks on a city contract has been suspended from practicing law for five years for his part in the scheme.


The Editorial Notebook;   Vietnam Again, for the First Time
LEAD: Fifteen years after North Vietnamese tanks smashed into Saigon's Presidential Palace, there are still two Vietnams.
The Republic of (South) Vietnam, that artificial creation of French colonialism and cold war politics, is no more.
But commercial capitalism, the American presence and the Viet Cong-led insurrection pressed a distinctive subculture onto the South.


Officer Kills Suspect in a Chain-Snatching
LEAD: A transit police officer chasing a chain-snatcher across several blocks of the Bronx yesterday caught the young man as he hopped into a gypsy cab and shot him to death in the back seat, the police said.


5 in Queens Indicted in Drug Ring
LEAD: A New York State investigation into a major Colombian drug cartel has led to the indictments of five Queens residents on cocaine-trafficking charges and has shed light on what the authorities say is the structure of the cartel's New York operations.


Rob Moore Stays Close To Home
LEAD: Most football players don't go home for lunch.
It's too far, in all senses of the word.
But whenever the schedule allows, Rob Moore travels three miles down Hempstead Turnpike to visit his family.

Review/Jazz;   Thoughts On America By Ellington
LEAD: For most of the second half of his career, Duke Ellington, in concert, brought together his hits with longer, more ambitious works.
Stung by the mixed critical reception of ''Black, Brown and Beige'' in 1943 and forced by financial necessity, Mr.
Ellington walked the line between the traditional function of the big bands, which was to keep a dancing audience happy, and his own aspirations as a serious composer.

LEAD: There are people who will see Mel Gibson in absolutely anything.

LEAD: A construction company owner who illegally demolished four buildings in Times Square in the middle of the night in 1985 was shot to death Wednesday in front of his house in Brooklyn in what the police described as a mob-style slaying.

More Caution by Sponsors After Shoal Creek Furor
LEAD: The scandal over a country club's racially exclusionary membership policy will make corporations more cautious about paying to associate their names with athletic events, a $2 billion industry that until now has been growing explosively.


Study Offers Hope for Reducing Assault Injuries
LEAD: Perpetrators of family violence often have records of repeated violence, a new Federal study shows, leading researchers to suggest that people at high risk could be identified.
This would allow the development of strategies to prevent the assaults, significantly reducing injury and death, the researchers said.

Auctions
LEAD: 3 houses in London to sell rock memorabilia, including Presley's library card and first driver's license and much from the Beatles.
Going by the collected wisdom of 1960's rock songs, summer is a time for surfing, romance, street-fighting or just getting gritty on the city streets.
Songwriters seem not to have caught on yet, but in the last decade summer has also turned into a hot time for buying and selling rock-and-roll memorabilia.

LEAD: The nation's governors are calling for a Presidential commission to investigate the savings and loan mess.
The head of the Federal bailout agency, L. William Siedman, is asking for an extra $50 billion just to get him through next year.
As Congress heads toward its August recess, there is a rush to sponsor bills to create a special prosecutor, extend the statute of limitations, provide more investigators.

LEAD: Foote, Cone &amp; Belding Communications Inc., the Chicago-based agency, said yesterday that its second-quarter earnings rose 9.4 percent, to $7.5 million, or 73 cents a share, from $6.8 million, or 67 cents a share, in the comparable period last year.
Revenues rose 6.4 percent, to $84.7 million, from $79.6 million a year ago.

LEAD: While the New York region is proportionally less dependent on energy than other parts of the country, the higher oil prices that have prevailed since Iraq invaded Kuwait endanger a local economy that is already among the frailest in the nation.

LEAD: In an abrupt shift, the leaders of West and East Germany agreed this evening to hold the first all-German elections since 1933 on Dec. 2.

Sallie Mae Notes
LEAD: The Student Loan Marketing Association, known as Sallie Mae, will redeem on Sept. 10 all of its outstanding 9.25 percent fixed-rate notes due Sept. 10, 1992, which were issued in 1987.
The notes will be redeemed at 100 percent of the principal amount, with interest accrued up to Sept. 10 of $46.25 per $1,000 principal amount.

LEAD: In a case that is likely to present some uncomfortable legal issues, an Oshkosh man is to stand trial next month on charges of sexually assaulting a 26-year-old acquaintance suffering from what has been diagnosed as multiple personality disorder.

Results Plus
LEAD:
BASKETBALL
United States Beats South Korea
The United States routed South Korea, 146-67, yesterday in a game that was a far cry from the harried overtime victory over Greece on Wednesday in the opening game of the world championships in Buenos Aires.
Alonzo Mourning scored 29 points in less than 19 minutes to lead the United States, which shot 73 percent from the field and outrebounded the South Koreans, 54-17.(AP)

LEAD: To the Editor:


Hurricane Sets Off Floods, Killing at Least 23 in Mexico
LEAD: A hurricane killed at least 23 people this week when raging torrents swept into a river valley in eastern Mexico, devastating homes, roads and farmland, the authorities said today.


Money Fund Assets Up
LEAD: The assets of the nation's 522 money market mutual funds increased by $6.03 billion, to $401.94 billion, in the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.
The assets of the 169 institutional funds increased by $1.39 billion, to $100.29 billion; 249 general-purpose funds were up by $3.7 billion, to $139.42 billion, and 104 broker-dealer funds increased by $946.9 million, to $162.24 billion, the institute said.


Sandinista Leadership Rethinking Its Ideology
LEAD: In the past, Sandinista leaders reserved terms like ''coercion,'' ''authoritarianism'' and ''abuse of power'' to describe mortal enemies like the deposed Somoza dictatorship and the Reagan White House.
Now, the Sandinistas have turned that language on a new target: themselves.


5,000 More Police Officers Are Needed, Panel Asserts
LEAD: Saying New York City's crime problems are not hopeless, a business-sponsored anti-crime group offered a formula yesterday that it said could turn back the clock a generation and restore the streets to forgotten levels of safety.


Some Oil Companies Cut Prices
LEAD: Several major oil companies cut or froze their wholesale gasoline prices yesterday.
Others said that any price increases would be reasonable.
And all the companies that made statements vigorously defended their pricing practices, which have come under strong criticism from consumers, who have faced sharp price rises at gasoline pumps in the last week.


Janet Nevins Young, Executive, 61
LEAD: Janet Nevins Young, the executive director of the Van Hornesville (N.Y.) Community Corporation and a former insurance industry executive, died on Tuesday at her home in Van Hornesville.
She was 61 years old.
She died of cancer, a nephew said.
Mrs.
Young was a personnel manager for the Equitable Life Assurance Society and for the Mutual of New York Insurance Company for 20 years.


Midway Airlines' St. Louis Routes
LEAD: The Chicago-based Midway Airlines, which offered service between Midway Airport in Chicago and Lambert Field here from 1980 through 1984, will re-enter the St.
Louis market starting on Oct. 1.
With five round-trip flights a day, Midway could fill a gap created by Trans World Airlines Inc., which is rumored to be planning to pull out of Midway at the end of September.


Dollar Is Mixed in the U.S., Lower Abroad; Gold Gains
LEAD: The dollar turned in a mixed performance in United States trading yesterday after moving mostly lower in earlier dealings abroad.
Gold prices gained.
Interest in the dollar as a safe investment haven waned in the absence of fresh Middle East hostility, currency dealers said.


Polaroid to Build $90 Million Plant
LEAD: The Polaroid Corporation said it planned to build a $90 million plant in New Bedford, Mass., to make advanced films for its new electronic imaging system called Helios.
The plant is expected to be operating in late 1992, and it will create more than 100 jobs.

LEAD: The shares of the Eastchester Financial Corporation fell yesterday after the North Fork Bancorporation said it was pulling out of an acquisition of Eastchester for $20 a share.

North Fork said it was not prepared to complete its offer to buy Eastchester based on Eastchester's financial condition as of June 30.

LEAD: Two freight trains collided near this northwest Georgia town early today, killing two conductors and an engineer and injuring four other railroad employees.

Washington Talk;   Iraq Puts Election Truisms To Test
LEAD: All the uncertainty in the Persian Gulf has insured at least one thing at home: this fall's elections, which weeks ago seemed but a hodgepodge of races with little national focus, will now revolve heavily around the economy as it sags under the burden of rising oil prices.


Private Art Collection Is Stolen in Moscow
LEAD: Thieves made off with the largest private art collection in the Soviet Union Union after breaking into an apartment and tying up the owner, Izvestia reported this week.


New Incentives On Ford Models
LEAD: The Ford Motor Company said it would offer four-year loans at 4.8 percent on selected car lines and $1,000 cash rebates on others.
The low financing and rebates end on Sept. 26, the date of the official introduction of Ford's 1991 models.
The 1991 Escort and the Ford Explorer are in showrooms and are exempt.


Toyota and GKN Pact
LEAD: GKN P.L.C. said this week that it had an exclusive order to supply constant-velocity driveshafts to the Toyota Motor Corporation for Toyota's new passenger car to be built in Britain.
The car will be built at Toyota's new plant in Derbyshire in central England.
Initial output is expected to be 100,000 vehicles annually, rising to 200,000 at full capacity.


THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Chiat/Day Management Is Shuffled
LEAD: After announcing last week that it was laying off 30 of its 150 employees in New York, Chiat/Day/Mojo said yesterday that it has reorganized the top management at the troubled office.


Dorothy Gillam Baker, Educator, 84
LEAD: Dorothy Gillam Baker, a scholar and educator who researched patterns of development in world history, died on Aug. 3 at Albert Einstein Hospital in the Bronx.
She was 84 years old and lived in the Bronx.


Confrontation in the Gulf;   U.S. Says Turkey Plans To Cooperate on Iraq
LEAD: In a crucial strategic development further isolating Iraq, the United States and Turkey laid the basis today for expanded military and intelligence cooperation to counter President Saddam Hussein, a Bush Administration official said.


Confrontation in the Gulf;   Baghdad Seals Off the Exit Of Foreigners Across Border
LEAD: Iraq informed the United States today that thousands of Americans and other foreigners stranded in Iraq and Kuwait since last week may not leave, the State Department said.


Barry Juror In Hospital; Deliberations Held Up
LEAD: Deliberations in Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr.'s drug and perjury trial were suspended today when one of the jurors was hospitalized for what her doctor called stress and depression.


Six Accused In $3.7 Million Insider Case
LEAD: Government lawyers in New York and Washington yesterday accused a former associate at a prominent New York law firm, his sister and four others of earning at least $3.75 million from illegal insider trading from 1984 to 1988.


IRAQ DETAINS FOREIGNERS, UPSETS SUMMIT;   ARAB ROLE UNCLEAR
LEAD: Just hours after worried Arab leaders arrived here today for emergency talks to ease the crisis caused by the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait, the meeting was postponed for a day when an unexpected Iraqi delegation showed up seeking to thwart Arab participation in a multinational military force.


Electronics Executive Surrenders on Charges
LEAD: The president of a Tampa electronics company surrendered to the Federal authorities here today on charges that he sold substandard electronic parts to the Government that wound up in missiles and the space shuttle program.


Bad Hop in 10th Helps Expos Trim Pirates
LEAD: Andres Galarraga scored from second base in the 10th inning on Mike Fitzgerald's bad-hop grounder when Don Slaught did not cover home plate to give the Montreal Expos a 7-6 victory tonight over the Pittsburgh Pirates.


Earl R. Zack, Pyschologist, 77
LEAD: Dr.
Earl R. Zack, a psychologist and an educator, died yesterday in Sarasota Memorial Hospital in Florida.
He was 77 years old and lived in Sarasota.


Hostages in Iraq? Their Families Think So


E.P.A. TO TIGHTEN DIESEL FUEL RULE
LEAD: The Environmental Protection Agency said today that it would require an 80 percent reduction of sulfur in diesel fuel sold for vehicles driven on the highway starting on Oct. 1, 1993.


More Airlines Raise Fares
LEAD: More airlines raised their fares today, and an industry spokesman attributed the increases to fuel prices that ''have gone through the roof.''


Prominent Speculator Is Indicted in Japanese Stock Case
LEAD: Prosecutors today indicted one of Japan's best-known and most politically influential stock speculators, Matsuhiro Kotani, today on charges that he manipulated a stock.
But the prosecutors left many disappointed when they indicated that the inquiry was now likely to end.


U.S. Files Suit Against Georgia, Charging Bias in Election Laws
LEAD: The Justice Department filed a lawsuit today challenging Georgia's election system, which requires candidates to participate in a runoff if none receive 50 percent of the vote in primary elections.

LEAD: Charles Miller and his 18th-, 19th- and 20th-century European and American furniture travel to some 30 antique shows every year, crossing the country from Maine and Florida to California.

Quayle Warns Haiti to Hold Fair Election
LEAD: Vice President Dan Quayle warned Haitian leaders today that the United States would cut off economic aid to this Caribbean nation if general elections scheduled for November are not free and fair.


Confrontation in the Gulf;   No Saudi Request Yet, Pakistani Army Says
LEAD: A spokesman for the Pakistani armed forces said today that there had been no request so far from Saudi Arabia for Pakistani troops to augment an international force facing the Iraqis.


Donaldson To Head Big Board
LEAD: William H. Donaldson, one of the three founding partners of Donaldson, Lufkin &amp; Jenrette Inc., was named chairman of the New York Stock Exchange yesterday.
He will replace John J. Phelan Jr., who will retire in January.


English Eyes Mavericks
LEAD: Alex English has agreed to a contract with the Dallas Mavericks, but he won't sign until he has a chance to meet with the team's owner, Donald Carter, The Dallas Morning News reported yesterday. (AP)


Net Up 24.6% At Wal-Mart
LEAD: Wal-Mart Stores Inc. reported today that it had a 24.6 percent gain in its second-quarter profit as revenue also increased by the same rate.


CHRONICLE
LEAD: MEL GIBSON, exhausted from playing the title role in FRANCO ZEFFIRELLI's film of ''Hamlet,'' says he is taking a break after working in four movies back to back.


Outdoors;   Contestants Set Creations Afloat
LEAD: YOU will have to scramble a bit - the deadline for submitting an entry form is Monday - if you wish to take part in the River Project's annual instant boat contest.
This year the contest will be Aug. 25-26, and even if you don't wish to participate, you might enjoy watching the zany event.


Equity Will Reconsider 'Miss Saigon' Decision
LEAD: Mayor David N. Dinkins said yesterday that he was ''reaching out to Actors' Equity'' to see if he could help in the dispute that has led to the cancellation of the planned Broadway production of the London hit musical ''Miss Saigon.''


Private Police Patrols Have Reduced Crime
LEAD: Private security patrols working with the police have cut crime in one midtown Manhattan district, new figures show.

He was Ambassador Saud Nasir al-Sabah of Kuwait.

A Voyage to Italy, as Seen in Postwar Cinema
LEAD: A dank, sunless morning.
A distracted young woman with the features of a high-fashion model (Monica Vitti) walks along the bank of a ship canal.
She holds the hand of her small son, pulling him along as if he were a wooden duck on wheels.
She is distracted, but she looks terrific, her dark reddish-blond hair set off by the soft green of her cloth coat, which is, of course, couture.

2 U.S. Premieres in Merkin Hall Season
LEAD: The American premieres of Sir Harrison Birtwistle's ''Ritual Fragment'' and Handel's opera ''Siroe,'' a concert performance of Rameau's ''Castor et Pollux'' and a four-concert ''American Folk'' series are to be part of the Merkin Concert Hall 1990-91 season.


Corrections
LEAD: An article on Aug. 2 about the social season in Saratoga Springs, N.Y., incorrectly described the criminal conviction of Peter M. Brant, a Greenwich, Conn., polo player and racehorse owner.
He was convicted of willful failure to maintain tax records, a misdemeanor, not tax evasion, a felony.
Two corporations of which he was president, the BATO Company and Riviere du Loup Newsprint Ltd., pleaded guilty to willfully filing false tax returns, a felony.

Chain-Snatcher Killed by Police Had Jail Record
LEAD: The 24-year-old Bronx man who was killed by a transit police officer on Thursday was a small-time marijuana dealer who had a history of snatching gold chains on the subway and fighting with police officers when they tried to arrest him, law-enforcement officials said yesterday.

LEAD: It would be foolish to venture grandiose conclusions about the state of new Western classical music from the offerings of any of the annual Tanglewood Festivals of Contemporary Music.
This is just one festival, after all, with one set of calculations - esthetic, historical, cultural and political - about how to make up representative programs.

LEAD: With the 1990 figure for foreigners applying for asylum in West Germany passing the 100,000 mark this week, and hundreds of thousands of East Germans and ethnic Germans from farther east in Europe jamming into the country, feelings against non-Germans and non-West Germans are rising.


Bridge
LEAD: For players brought up to believe that 26 points makes a game, it is tempting to suppose that three no-trump must necessarily be easy when the combined hands have 29 points and all suits are stopped at least twice.
But consider the diagramed deal played early this year at the Cavendish Club in New York City and reported by the East player, Sid Rosen.

LEAD: For years, New York City's Transit Police have muddled along under confused management: the head of the Transit Authority is responsible for policy, and the city's Police Commissioner is responsible for operations.
Now the confusion has turned dangerous.

Equity Plans to Meet on Thursday
LEAD: Actors' Equity announced yesterday that it would meet on Thursday to re-evaluate its decision not to let the English actor Jonathan Pryce appear on Broadway in ''Miss Saigon,'' the hit musical in which he is starring in London.
In rejecting Mr.
Pryce, Equity had said it could not ''appear to condone the casting of a Caucasian in the role of a Eurasian.


Mortgage Rates Jump
LEAD: Fixed-rate mortgages jumped into the double digits for the first time in a month and averaged 10.08 percent this week, according to a national survey released today by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation.
The rate was up from 9.84 percent last week and was the highest since mortgage costs averaged 10.11 percent for the week that ended on July 13.

LEAD: The Coca-Cola Company and Cadbury Schweppes P.L.C. have decided in principle to build a new soft-drinks factory in England.

Last Stand for the Adirondacks?
LEAD: Any map of the Eastern United States shows it laced with roads -parks and wild lands appear as lonely green islands.
Just about the only exception is in northern New York, where the Adirondack Park covers an area the size of Yosemite, Yellowstone, Glacier and Grand Canyon National Parks combined.
The Adirondacks are not green by accident.

LEAD: The Southmark Corporation has emerged from bankruptcy, a little more than a year after it filed for protection from creditors because of problems with bonds it had issued.

LEAD: Iraq, with 17 million people, boasts of having a million-strong army, but some experts in the United States and abroad who have studied Iraqi demographics and intelligence reports estimated yesterday that the number of active forces may be half that amount.

LEAD: By a slight margin, the people of France want their armed forces to fight alongside the United States in the event of war involving Iraq, according to a poll made public on Friday.

LEAD: By saying today that as many as 100,000 United States troops would be committed for duty in Saudi Arabia, Administration officials doubled the estimates provided two days earlier.

LEAD: Pentagon officials said today that the American force mobilized to defend Saudi Arabia against possible Iraqi attack could reach 100,000 in a matter of months, and President Bush warned Baghdad not to try to ship oil through an undeclared allied naval blockade.


Donald R. Heiges, 80, A Lutheran Educator
LEAD: The Rev.
Dr.
Donald R. Heiges, a former president of two Lutheran seminaries, died yesterday at the Lutheran Retirement Village in Gettysburg, Pa.
He was 80 years old.
A funeral home spokesman said Dr.
Heiges died of cardiomyopathy, a disease of the muscular tissue of the heart.

Review/Jazz;   Alto Saxophonist Leads Improvisation
LEAD: It usually takes a jazz group the first few days of a weeklong stand to loosen up, to find the sort of improvisational empathy that defines a good performance.
Not so with the alto saxophonist Arthur Blythe's group, which came out fighting at the Village Vanguard on Tuesday night, and on Thursday was playing with the excitement and spontaneity that's normally heard only toward the end of an engagement.

Among Salvadoran Rebels, A Split Over Rights Accord
LEAD: Rebel fighters here and around the country are sharply criticizing a human rights accord recently reached with the Government and are pressing their commanders to take a harder line in coming talks in San Jose, Costa Rica.


Barry Guilty on One Drug Count; Mistral is Declared on Felonies
LEAD: The jury in the trial of Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. convicted him today of one misdemeanor count of drug possession and acquitted him of another misdemeanor drug charge.
But it failed to reach a verdict on the 12 remaining charges, including the most serious ones.


Bryan Holme, Author And Publisher, 78
LEAD: Bryan Holme, an author and retired publisher of photographic and art books, died Wednesday at his summer home in Round Pond, Me.
He was 78 years old and also lived in Vero Beach, Fla.
His son, Christopher, said his father had died of kidney failure.
Mr.
Holme had been the head of Studio Books, a subsidiary of Viking Press based in Manhattan.


New Continental Chief Plans To Transform Line's Image
LEAD: When Hollis L. Harris takes over as the president of Continental Airlines Holdings next month, he will be inheriting a company that has weathered two strikes, two bankruptcies, three aquisitions and seen seven presidents in as many years.
Mr.
Harris's mandate, not surprisingly, is to lend stability to the company.

Review/Opera;   A Carmen Set in the Seville of 1936
LEAD: The New York City Opera's ''Carmen,'' which transports the action forward more than a century to the early days of the Spanish Civil War, once seemed a particularly bizarre example of opera revisionism.
Now, may the ghost of Georges Bizet forgive us, the Frank Corsaro production has come to seem almost conservative compared with the more flagrant directorial ego trips of recent years.

LEAD: For bicyclists who become stiff and sore from riding, Nathaniel Calvert of Rochester, Minn., obtained a patent this week for liquid-cushioned seat covers, bicycling pants and gloves.

Marilyn Horne Cancels Mostly Mozart Concert
LEAD: The soprano Arleen Auger and the violinist Shlomo Mintz are to be the soloists in the Mostly Mozart concerts on Tuesday and Wednesday, replacing Marilyn Horne, who has canceled her scheduled appearances.
A spokesman for Lincoln Center said Miss Horne was suffering from exhaustion.

Corrections
LEAD: An article on Tuesday about problems in raising funds to fight AIDS misidentified an administrator at the Whitman Walker Clinic in Washington.
He is Jim Graham.
The article also misidentified a vice president of the Robert Wood Johnson Foundation.
She is Dr.
Ruby Hearn.


Child World Sale
LEAD: Child World Inc., the chain of toystores, said its directors had approved the sale of Child World's two million shares outstanding at $14 each.
The company will be acquired by a unit of Trefoil Capital Investors L.P.
Child World said completion of the merger is subject to Trefoil's acquisition of the 82 percent stake in Child World held by the CNC Holding Corporation.

LEAD: The American Red Cross announced today that it was reorganizing its regional operations and appointing a new senior vice president to oversee blood services.

Eva Sully Block, Vaudevillian, 88
LEAD: Eva Sully Block, who in the 1930's was a headline vaudeville performer at the Palace Theater and other stages, died on Tuesday at Tisch Hospital in Manhattan.
She was 88 years old and lived in Manhattan.

Corrections
LEAD: An article on Thursday about a report by the New York Public Service Commission on Con Edison's role in a steam-pipe explosion in Gramercy Park misstated the utility's action on a $59,000 fine levied by the Federal Occupational Safety and Health Administration.
Con Edison is appealing the fine, imposed for violations of health and safety standards stemming from the blast; it has not paid it.


Your Money
LEAD: For people who are afraid of the risk that investing in stocks entails - as are many, given the events of the last week and a half - but who want to share in the market's potential for appreciation, zero-coupon convertible bonds offer an answer.

Tornado Hits Staten Island, Uprooting Trees
LEAD: A tornado born of a waterspout swirling in lower New York Harbor spun ashore in southeastern Staten Island yesterday afternoon, toppling dozens of trees, popping out windows and dispatching debris through the air and garbage pails down the streets.


Deliberations Were Earnest and Cordial, Jury Says
LEAD: Jurors in the drug and perjury trial of Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. said tonight that despite their inability to reach a verdict on 12 of 14 charges, their deliberations were cordial, earnest and apparently free of racial strife.


2 Cereal Giants Fight Over Shredded Wheat
LEAD: To the nation's biggest cereal makers, shredded wheat is worth fighting for.
And their arena is the courtroom, as well as supermarket shelves.


News Summary
LEAD: International
2-9
Arab states voted to send troops to join American forces in Saudi Arabia, leaving Iraq isolated with only Libya and the Palestine Liberation Organization openly backing the isolated Iraqis in the crucial decision.
Page 1
American forces in the Middle East to defend Saudi Arabia against a possible Iraqi attack could reach 100,000 in a matter of months, Pentagon officials said.

LEAD: Sun, sand and water do not always lead to summer fun.

And not all the hazards are obvious.

Guidepost;   Plugging In, Paying Out
LEAD: Every time you flip on a light or an appliance, you're buying electricity.
Each customer's use varies, of course, but on May 1, the average monthly bill for a Long Island Lighting Company residential customer was $83 for 600 kilowatt hours of electricity.
Lilco's and Con Edison's rates are among the highest in the country, so the averages for other areas would have been lower.


The Scorecard: Bumps, Bruises and Hot Heads
LEAD: On the day after their free-for-all with the Philadelphia Phillies in Shea Stadium, the Mets had bumps, bruises, claw marks, one lineup casualty and hostile feelings.
But so far they had no fines or suspensions from the National League office, which said no punishment for either team was likely until Monday.

Corrections
LEAD: An article last Saturday about Soviet-Japanese diplomacy incorrectly characterized a planned visit to Tokyo next month by Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze.
It will not be the first visit since World War II by a Soviet official of that level; Mr.
Shevardnadze went to Tokyo in 1986.

New Deployment in Gulf May Slow Drive for Deep Cuts in Military Budget
LEAD: The commitment of American forces to the Arabian Peninsula is altering the debate over the military budget, promising to slow the momentum for deep spending cuts and to hasten a shift in military planning from superpower standoffs to regional conflicts.


Eason Sparks Jets' Offense
LEAD: The most intriguing drama of the Jets' summer of change emerged in the first half of their preseason opener tonight: Although the Jets led by only 3-0 at halftime, their offense had lifted noticeably after Tony Eason replaced his good friend Ken O'Brien at quarterback in the second quarter.


Secret Service Faces A Rise in Counterfeiting
LEAD: INFLATION, and the drug trade, have aided counterfeiters in Connecticut, says Thomas W. Gardner of the United States Secret Service.

Miss Tang is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs.

Business Diary
LEAD:
OIL AND THE MIDDLE EAST
Prices at the Pump
Gas station owners seemed to react to the oil crisis with the quickened reflexes of commodities traders last week.
Retail prices soared an average of 12 cents a gallon by Wednesday, with analysts blaming psychological factors, motorists blaming gas station owners, gas station owners blaming Arabs and oil companies.


Man Fatally Shot in Yonkers
LEAD: A man was shot dead and a woman seriously injured early yesterday in a private house in Yonkers, the police said.
The man, identified by the police last night as Carmelo Gonzalez, 28 years old, was reported dead at the house, at 711 Scarsdale Road, and the woman was taken to an unspecified hospital in critical condition, they said.


RANGERS ELUDE JAMS, BEATING WHITE SOX
LEAD: Charlie Hough won his third straight decision and the Texas Rangers escaped jams in the seventh and eighth innings today to beat Chicago, 7-5, and drop the White Sox four and a half games behind Oakland in the American League West.
The White Sox stranded 14 runners and could not overcome an early 6-0 deficit.

Q and A
LEAD:
Rental Co-op Up for Sale
Question: I rent a co-op apartment that the owner is about to sell.
If the co-op board approves the new owner, it looks as if he will occupy the apartment.
If this is the case, is there any way I can maintain our rental position past the term of the lease? . . .
D.


Where Have All His Spies Gone?
LEAD: On Normannenstrasse in East Berlin, in the heart of an ordinary middle-class neighborhood, stands a massive office complex: 41 concrete buildings as grimly functional as the apartment towers that surround them.
Nine months ago it was the headquarters of East Germany's Ministry for State Security - the Staatsicherheit - or Stasi, perhaps the most sophisticated and far-reaching espionage organization ever created.


In Search of the Latino Writer
LEAD: To the Editor:


And Now, Doctorates in Development
LEAD: Sarit Rozycki is one of a handful of young New York City developers who have been bidding up prices for prime midtown Manhattan real estate parcels recently.
In her case the goal is to put up a 50-story office tower with retail space that she expects to become the first American home of Harrod's, London's swank department store.

The Hard Thing About Cutting Infant Mortality Is Educating Mothers
LEAD: A PANEL of Bush Administration officials who investigated infant mortality recommended 18 steps to reduce infant deaths in the United States.
Half the recommendations were marked ''high priority'' because they could have a ''direct and immediate effect.''


ARAB TROOPS JOIN SAUDI FORCE; BUSH SAYS HE HOPES THE IRAQIS 'DO SOMETHING' ABOUT HUSSEIN
LEAD: As Egyptian and Moroccan troops began landing in Saudi Arabia to guard against the threat of an Iraqi invasion, President Bush made it plain today that it would please him if President Saddam Hussein of Iraq were to be overthrown.


Go for Wand Outruns Charon
LEAD: Go for Wand seized an early advantage from Charon, held a narrow lead for a mile and then pulled away in the stretch to post a brilliant seven-length victory today in the $217,600 Alabama Stakes at Saratoga Race Track.


Fashion: On the Street;   Ties Are Sizzling With Individuality
LEAD: Neckties, you may have noticed, are loosening up a little.
Gone with the wind are those lockstep power ties that turned gray suits into Wall Street uniforms.
In their place are wider, splashier, more individualistic ties that put zip into any suit, regardless of its color.
Most of these ties trace their roots to Italy, or more specifically, Florence, and their designs, roughly, to the school of Pop Art.


Cambodians Face Loss of Eastern Aid And Trade
LEAD: SOVIET retrenchment and the collapse of Communism in Eastern Europe, hailed in the West as the opening to a harmonious new post-cold-war world, promises yet another disaster for the people of Cambodia, who have already had their share of ravaging at the hands of external forces.

Hammerin' Hank, Joltin' Joe, mr. Cub And Me
LEAD: As soon as i'd gotten the improbable call inviting me to Chicago to play in the Fifth Annual Equitable Old-Timers All-Star Game, my baseball dream merchant appeared.
My vision was pure, uncomplicated: the brick and ivy of Wrigley Field, patriarchal, antediluvian, the baseball acropolis where Babe Ruth called his shot.


Streetscapes: The Columbia Grammar and Preparatory School;   A Lesson on the Boundaries of Historic Districts
LEAD: At first it seems like a startling architectural conundrum.
The new Central Park West historic district excludes the original, 1907, classically styled building of the Columbia Grammar and Preparatory School at 5 West 93d Street.
Yet it includes the school's 1987 gym building directly across the street, at 4 West 93d

Pastimes;   Coins
LEAD: Collectors of United States proof sets may be in for a nice surprise - cents in some of the sets lack a San Francisco Mint mark and this is making such sets valuable.
Within one week of the discovery, proof sets lacking the mint mark on the cent are being bought for $600.

Open Tickets
LEAD: To the Editor: A wonderful part of air travel used to be the ''open ticket,'' which meant passengers could use their prepunched airline tickets whenever they wished.
Open tickets still exist, but they cost an arm and a leg.
Most nonbusiness budget travelers are locked into nonrefundable, nonchangeable flights.

The Town That Pullman Built
LEAD: Preserved first by benign neglect and now by design, the red-brick company town of Pullman, Ill., on the outskirts of Chicago, offers the visitor a revealing course in late-19th-century industrial paternalism.
Though this is textbook social history, Pullman today is very much alive, a real place where people live - people proud of their community's past.

At Division of Motor Vehicles offices, lines will be longer.

Recapturing Maine's Elegance
LEAD: Like wines, antiques of a particular region have a taste of their own.
Although many city shops specialize in country antiques, the collector learns more by regular shopping close to the source - an experience enhanced by local scenic and architectural pleasures.
On the Maine coast, one area rich in antiques of regional interest is along the roads of the peninsulas extending out from this 200-year-old town on Blue Hill Bay, just across the water from Acadia National Park.


F.D.A. to Check on Honey
LEAD: The Food and Drug Administration will test the nation's honey because some produced by a large supplier in Massachusetts was found with 22 times the legal limit of a pesticide.
The investigation, first reported Friday by The Boston Herald, involves apparent misuse of fluvalinate, a pesticide that the Environmental Protection Agency describes as ''low to moderately toxic.

All About/Deodorants;   The Success of Sweet Smell.
LEAD: The human race may owe its rise to the survival of the foulest.
Our hominid forebears, said Louis S. B. Leakey, the anthropologist, smelled so rank that hungry predators recoiled, allowing our unappetizing species to flourish and invent civilization.
Brains and an opposable thumb helped, too.

Ravenna
LEAD: To the Editor: Joan Gould writes of Ravenna: ''Nothing of tourist interest was added from the completion of the mosaics'' (in the sixth century) ''to the opening of Benetton.'' Apparently she is unaware of the Tomb of Dante, a building erected in 1780 to enshrine the older tomb by Pietro Lombardo (1483).

Ravenna
LEAD: To the Editor: Joan Gould's otherwise lovely article on the mosaics of Ravenna (Travel, June 10) misstated the Arian heresy.
The point at issue between the Arians and the Orthodox in the fourth to sixth centuries was not whether Jesus was fully human or a god who merely appeared to be human.
Both sides in the controversy condsidered Him fully human and our fellow sufferer; the idea that he only appeared to be human was a characteristic of several other heretical groups, Gnostics, Apollinarians and Monophysites, each in their own way.


Cookie Lavagetto Is Dead at 77; Hit in '47 Series Ruined No-Hitter
LEAD: Harry (Cookie) Lavagetto, the popular Dodger infielder best recalled for his ninth-inning double that spoiled a no-hitter for the Yankee pitcher Bill Bevens in the 1947 World Series, died in his sleep Friday morning at his home in Orinda, Calif.

The Yankees are no longer the team Randolph spent 13 years playing for; they are not even a facsimile.


Pastimes;   Chess
LEAD: The nicest discovery that a world champion can make about a training match is that it was unnecessary.
And that is the conclusion that Gary Kasparov can draw from his recent six-game practice series with Lev Psakhis at the La Manga Chess Club in Murcia, Spain.

Waiting for Armageddon
LEAD: Some 50 million Americans share a belief that these are the last days.
They are fundamentalist Christians, men and women who consider themselves ''reborn'' and who read the Bible as inerrant truth.
They also, it turns out, read many other books, both fiction and nonfiction - so much so that one of publishing's fastest-growing markets is religious books, from the melodramatic visions of Hal Lindsey to the elegant apologia of C.

Don't Blame Victims, Listen to the Poor
LEAD: I read Barbara Warsaw's ''The Other Side of the Welfare Debate'' (May 27) with resentment.
Once again it seems someone is commenting on poverty, morality and indigence from a middle class armchair.
I don't have any answers for American poverty.
But I get so tired of hearing people suggesting the victims are to blame.


Formica: When a Household Name Becomes an 'Also-Ran'
LEAD: No company likes to be knocked off the mountaintop by competitors, but the experience is especially galling if that mountain bears the company's name.
Consider the case of the Formica Corporation, whose name is to laminated plastic countertops what Xerox is to copiers and Polaroid to instant photography.


Moscow Is Said to Evacuate Bulk of Nationals From Iraq
LEAD: The Soviet Union has evacuated all but 700 of its 8,000 citizens living in Iraq, Foreign Minister Gianni De Michelis of Italy said today.

Championship on Sunday.

Pastimes;   Camera
LEAD: Is it possible to get too much of a good thing when it comes to color films?
It is if you can't figure out which one to use.
In recent years film manufacturers have bombarded photographers with so many new and improved emulsions that for many choosing one has become something of a guessing game.

Style Makers;   Julie Bowman, Umbrella Designer

If it's Julie Bowman, born in Cincinnati, she gets a fine arts degree at Indiana University and looks for a job.
Hired by Totes for its umbrella division, she finds a career.


Ask It No Questions: The Camera Can Lie
LEAD: Ever since its invention a shade more than 150 years ago, photography has been seen as a medium of truth and unassailable accuracy.
Photographs have been used by scientists to map the planets and identify subatomic particles, by police and prosecutors to solve crimes and convince juries, by newspaper and magazine editors to document events around the world - and few think twice about it.

LEAD: Daniel Levy never edited a book before last year, and at 32 he is too young to have been involved in the tumult of the 1960's.
But today the Los Angeles native is the editor of Citadel Underground and edits books about the counterculture.

Living Cells Enter Commerce; Now, Who Has a Claim to Profits?
LEAD: THE biotechnology industry welcomed the California Supreme Court ruling last month that a man was not entitled to share in the profits from a drug developed from tissues removed from his body.
But the case raised questions about the property status of tissues, genes and other biological materials, issues that are not likely to go away.

LEAD: Two advocates of the protection of dolphins say they were intentionally run over by Navy boats on Friday when they tried to demonstrate against a test involving explosives earlier in the day off Key West.

IN SHORT: FICTION
LEAD:
THE HOME GIRLS.
By Olga Masters. (Norton, $18.95.) The women in Olga Masters' stories do not triumph.
They rarely smile and are often mean.
Most simply endure.
Yet they are powerful, somehow positive characters.
Like most of the works of Masters, an Australian who died in 1986, the stories in ''The Home Girls'' tell of poverty, sadness, dreams and lost opportunities, often seen through the eyes of children forced to grow up too soon or women bowed by a relentlessly patriarchal society.


17 Are Hurt When Bus Flips on Way to Airport
LEAD: Seventeen people were injured, none seriously, yesterday afternoon in Queens when an airport bus flipped over on the Van Wyck Expressway service road after hitting a large puddle, the police reported.


Bulls Sign Grant
LEAD: The Chicago Bulls signed their leading rebounder forward, Horace Grant, to a three-year contract extension yesterday.
The agreement, whose terms were not disclosed, ends eight months of talks between Jerry Krause, the Bulls' vice president; Jerry Reinsdorf, the owner of the Bulls, and Grant's representatives, Kyle Rote Jr.


Japanese Discord on Iraq Raises Doubts About Premier's Trip
LEAD: The crisis in the Persian Gulf has stirred unusual discord in Japan over how boldly to assert its leadership in denouncing Iraq and seeking oil supplies from other countries in the region, Government officials say.


Sri Lanka May Move Tamils From a Region
LEAD: President Ranasinghe Premadasa is weighing a plan to evacuate one million Tamil civilians from the line of fire before the army mounts an assault on the rebel-held Jaffna peninsula in northern Sri Lanka.


This Middle Eastern Play Is in Rice
LEAD: SINCE Iraq invaded Kuwait, some investors have been prowling for ways to benefit from the turmoil in the Middle East.
One ''Iraq play'' that has been spotted involves Erly Industries Inc., a Los Angeles-based food processor whose 2.8 million shares are trading at $7.125 over the counter.
Like other thinly capitalized stocks, the shares have fallen modestly since the invasion, but speculative investors think they will drop further because of a disclosure in the company's annual report that one short seller described as ''too good to be true.


Using Plastic Pipe for Plumbing
LEAD: BY using plastic plumbing pipe instead of metal, amateurs can perform many home repairs and improvements that otherwise might require hiring a plumber.


Winners and Losers in the Mideast Crisis Game
LEAD: If life is unfair now, it is about to become even more so for some sectors of American business and industry as the sudden rise in oil prices plays out through the economy.
All companies will be affected to some degree by the fallout from Iraq's invasion of Kuwait.
For some, the impact may range from negligible to potentially catastrophic.

Judge Bars Inquiry in Daily News Labor Talks
LEAD: A Federal judge in Manhattan yesterday barred a New York State board of inquiry from looking into a labor dispute between The Daily News and its 10 unions, saying the panel would intrude on collective bargaining, disclose confidential information and irreparably harm the newspaper.

Review/Cabaret;   Cindy Benson Adds Novelty To Some Familiar Melodies
LEAD: When Cindy Benson was growing up she wanted to be a tap-dancer: someone, as she recalls in her cabaret act, like ''Shirley Temple and Agnes de Mille rolled into one.'' The singer goes on to declare mischievously that she finally got her wish.
In the current Broadway production of ''Cats,'' she portrays a 200-pound tap-dancing feline named Gumbie.


The Editorial Notebook;   Vietnam's Golden Opportunity
LEAD: Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam Vietnam's Communist leaders now have the long-awaited chance to open their country to a brighter economic future.
But that will require them to move away from dogmatic foreign policy positions of the past.
Thanks to Vietnam's withdrawal of its occupation army from Cambodia and Secretary of State Baker's new diplomatic initiative to prevent a Khmer Rouge victory there, direct talks are now under way.

WESTCHESTER GUIDE
LEAD:
DAYS AT THE U.N.


Artist Creates 'Magical Objects' With Fiber Optics
LEAD: CLYDE LYNDS is an artist who combines the talents of a sculptor, a painter, an engineer and a magician.
He casts monumental sculptures in stone; like slow silent fireworks, patterns drawn with points of light seem to move across their surfaces.
Although the lights move as subtly as the hands of a clock, their mesmerizing quality compels the viewer to experience the work in time as well as space.


THE CENSUS: WHY WE CAN'T COUNT
LEAD: I never received a census form, so when The New York Times published a phone number to call to report the omission, I dialed it.
A jolly voice told me that a census taker would come to my home to count me.
I explained that I would be willing to fill out the census form but that my job required intensive travel and it would be difficult to catch me at home for an interview (not to mention that it seemed silly, since my entire ''household'' consists of me).
