LEAD: IN New York City, summers mean Mostly Mozart; but 90 miles away at the new Bard Music Festival, the focus will be on Rediscovering Brahms.
The 600-acre Bard College campus is in Annandale-on-Hudson, just north of Rhinebeck, in the heart of the Hudson River Valley.


Works in Progress;   Grandiose Piano
LEAD: It could be argued that the room shown in the photograph above, at the Steinway &amp; Sons factory in Queens, is where a piano actually begins to be a piano.
Known as the belly department, it is where the innards of the instrument - the metal plate and soundboard - are fitted and set in place.
After all, before it gets there, the piano is something less than musical.


BEST SELLERS: August 12, 1990


The Twin Cities
LEAD: Minneapolis and St.
Paul rise up on the plain like two glimmering mirages.
They are known to outlanders as the Twin Cities, but since there's nothing for hundreds of miles across the farmscape that might invite comparison or confusion, most Minnesotans simply call them the Cities.
They perch on tree-lined bluffs at the confluence of the Mississippi and the lesser-known but equally handsome Minnesota


CORRECTIONS
LEAD: A table last Sunday listing the performance of world stock markets was out of date.
The data, supplied by Goldman, Sachs &amp; Company, were for the week ended July 27.
The table for the week ended Aug. 3 appears today on page 26.


PEAKS TAKE TOLL ON MATTERHORN
LEAD: While this Swiss town celebrates the 125th anniversary of the first ascent of the Matterhorn, the mountain has claimed 10 lives in the first four weeks of the summer.


In Grief, Lockerbie Families Are Divided
LEAD: THE families of the victims of Pan Am flight 103 over Lockerbie, Scotland, bound together by the tragedy of the crash, have been split by a debate over legislation that in large part arose from their anger, grief and determination to prevent future terrorist bombings.


Taking His Mark
LEAD: The lifetime ban of Ben Johnson has proved to be short-lived.
Canadian officials announced last week that Mr.
Johnson would once again be allowed to compete for his country.
The West Indian born Toronto sprinter was told he could never again run for Canada after he forfeited a gold medal in the 1988 Olympics for using steroids.


David Lynch Pushes America to the Edge
LEAD: Four films and a hit television series have established David Lynch as the reigning master of locating the bizarre, the surreal and the disturbing in American life, and his new film, ''Wild at Heart,'' which opens Friday, is certain to further that reputation. ''I like people who are in trouble, in darkness and confusion,'' Mr.


U.S. Gulf Policy: Vague 'Vital Interest'
LEAD: In his statement to the nation on Wednesday explaining the decision to send American troops to the Arabian Peninsula, President Bush said that the defense of Saudi Arabia was of ''vital interest'' to the United States.
But Mr.
Bush and his top aides have not clearly defined just how the Iraqi invasion and annexation of Kuwait touches the lives of Americans or affects their future.


Wendy Light to Wed Danal F. Abrams
LEAD: October wedding plans for Wendy Ellen Light and Danal Frederic Abrams, a son of Lynn E. Abrams and Dr.
Martin Abrams, both of Great Neck, L.I., have been made known by the prospective bride's father, Gerald Light of Floral Park, Queens.


The Split Among Arabs Unleashes a People's Anger
LEAD: FOR Arabs everywhere, it was a momentous week, one in which long-suppressed antagonisms exploded into anger, military action and recriminations.
For the Western powers, it was a week whose benefits and costs are only beginning to be counted.


Northeast Notebook: Providence, R.I.;   Macy's to Open At a New Mall
LEAD: Macy's has announced it will open a store in downtown Providence, which has no major department store.
It will be an anchor of Providence Place, a $300 million mall, office and hotel project to be built not far from the State House lawn.


Question Of the Week;   Should Lawrence Taylor Get A Raise?
LEAD: I was always an offensive groupie until a strong Giant defense, led by Lawrence Taylor, gave me an appreciation for the beauty of the defensive game.
It makes my adrenaline flow to chant ''L.
T.!'' during a game, to watch him - like an animal of prey ready to attack.
What are the Giants waiting for?


Couple Found Shot Dead in Their L.I. Home
LEAD: The Nassau County police are investigating the deaths of a couple who were found by their son on Thursday night shot in the master bedroom of their split-level ranch house.


Share the Work, Share the Bounty
LEAD: THE way Judy Godino sees it, getting the family food through a cooperative buying club only looks like trouble.
Granted, it entails planning weeks in advance, ordering in bulk, making sure someone can take time off from work to unload the delivery truck and separating everyone's order once it all arrives.

LEAD: Worldwide orders for new ships have begun to recover after one of the industry's longest slumps.
Yet the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, for one, has recently disbanded a team of managers, designers and engineers capable of building new ships at the company's yard here.

LEAD: The summer invasion so dreaded by American residents of Paris is in full spate.
As the French Parisians flee their city, heading for the sewage-saturated seashore, on come wave upon wave of our fellow Americans, inundating Paris and our apartments: the friends, the friends of friends, the children of friends of friends, the friends of friends of the children of friends, the whole implacable pack of them determined to live it up in Paris for one-eighteenth of what it costs them to live very simply in, say, Fond du Lac,

Correction
LEAD: An article on July 22 about an increase in the number of women on corporate boards misstated the age of Catalyst, a research and advisory organization for women in the business world.
Catalyst is 28 years old; its Corporate Board Resource service, which helps place women on boards, is 13 years old.


Lifestyle;   Big Mac With Chopin, Please
LEAD: Danny Deaver adjusted the ornate golden candelabrum on the black Baldwin grand, smiled and glided into his Chopin medley.
A polonaise or two later, he peered down from his perch on the restaurant's balcony to acknowledge the applause of the diners below.
Their tables were bedecked with fresh flowers, which also blossom in the men's and ladies' rooms.


The Voltaire Project
LEAD: To the Editor:


If You're Thinking of Living in: Lincoln Square
LEAD: Lincoln Square, the West Side neighborhood dominated by Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts, is not the place for those who feel underdressed when everyone else seems to be in furs and evening dress.


New Yorkers, etc.
LEAD: Never mind the people who get hysterical over nothing, the disorganized, the dillydalliers and shillyshalliers.
It's only to be expected that these types would be prone to panic.
But what about the middle-of-the-roaders, the average Jill and Joe?
And what about the calm, cool and collected, the logical, the organized, the ''nothing fazes me'' types?

Campus Life: Pittsburgh;   Soviet Emigres Find Legal Help In a New Land
LEAD: In Kharkov, a city in the Ukraine, Alexander Kisler could depend on the government to provide his water.
In Pittsburgh, Mr.
Kisler had to depend on a legal counseling service to keep his water free.


Robert W. Cleveland, Executive, 80
LEAD: Robert W. Cleveland, a road builder and heavy-equipment supplier, died on Thursday at the United Hospital in Port Chester, N.Y.
He was 80 years old and lived in Rye, N.Y.
His family said he died of lymphoma.
The company that bears his name was the contractor for road work at several major projects in the 1930's and 1940's, including the New York World's Fair of 1939-40 and the Pentagon in World War II.


Corrections
LEAD: A caption on page 21 of the Arts and Leisure section today, about the movie ''The Exorcist III: Legion,'' misidentifies the actor shown.
He is Jason Miller.


How a Meadow Complements a Lawn
LEAD: A MYTH has risen among some gardeners about lawns.
They think they would rather substitute a meadow in the belief that it would be much easier to keep. ''All you have to do is plant seed, and voila, a meadow!'' So they say.

LEAD: American English is not what it used to be.


Using Plastic Pipe for Plumbing
LEAD: BY using plastic plumbing pipe instead of metal, amateurs can perform many home repairs and improvements that otherwise might require hiring a plumber.


Saddam Hussein, Mideast's Noriega, Has to Go
LEAD: The issue underlying President Bush's moves in the Persian Gulf is not Kuwait or Saudi Arabia or even oil.
It is Saddam Hussein, the Noriega of the Middle East.
Like his Panamanian counterpart, he has to go.
He ought to be disposed of now before his power and opportunity for doing greater damage grows.

LEAD: I think L. T. should get a raise because if you look at the salaries of other football players who are not nearly as good as he is, you see that they earn as much as or more than he does.
The Giants wouldn't be nearly as good without him.
A lot of people go to the games just to see him sack the quarterback.

LEAD: A woman wary of trees, the father of a creature who seems part baby and part worm, a trashy-chic punk heroine and a deadpan Hungarian woman on the road to Cleveland: some movie heroes are deeply weird, in the best sense of the word.
Such socially misfit, funny and appealing characters are most likely to escape from film makers' imaginations at the start of their careers.

CRIME
LEAD: Fat, crude, surly Superintendent Andy Dalziel literally plays God in BONES AND SILENCE (Delacorte, $17.95), the 10th entry in Reginald Hill's outstanding procedural series featuring the bluff Yorkshire detective and his sensitive and contemplative associate, Inspector Peter Pascoe.
The role of the Deity, which Dalziel assumes for a pageant of medieval mystery plays in his cathedral city, suits the Old Testament personality of the detective, who has achieved local fame as ''a man who walked through brick walls as he headed for the truth.

In the Movies, Jazz Musicians Are Destined to Die Young
LEAD: Young, gifted and doomed - that's the prognosis for jazz musicians in the movies.
On screen, jazz is a siren call, an obsession, an addiction that disrupts the lives it touches and consumes anyone under its sway.
The musicians are pure souls, verging on idiot savants, who are so wrapped up in the music that they invariably mess up both business and romance.

LEAD:

H. G. Mangelsdorf, 83, Former Oil Executive
LEAD: Harold G. Mangelsdorf, a petroleum industry executive who spent much of his 40-year career in senior positions with Standard Oil of New Jersey, now Exxon, died on Wednesday at Overlook Hospital in Summit, N.J.
He was 83 years old and lived in Short Hills, N.J.
His family said he died of heart disease.


Correction
LEAD: A map on April 1 with an article about Glacier National Park included an incorrect highway symbol and misspelled a nearby town.
As a reader wrote recently to point out, the highway is U.S. 89, not Interstate 89, and the town is Kalispell.

U.S. Reduces Bonus for Operator of A-Plant
LEAD: Unhappy with the pace of the environmental cleanup at its uranium processing plant in Fernald, Ohio, the Energy Department has decided to deny three-quarters of a $1.67 million semiannual bonus to the company that manages the plant for the nation's nuclear weapons manufacturing complex.

Talking: Docks;   Ebb Tide In Market For Slips
LEAD: Dockominium sales lie dead in the water.
Echoing the direction of the real estate market in general, demand has all but dried up for these slips, some of which had been selling as high as $2,000 a linear foot in the New York area only 18 months ago.


NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Raymond, Me.;   A King Builds His Castle
LEAD: SITTING on a hill in a modest neighborhood in this town of 4,000 year-round residents is a house the locals call the Castle on Mill Street.
It belongs to William King, an architectural draftsman and graphic designer who has been building the 5,000-square-foot dwelling himself, cinderblock by cinderblock, for 18 years.

LEAD: While American universities and corporations worry about a future shortfall of research scientists and engineers, Victor Vigdorchik, a theoretical physicist and mathematician from the Ukraine, works as a home attendant in Brooklyn.

LEAD: On the wall of the Fresh Air Fund office in midtown Manhattan hangs a patchwork quilt decorated with names and designs representing some of the 13 states and countless communities that are the destinations of thousands of poor city children for two weeks in the summer.

Market Forces
LEAD: Very little seafood reaches the table in New York City without passing through hands of criminals, according to Frank H. Wohl.
Mr.
Wohl, who was appointed by a Federal court in 1988 to oversee the Fulton Fish Market with an eye to curbing the racketeering that has long been rampant there, said in a report last week that an ''atmosphere of lawlessness'' persisted.


A Life Spent on One Musical Path
LEAD: ''I like attention being given to special birthdays,'' says William Schuman, ''especially when it means performances.
I think anything that draws attention to your music and gives a pat on the back is a titillation, but as someone said, 'Flattery is okay if you don't inhale.' ''


Question Of the Week;   Should Lawrence Taylor Get A Raise?
LEAD: Definitely, absolutely, positively!
Lawrence Taylor is the best linebacker in the history of professional football.
He is definitely a future Hall of Famer and I would like to see him continue his illustrious career with the Giants.
He puts his heart and soul into the game, and in my book that makes him deserving of a raise.

Fashion;   For Fall, Stylish Feet (and Knees) Are Covered Up
LEAD: What do you wear with leggings, cat suits, ski pants or micro-miniskirts?
Boots.
Or at the very least, shoes that look like boots.
That's the big news in fall footwear.
Even regular shoes are cut high on the vamp for what fashion people call a ''choked up'' look.

Miserable Level of Discourse
LEAD: To the Editor:


Company Wins 4th Exporting Award
LEAD: THE Endresens, father and son, are good at making new money by exporting products to the Old World.
They are so good at it that Jan Endresen, the son and president of the family-owned company, Aerotech World Trade Corporation of White Plains, recently received a special Presidential citation.
It was the same award his father received in 1975 when he headed the business.

LEAD: They were the legal profession's gilded generation, an army of lawyers without limits.
As law students, they were wined and dined and wooed by the most prestigious law firms in New York.
Once hired, they began settling into a frantic but fantastically lucrative life.
It was a life of glamour, prestige and, they assumed, stability.

Dominic's Roman Catholic Church in Oyster Bay, L.I.
Mrs.
Stephenson, 26 years old, graduated from Syracuse University and received a master's in school counseling from Long Island University.


Retracing the Santa Fe Trail
LEAD: The rents that the Santa Fe Trail tore through the earth of Missouri, Kansas, Oklahoma and New Mexico serve as one great metaphor for travel.
Now they are followed ''in pursuit of an experience that is never quite brought to completion.'' (The words are those of the trail historian Marc Simmons.) Traveling the Santa Fe Trail from Kansas City to Santa Fe is addictive, hallucinogenic, for without the forgotten fears of Indian attack or thirst or childbirth to dispel the boredom, finding the historical remains of the trail in the empty prairies becomes a desperate necessity.


Fashion;   Around the Head in a Variety of Ways
LEAD: The ever-popular headband has acquired a new versatility and softness.
In most cases, this means a wide band of fabric pulled on like a ski band and adjusted in a variety of ways to the wearer's liking.

Pastimes;   Around the Garden
LEAD: For This Week: Keep up with transplanting perennials, shrubs, especially conifers, but water everything well so the roots become established.
Mail orders for hardy bulbs that will be planted in the early fall months.
Cut off the stalks of early-blooming hostas and daylilies; carefully remove seed pods from other perennials.


Quotation of the Day
LEAD: ''If that means Saddam Hussein changes his spots, so be it.


THE CENSUS: WHY WE CAN'T COUNT
LEAD: James Gleick's article ''The Census: Why We Can't Count'' (July 15) gets to the heart of our diminished capacity to collect accurate data on a large scale.
The Census Bureau has (admirably, I believe) carried out the census it planned.
However, the size, diversity and mobility of our society have rendered time-honored cenus methods imprecise, at best.


Campus Life: Baylor;   A Ban on Dancing Survives Another Test
LEAD: For a short time last spring, it looked as if the Baylor University students of 1990 would be allowed to do something none of their predecessors had been allowed to do in the school's 145-year history - dance on campus.


SAUDI ARABIA/At a Glance
LEAD:
Vital Statistics
Capital: Riyadh
Population: 12.7 million ('89)
Government: Monarchy. King Fahd took office in 1982.
Area: 839,996 square miles (about one-third the size of the U.S.)
Economy: Oil production is the major industry.
Reserves in '89 were 225 billion barrels, one-quarter of the world supply.


How a Meadow Complements a Lawn
LEAD: A MYTH has risen among some gardeners about lawns.
They think they would rather substitute a meadow in the belief that it would be much easier to keep. ''All you have to do is plant seed, and voila, a meadow!'' So they say.


A Star Is Barred and 'Miss Saigon' Cancels
LEAD: WHEN Actors' Equity voted on Tuesday to bar the English actor Jonathan Pryce from re-creating his prize-winning portrayal of a Eurasian pimp in a Broadway production of the London hit musical ''Miss Saigon,'' a lot more was potentially at issue than the future of the $10 million show, or its record $25 million advance sale, or whether the union even had a legal basis for taking such action.


Baking in the Summer Can Yield Satisfying Desserts
LEAD: AS unappealing as the thought of baking might be on a hot summer's day, the abundance of fruit in the market makes it compelling.
Dessert planning is often resolved by filling pastry or topping cake with peaches, plums, nectarines or berries.

Postings: Coming to White Plains;   14 Modest-Income Condos
LEAD: With state subsidies in place, plans are advancing for a 14-unit condominium in White Plains for buyers with modest incomes.
A one-bedroom apartment would cost $95,991 and a two-bedroom $112,181, said Jane Henderson, executive director of the White Plains Housing Information Service, the not-for-profit developer.

THE CENSUS: WHY WE CAN'T COUNT
LEAD: Gleick is not convincing in arguing that a statistical sample would produce an improvement over the actual census count.
The imperfect art of sampling, and the inevitably political selection of the ''right'' adjustment formula, would add entirely new sources of distortion to the census results.
Gleick seems to forget that we are not talking about stars or fish.


WITH FUEL PRICES SOARING, MAKE PLANS TO DRIVE FOR ECONOMY
LEAD: A lot of people have been wringing their hands, but it was George F. Will who so deftly put his finger on the problem at the pump.


Tech Notes;   M.I.T.'s Video Version of the Hologram
LEAD: The Media Laboratory at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology is experimenting with holograms using a video image.
Holograms, images created on flat surfaces by laser light that appear to be three-dimensional, are now frequently seen as decorative art, on credit cards among other things.
Video hologram technology, when perfected, might offer architects the ability to draw a house on a computer screen and then examine its three-dimensional appearance or it could become the basis of three-dimensional television.

IN SHORT: NONFICTION
LEAD:
THAT PLACE IN MINNESOTA: Changing Lives, Saving Lives.
By Ed Fitzgerald. (Viking, $18.95.) Take an executive at the pinnacle of his profession in an industry that associates creativity with alcohol.
Mix in an exhilarating career full of deals sealed at three-martini lunches.
Add forced retirement at the age of 65 and you have created circumstances, at least for Ed Fitzgerald, as explosive as a Molotov cocktail.


TV Needs More Than 1 Ratings Agency
LEAD: The latest spat over the accuracy of television ratings should not be dismissed as just another round of posturing among symbiotic elements of the advertising industry.
The rift marks no less than the collapse of the ''social contract'' that for decades bound the networks, advertisers, agencies and, ex officio, the viewers they buy and sell.

;   The Spirit of Marsalis With the Swing of Sinatra
LEAD: From Yehudi Menuhin to Stevie Wonder, American music has a long tradition of Wunderkinds, though few if any have demonstrated the range of talents commanded by Harry Connick Jr.
In the last three years, the 22-year-old entertainer from New Orleans has released no less than five albums.
This week three of them - a number matched only by New Kids on the Block - are listed on Billboard's pop album chart.


Putting Prokofiev and Mozart in the Same Basket
LEAD: About all Prokofiev's ''War and Peace'' and Mozart's ''Cosi fan tutte'' have in common, it might be plausibly argued, is that both play in two long acts.
Forget for the moment that Mozart sustains lengths more skillfully than anybody, let alone Prokofiev.
Such gross differences are easy to point out.

LEAD: SICK-BUILDING SYNDROME, a disorder that medical and environmental professionals say is widespread, but largely unregulated, refers to vague illnesses reported by people who work in large office buildings where the windows are inoperable.

Postings: More Lighting;   Meeting Tenant Fears
LEAD: For 40 years, Louis L. Friedman has cursed the darkness and lit a few candles.
As a New York State Senator from Brooklyn in the early 50's, he sponsored a bill requiring landlords to put lights in front of apartment buildings.
He believed this would deter muggers and make it less perilous to navigate stairways at night.

Louis, he and four other youths wrote detailed plans to open a mail-order software company.

LEAD: The Mets want you to know they are not in a swoon, a slump or even a sinking spell.

Complication On Asbestos
LEAD: The fragile alliance forged last week by 10 Federal judges trying to coordinate and resolve quickly tens of thousands of asbestos personal injury disputes will complicate settlement talks in many large cases, making their immediate resolution much more difficult, lawyers and judges said yesterday.


Pennsylvania Job Cuts
LEAD: JLG Industries said Friday that it planned to cut 150 workers at its plant here because of a previously reported softening in its incoming orders.
The latest reductions are in addition to the elimination of about 135 positions at some of the company's foreign and domestic plants, JLG said.
It said current levels of unfilled orders are at 45 days' sales.

LEAD: Rather than take credit for rousing a moribund Jets team, Tony Eason seemed more intent on explaining why his good buddy Ken O'Brien didn't do as well as he did at quarterback Saturday night.

Illegal Guns: Go Get Them
LEAD: In Brooklyn, a young woman leaving early for work hurries back inside her vestibule.
In the schoolyard across the street, the kids are shooting again.
Now she can see the fire leaping from the muzzles of their semiautomatics.
Each year, she reflects, the shooters seem a bit younger.
These kids look to be no more than 13 years old.

RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:
TENNIS
50th for Graf: Steffi Graf yesterday won her 50th pro singles title, defeating Manuela Maleeva-Fragniere, 6-3, 6-2, in the final of the Great American Bank tournament in San Diego.
Graf, who as of Friday will have been the top-ranked female for three years, became the third woman in the 22-year open era to win 50 tournaments or more.

LEAD: Along Route 30, the main road that runs past the Schoharie Creek, there is a blackened void in the center of this village.
Trees have been burned away, and all that remains of a dozen homes and stores are charred stone foundations.

Question Box
LEAD:
Hitless More Than Once
Q.
There have been seven no-hitters in the major leagues this season, with a different team the victim each time: Seattle, Detroit, Oakland, Toronto, St.
Louis, the Chicago White Sox and the Yankees.
Has a team ever been no-hit more than once in a season?
A.
In this century, it's happened 10 times - seven times in the American League and thrice in the National - but no team has ever suffered the embarrassment of being held hitless in a game more than twice in a season.

LEAD: President Bush ordered the United States military today to block exports of Iraqi oil and all imports to Iraq except some food shipments, Administration officials said.
The blockade would fulfill the President's threat to halt Iraqi commerce.


Outdoors: Fishing In a (Bigger) Crowd
LEAD: IT used to be that the only crowd anybody ever noticed on the Missouri River was a tower of tricos, a gray cloud of flies 30 feet high at the water's edge an hour or two after sunrise.
A welcome crowd, for when the flies mated and fell to the water in midmorning a frantic hour or two of trout feeding and trout fishing followed.

Japan Beer Sales Surge
LEAD: The Japanese are reacting to one of the hottest summers in years by consuming beer in record amounts.
Beer sales are rising at such a rapid rate that the Kirin Brewery Company, Japan's top brewer, has raised its profit forecast twice since February.
Kirin attributed part of its recent profit growth to strong demand for its new Ichiban Shibori beer.

Research Probes What the Mind Senses Unaware
LEAD: THE power of subliminal messages is taken as an article of faith by many people.
Critics of advertising often take for granted the power of ''hidden persuaders.'' Many parents stand convinced that messages buried in rock music are poisoning their children's minds.
And for vendors of audio tapes, the power of the imperceptible exhortation to strengthen memory or take off pounds is more than an article of faith - it is a profit center.

Costs Rising for Chemical Industry
LEAD: Higher crude oil prices are starting to affect prices in the chemical industry, a leading consumer of petroleum products, executives of chemical companies say.
And because products derived from crude oil are used to make many of the basic materials that go into a host of other products, notably plastics, consumers will soon feel the pinch.

LEAD: Words: After all the aggression, alarm, councils of state, hostages and troop movements, the controversy of the instant in the Iraq-Kuwait crisis is merely semantic.
Should President Bush's orders to U.S. forces to halt shipments of Iraqi oil be termed a blockade, a quarantine, an interdiction or a barricade?


Chess
LEAD: On hearing of the Franco-Polish grandmaster Savielly Tartakover's pronouncement, ''Sacrifices only prove that someone has blundered,'' you might be inclined to put it down as just one of the witticisms for which he was always ready to sacrifice the truth.
It's not entirely invalid, although it is an exaggeration to claim that beautiful games must take their start in gross errors.

LEAD: Huge, super-efficient drift nets of the kind that ignited a storm of international protest in the Pacific Ocean have been spotted for the first time in the Atlantic near the Caribbean, raising fears that Atlantic marine life could be threatened and that commercial and sport fisheries important to the eastern United States could be devastated.

LEAD: A former Chinese journalist says security forces killed more than 450 Tibetans in the capital of Lhasa in 1989, the Observer newspaper has reported.

He was 55 years old and lived in Corte Madera, Calif.

The Growing Gap in Wages
There are several new theories that explain the gap between the incomes of the wealthiest and poorest Americans, which is now the widest since World War II, even after adjusting for inflation.

LEAD: IN at least two cases, the rare northern spotted owl has bred with the more common barred owl, but scientists say it is too soon to tell whether the crossbreeds are isolated quirks of nature or the progenitors of a new owl species.


Rig Count Up in Week
LEAD: The number of working oil and natural gas rigs in the United States rose last week for the first time in three weeks, jumping by 26, to a total of 992, Baker Hughes Inc. reported today.
A year earlier, the count was 858.
Ike Kerridge, a vice president of Baker Hughes, said the increase might be related to the Iraqi oil embargo.

Complicated Surgery Through Tiny Incisions
LEAD: THOUSANDS of surgeons are learning a new technique for removing gallbladders that could greatly simplify the operations now performed on some 500,000 Americans each year.


Mexico Sets Telmex Sale
LEAD: Mexico started the sale today of its giant telephone company, Telefonos de Mexico S.A., whose privatization is a showcase for President Carlos Salinas de Gortari's drive to spin off inefficient state-owned industries.


Unequal Justice
LEAD: An American jury sent a stern message to the Attorney General the other day: The Government of the United States should never stoop to acting like a pimp.


IVAX Chairman Gets Ferro Stake
LEAD: Dr.
Phillip Frost, a physician who is chairman of the IVAX Corporation, a pharmaceutical concern based in Miami, has acquired a 7.7 percent stake in Ferro Corporation.
Mr.
Frost said he received permission in March 1989 from Government antitrust regulators to raise his stake in Ferro, a Cleveland-based chemical concern, to as high as 15 percent.


I.M.F. Position On Brazil Debt
LEAD: The International Monetary Fund is likely to urge Brazil to agree to resume debt payments to its creditor banks before striking a new financing deal with the country, the third world's biggest debtor, international monetary officials said.


Don't Celebrate 1492 - Mourn It
LEAD: Throughout the country, groups are organizing counter-celebrations of the quincentennial of the year 1492.
They are preparing to counteract the official celebrations of the 500th anniversary of Columbus's landing in the Americas.
A New York group, tentatively called Columbus In Context, had its first meeting last month.


Corrections
LEAD: An article on Saturday about a dispute between the Federal Government and New York State over an $80 million Westway grant incorrectly characterized a state application to avoid repaying the grant.
The application dealt with potential development between the Hudson River bulkhead and the ends of the river piers, not the area between the bulkhead and the West Side Highway.


Blockade of Iraq Raises Oil Prices
LEAD: Oil prices moved up more than $1 a barrel on world markets yesterday as traders reacted to the American blockade of Iraqi oil and the Saudi decision to turn away an Iraqi tanker that had sought to load at a pipeline terminus.


Tallying the U.S. Forces in the Mideast
LEAD: With the aircraft carrier Saratoga expected to reach the Mediterranean Sea by today, the United States will have about 10,000 ground troops in Saudi Arabia and about 20,000 sailors and airmen on more than 30 ships in the Mediterranean, the Red Sea and the Persian Gulf region.


Iraqis Are Reported to Send Home $3 Billion Taken From Kuwaitis
LEAD: Iraq has transferred between $3 billion and $4 billion in gold bullion, foreign currencies and goods seized from Kuwaiti financial and commercial institutions to Baghdad, Arab bankers in London and the Persian Gulf region said today.


Bethlehem Steel Plans Sale of Unit
LEAD: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation, the nation's second-largest steelmaker. said it planned to sell its railroad freight car division as part of an effort to divest itself of assets unrelated to its basic steelmaking operations.

LEAD: To the Editor:


Winfield Shows Old Flair As Angels Beat Yanks
LEAD: Dave Winfield faced the Yankees for the first time since he was traded last May and had a good laugh about it.


Pentagon Faces Daunting Challenge In Rushing Sizable Force to Mideast
LEAD: The deployment of American forces to Saudi Arabia, the largest United States military operation since the Vietnam War, has severely strained the ability of the Pentagon to move thousands of troops and tons of weapons and equipment quickly over great distances.

Steinbrenner Son and Yanks: New Doubts Over Succession
LEAD: With George Steinbrenner having to surrender day-to-day control of the Yankees next Monday, there are signs that the succession process is in disarray.
The Yankee owner's 18 limited partners are scrambling for solutions even as they prepare to gather in Cleveland tomorrow to select a new general partner.


2 Giants Battle in Wiring Money
LEAD: The American Express Company, the nation's largest financial-services concern, is aggressively challenging the Western Union Corporation at a business it pioneered and has long dominated: wiring money.

LEAD: The Persian Gulf crisis is recasting the United States' relations with two of its oldest Middle East allies, Israel and Jordan.

Editorial Notebook;   Children of Privilege, Learning
LEAD: Gillian Williams stands at the front of Room 20 of the San Gabriel Avenue Elementary School.
She directs 30 second-graders making their family trees. ''Who goes with you to Disneyland?
Who goes with you on picnics?'' That her voice lacks authority is understandable; she is an unusual student teacher who only recently took over the class.


Parking Rules
LEAD: Because of the Feast of the Assumption, alternate-side parking rules will be suspended in New York City tomorrow.


Jogger Rape Jury Asks for String and Ruler
LEAD: The jury in the Central Park jogger trial, in its fifth day of deliberations, asked for photographs of the victim and the testimony of a police detective who questioned one of the defendants.


Challenge to College Football


TENTATIVE ACCORD SET IN G.M. STRIKE
LEAD: The United Automobile Workers and the General Motors Corporation today reached a tentative agreement that could end a parts plant strike that has forced eight other plants to close or curtail operations, a company spokesman said.


Steinbrenner Drew Up Anti-Vincent Release
LEAD: Lawyers for George Steinbrenner were prepared last week to accuse Commissioner Fay Vincent of severely damaging Steinbrenner's reputation and business by misrepresenting their agreement that will end the owner's management of the Yankees next Monday.


Chip Indicator Continues Slide
LEAD: Chip orders declined in July as the American semiconductor industry's leading indicator continued the downward slide it began in June, a trade group said today.

Rafsanjani Stresses Iran's Military Role For Security in Gulf 13&gt;
LEAD: President Hashemi Rafsanjani has declared the readiness of Iran to restore security to the Persian Gulf area and he called for the army to be put in readiness.


Three Mets Ready to Face Hefty Fines
LEAD: The Mets, still waiting for penalties to fall on three of their star players for participation in the free-for-all with the Philadelphia Phillies last week, said yesterday that they expected hefty fines but would appeal any suspensions.


TLC Beatrice Net Up
LEAD: TLC Beatrice International Holdings Inc., a multinational food products company operated by the financier Reginald F. Lewis, reported yesterday that its second-quarter net income doubled, to $17.5 million, from $8.8 million in the corresponding period last year.
The company's revenue increased 26 percent for the quarter, to $403.7 million, from $320.5 million in the period last year.


Workers Strike In North Sea
LEAD: Maintenance workers on Britain's North Sea oil platforms went on a 24-hour strike today, the fourth in a series of protests over union recognition, pay and safety.


Texas Gas Pipeline Sold
LEAD: KCS Group Inc. said today that it had signed a definitive contract to acquire 90 percent of a 150-mile intrastate natural gas pipeline in Texas from the Morgas Company of Conroe, Tex., for $21.5 million.
It said the Moran family, which controls Morgas, would retain a 10 percent interest.
KCS said the 12-inch main line runs from north of Houston to 20 miles northeast of Madisonville, and six lateral lines connect to multiple sources of natural gas supply and market outlets.


Gold Rises Above $400; 5-Month High
LEAD: Prices of precious metals continued to advance yesterday, fueled by the Middle East crisis.
Gold jumped to more than $400 an ounce for the first time in five months.


Above the Clamor of the City, More Clamor
LEAD: Old MacDonald, presumably, had a rooster to wake up to (45 decibels from across the barnyard).
In New York City, he could not hear the crowing for the noise.


Despite Flaw, Hubble Finds New Stars
LEAD: Despite its serious optical flaws, the Hubble Space Telescope has provided scientists with a detailed look into a prolific star-forming area, clearly showing 60 stars in an area once thought to have only 27 stars.


Chronicle
LEAD: PRINCESS ANNE, the daughter of QUEEN ELIZABETH II of Britain, will be 40 years old tomorrow.
The Queen's sister, PRINCESS MARGARET, will turn 60 on Tuesday.
There are no official plans to celebrate either birthday, but The Daily Mail has reported that ''a bash at Balmoral'' - Balmoral Castle in the highlands of Scotland - is planned for Princess Margaret's birthday.


A.T.&amp;T.'s New Card Stirs Strong Response
LEAD: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said yesterday that the pace at which it distributed its new A.T.&amp;T.
Universal card, a combination calling card and general purpose credit card, had accelerated sharply this summer.


Business and Health;   Unions Joining Discount Plans
LEAD: While labor unions are still actively campaigning for a greater Government role in health insurance, a growing number of them have agreed to participate in discount health-care plans.
With no immediate prospects for a national system, union officials say the discount plans can help stretch the limited dollars available for wages and other benefits as health costs keep rising.


Review/Theater;   A Couple Bound In Conflict
LEAD: Near the start of the Soviet writer Sofiya Prokofyeva's two-character drama ''Sin Testigos'' (''Without Witnesses'') the wife in a marriage that came apart nine years earlier declares in a soliloquy that the submergence of her personality in her husband's became a kind of death.
Now she feels nothing.


Velischek Traded
LEAD: The New Jersey Devils yesterday completed payment for the acquisition of Peter Stastny, the 33-year-old center, in a trade with the Quebec Nordiques last March 6.
At the time, the Devils sent Craig Wolanin, a defenseman, to Quebec, but promised one more player.
Yesterday, they named Randy Velischek, a 28-year-old defenseman, who played in 62 games last season for the


Soviets Prepare to Evacuate 7,830 Citizens Still in Iraq
LEAD: Baghdad has assured Moscow that Soviet citizens still in Iraq are not directly threatened by the Persian Gulf crisis, but the Kremlin is drawing up plans to evacuate them anyway, the official press agency Tass said today.


A New Interest in Taxing Trades
LEAD: Events in the Middle East have revived concern on Wall Street about the prospect of a securities transfer tax - something the financial community is dead set against.


A 9-Pound Mac Clone
LEAD: APPLE Computer Inc. has given its blessing to a small Colorado company that makes a nine-pound Macintosh-compatible portable.
The rival portable machine, called the Outbound Laptop System, is made by Outbound Systems Inc. of Boulder.
It is smaller, lighter and - if you already own a Macintosh Plus or SE - less expensive than Apple's own Mac Portable.


Soviet Justice Chief in U.S. For Talks on Legal Systems
LEAD: Veniamin Yakovlev, the Soviet Minister of Justice, arrived in Washington today for a week of talks on the legal systems in the Soviet Union and the United States.


Ex-Judge Named to Study Action Under Asbestos Plan
LEAD: A Federal judge in Brooklyn took the first steps yesterday toward carrying out a national plan for resolving asbestos personal injury cases.
Federal District Judge Jack B. Weinstein said that he had appointed Marvin E. Frankel, a former Federal judge, as a special master to conduct hearings on part of the plan.


Chronicle
LEAD: B. D. WONG, the actor who was an initiator of the ''Miss Saigon'' dispute, met yesterday at City Hall with Deputy Mayor BARBARA FIFE and DENNIS DELEON, who heads the Mayor's Commission on Human Rights.


A Profession Divided Is Finding It Hard To Teach Prevention
LEAD: THE ultimate goals of medicine are to prevent illness and to promote public health, and thus many would expect them to be a prime focus of medical education.

LEAD: ''The homosexuals are in a battle against American values,'' the speaker says. ''Their ultimate aim is to have the American people accept the proposition that their perverted 'life style' is as worthy of protection as race, creed and religion.
I do not buy that.
I say to them, 'Bosh and nausea.' ''


Tucurui Journal;   In an Amazon Lake, Underwater Logging Blooms
LEAD: Perched on the gunwale of a skiff here, Juarez Cristiano Gomes chuckled to himself as he watched a trail of small bubbles rising to the surface of Tucurui Lake.


Pakistanis Agree to Join Defense of Saudi Arabia
LEAD: Pakistan agreed today to join an international force deployed to defend Saudi Arabia against Iraq.


Gus Journal;   Nomads in Kenya See the Future. It Is Houses.
LEAD: The new moon was due in several days, a signal on this occasion for the twice-a-year ceremony known as sorio, for sacrifices, marriage and reconciliations.


Man's Life Support Extended
LEAD: A man who drank a cocaine-laced soft drink from Colombia and collapsed in a coma last month showed signs of life today, and doctors postponed shutting off his life-support systems.
The 25-year-old man, Maximo Rene Menendez, was declared brain dead on Monday, and an order was signed by a Dade County judge allowing a hospital to turn off his life-support system.

Self-Requiem for the Board of Estimate
LEAD: A dying institution of government will conduct its own last rites in a marathon session to start tomorrow.
In the process, New York City's Board of Estimate can improve - or obstruct - the life of the city it has managed for 92 years.
Dozens of items are on the agenda for its last meeting; four in particular will determine how the board, and its members, are remembered.

First Executive Earnings Drop
LEAD: The First Executive Corporation, a life insurance company that invested heavily in ''junk bonds,'' said today that its earnings fell 40.2 percent, to $30.5 million, or 10 cents a share, in the quarter that ended June 30.
It had earned $51 million, or 45 cents a share, in the comparable period a year earlier.

Mr. Rinfret on Garbage
LEAD: Pierre Rinfret, the Republican gubernatorial candidate, believes that one way to give plausibility to his quixotic campaign against Gov.
Mario Cuomo is to offer dramatically unconventional solutions to New York State's problems.
He now proposes to resolve the struggle over landfills and incinerator sites by allowing local communities to bid for the right not to have them.

AIDS Therapy Experiment Yields Encouraging Results
LEAD: A new AIDS therapy that involves administering a drug, withdrawing some of the patient's blood, shining ultraviolet light on it and returning it to the body has shown promising preliminary results in a study of five patients, researchers say.

It was 1941.

Penalties Could Have Been Worse
LEAD: Darryl Strawberry, who makes $1.8 million a year, said it was a ''stiff'' fine - all of $1,000.

Corrections
LEAD: Because of an editing error, a chart yesterday on the American forces in the Middle East misidentified the Marine unit involved.
It is the First Marine Expeditionary Force, not the First Marine Division.


Bridge
LEAD: Four decades ago a combative bridge writer named Alphonse Moyse Jr., known as Sonny, used to advocate the advantages of playing in a 4-3 trump fit.
He was thinking of major-suit games, and he would have been intrigued by the diagramed deal, on which North-South played the ''Moysian fit'' in a minor suit, rejecting two plausible seven-card fits in the majors.

Confrontation in the Gulf;   U.S. COORDINATES FLOTILLA IN GULF
LEAD: The United States Navy is coordinating its actions in the Persian Gulf with the French and British Navies and with the Saudi armed forces, the commander of the Joint Task Force for the Middle East said today.


Slight, Speedy Bell Seeking Jets Slot
LEAD: Midway through the seven-week grind of a pro football training camp, the Jets' Grantis Bell can claim two distinctions, one for sure.
At 5 feet 9 inches and 156 pounds, he is the smallest Jet, and he may be the fastest, too.
There have been no competitive tests to prove that.

LEAD: The Mozambican Government and rebel leaders ended a second round of talks here today after what they described as a fruitful exchange on ways to end their 13-year war.

BANKS' PAYMENTS TO INSURE DEPOSITS MAY JUMP BY 30%
LEAD: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation moved today to raise the premiums banks pay for deposit insurance by $1.1 billion, or 30 percent, next year.
The action reflects increased concerns about the safety of the deposit insurance system and about the effects of depressed real estate prices on commercial banks and the overall economy.

Once a Hotel Desert, Times Square Blooms
LEAD: Times Square, which has been a near-wasteland for hotels since the Beaux-Arts splendor of the Astor met the wrecker's ball in the 1960's, is now at the center of a virtual tide of new hotels.
Coming in the wake of a wave of high-rise construction on the West Side, two brand-new skyscraper hotels, the Holiday Inn Crowne Plaza on Broadway at 49th Street and the Hotel Macklowe on West 44th Street just east of Broadway, have opened in the last few months.

Confrontation in the Gulf;   12 Iraqi Soldiers Reported To Defect to Saudi Arabia

Japanese Bankruptcies
LEAD: The number of bankruptcies in Japan fell 12.5 percent in July from a year earlier, the 67th consecutive month of year-on-year declines, the Tokyo Commerce and Industry Research Company said today.
The number of bankruptcies declined 6.6 percent in July from June.
Bankruptcies with debt of less than 10 million yen ($67,000) are not included in the statistics.

Henley in a Deal To Sell Itel Shares
LEAD: Henley Group Inc. said it had reached a pact for the Itel Corporation to buy for cash or be obligated to underwrite 18.7 million Itel shares now held by Henley in a series of deals with a total value of about $375 million.
Itel will buy within 30 days about 4.68 million of the shares at $18 each and another 4.68 million shares before the end of 1990 at $19.50 a share.

About New York;   For Caring Chefs, Crowning Glory Is the Headgear
LEAD: New York, as a city, wears many hats, but none are in better taste than the toque, the high, white cylinder of headgear to be found in the best, if not the most expensive, kitchens in Manhattan and surrounding arrondissements.
Unlike firefighters, police officers, baseball players, postal workers, waiters and bus drivers who work in full view of audiences, chefs are a backstage lot, only recently accustomed to coming out for a bow as the brandy serves as a coda for their caloric symphonies.

LEAD: Tele-Communications Inc., the cable TV and theater company, said yesterday that its loss narrowed in the second quarter to $44 million, compared with a deficit of $64 million a year earlier.
Revenue for the quarter rose 22.6 percent, to $890 million, from $726 million a year earlier.
The loss was attributed to interest expenses resulting from a variety of deals, including the purchase of the TCI/Cooke Systems, and a 42.5 percent indirect interest in SCI Holdings Inc.

Whitman Calls Off Sale of Hussmann
LEAD: The Whitman Corporation said it had discontinued negotiations for the sale of its Hussmann Corporation subsidiary and would pull the refrigeration equipment unit off the sale block.
Whitman said that, after several weeks of negotiations, it had concluded that the proceeds from the best offer for Hussmann would not justify the sale.

LEAD: Marsh Jeanneret, a leading Canadian book publisher, died Friday at his home in King City, Ontario.
He was 73 years old.


Eastern Can Trim Pilots' Pay
LEAD: In a ruling that gives Eastern Airlines some financial relief, a Federal Bankruptcy Court said yesterday that the beleaguered carrier could impose temporary wage and benefits cuts on pilots.
At the same time, the airline reported a $35.6 million loss for the second quarter, an improvement from the period a year earlier.

Philadelphia Justice System Overwhelmed
LEAD: Violent criminals have so overloaded jails, courts and the police here that city officials say they are routinely setting free thousands of other criminals who repeatedly burglarize houses, snatch purses, steal cars and sell drugs.


Inflation Rise Abroad
LEAD: The International Labor Organization, a United Nations agency, issued a report today showing steadily rising inflation in many nations in the first few months of 1990.
Britain's inflation rate rose to 9.4 percent from 7.7 percent in the comparable period in 1989.

LEAD: The city's chief accounting officer said Monday that in nine months Philadelphia might not have enough money to pay its bills, despite plans to borrow heavily this summer.

English Going to Dallas
LEAD: The Dallas Mavericks said yesterday that they would announce today the signing of Alex English, the eighth-leading scorer in National Basketball Association history.
English, a forward, is expected to fill the gap left by the loss of Sam Perkins, who signed as a free agent with the Los Angeles Lakers.

Jogger Jury Still Deliberating
LEAD: The jury in the Central Park jogger trial deliberated yesterday for the sixth day in State Supreme Court in Manhattan without reaching a verdict.
Justice Thomas B. Galligan granted jury requests to review videotaped statements by two of the three youths charged with rape and attempted murder.

CHRONICLE
LEAD: A Georgia O'Keeffe painting has been formally declared lost by the Art Institute of Chicago, 20 years after a search for the misplaced painting began.
JAMES WOODS, director of the museum, said on Monday that its staff had hoped that the work, ''East River from the Shelton,'' would turn up.
But a recent inventory of 1,500 pieces in the museum's department of 20th-century paintings and sculpture made it clear the painting was nowhere to be found.

9 Killed Near Johannesburg
LEAD: Nine people were killed and 35 wounded when squatters attacked a hostel for migrant workers in Thokoza township west of Johannesburg, the police said today.
Witnesses said the attack on Monday was apparently to avenge the death of a squatter over the weekend. ''We ran helter-skelter and those in their rooms had to jump through windows,'' a hostel resident, Mpumuzi Tshabalala, told the South African Press Association.


Federko Retires
LEAD: Bernie Federko, the 16th-highest scorer in National Hockey League history with 1,130 points over 14 seasons with St.
Louis and Detroit, has announced his retirement.
The 34-year-old center, who was a free agent, made the announcement yesterday in Detroit, where last season he was the Red Wings' third-leading scorer with 57 points.

RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:
Basketball
U.S. Team Closes In on Semifinal
The United States overcame a 13-point deficit with seven minutes to play and beat Australia by 79-78 yesterday at the World Championships at Buenos Aires.
The victory virtually assured the United States of a semifinal berth.
The team would advance to Friday's semifinals if Puerto Rico beat Argentina later last night, or if the Americans beat Puerto Rico today in the last quarterfinal game.

LEAD: The Tokyo stock market soared today, with the 225-share Nikkei index climbing 1,439.59 points, or 5.4 percent, to close at 28,112.12.

LEAD: WITH her long, wavy dark hair, olive skin and startling black eyes, Magdalena Leciejewska has always been self-conscious in this country of mostly pale blond Slavs.

LEAD: Because a service that provides The Associated Press with market data remained without power yesterday after a Monday fire at a Consolidated Edison plant in lower Manhattan, the commodity futures tables today contain only settlement prices and net changes, plus volume and open-interest figures where available.

Herzog's artistic intentions.

Margaret B. Mark, 86, Ex-Girl Scout Official
LEAD: Margaret B. Mark, a leader in the Girl Scouts of America and in social work organizations, died on Friday at her home in Manhattan.
She was 86 years old.


New Fiber-Optic Cable Will Expand Calls Abroad, and Defy Sharks
LEAD: Like Brobdingnagian spools of thread, three giant steel cones in the hold of an unusual ship here are wrapped with up to 3,000 miles of cable no thicker than a garden hose.
The cable, composed of six hair-thin strands of glass covered by steel and plastic, can carry 40,000 telephone calls across the ocean floor at a time.


Corrections
LEAD: An article on Monday about American policy toward Iraq misstated the year in which the United States removed Iraq from a list of nations that sponsor terrorism.
Iraq was taken off the list in 1982, not 1983.

On the Trail of the Tortilla: All Tracks Lead to Tucson
LEAD: THIS beautiful, manageable city, with its crisp, dry, hot climate, desert landscape and pink adobe houses, calls itself the Mexican-food capital of the world - outside of Mexico, one assumes.
The most authentic local cuisine is found in South Tucson, a city built in the 18th century, distinct from but surrounded by Tucson.


Corrections
LEAD: A map of the Middle East that appeared Monday and Tuesday incorrectly located the United States aircraft carrier group headed by the Saratoga.
The group arrived in the Mediterranean Sea only yesterday.


Emergency Generator Fails at Hospital
LEAD: As lower Manhattan began returning to normal after Monday's blackout, the emergency generator feeding power to New York Infirmary-Beekman Downtown Hospital shut down yesterday afternoon, plunging the hospital into total darkness and paralyzing its life-support systems for an hour.

Plane Crashes Off Fire Island
LEAD: A plane crashed today in 65 feet of water off Fire Island, the Federal Aviation Administration said.
The pilot, Kevin Heffernan of Milltown, N.J., was the only person aboard the Citabria owned by United Aerial Advertising of Nyack, N.Y.
A search was halted at nightfall.

June 1, 1989: Juvon Edmunds charged with burglarizing his mother's home in northwest Philadelphia.

WINE TALK
LEAD: There is a water shortage in much of France this summer thanks to a three-year drought, but in Paris it seems that only Badoit is affected.
Badoit is a popular mineral water and since the recent spell of record-breaking heat here, there just has not been enough of it to go around.


Assistant Pro Finds Time To Play a Bit Between Duties
LEAD: He is in his first year as an assistant pro at the Westchester Country Club, but he is so busy working for perhaps the busiest course in the area that Rudy Virga has played the course only three times.


Texaco Signs Pact With Soviet Unit
LEAD: The Texaco Corporation announced yesterday that it had signed an agreement with the Soviet Union's Ministry of Geology to study the feasibility of joint oil production in Arctic oilfields south of the Barents Sea.
Texaco officials said the Soviets had identified reserves of at least five billion barrels of oil in the region.


Confrontation in the Gulf;   U.S. Troops' Biggest Fight So Far Is With 115-Degree Desert
LEAD: The following report was filed from Saudi Arabia yesterday and was based on the dispatches of a pool of reporters sent there under Defense Department auspices.
The ground rules for the pool prohibit the reporting of exact numbers of troops or weapons, their exact locations and the names of enlisted personnel.

INSIDE
LEAD:
Tokyo Stocks Up 5.4% On Report From Iraq
The Tokyo stock market soared, with the Nikkei index climbing 1,439.59 points, or 5.4 percent, to close at 28,112.12.
Analysts in Tokyo said that the rise was due in part to an unconfirmed report that Iraq was willing to negotiate a withdrawal.
Page D8.


Czechoslovak Compensation
LEAD: More than 220,000 Czechoslovaks who suffered during 41 years of Communist rule will probably share around $95 million in compensation, officials said today.
Those eligible include people in political trials between the Communist takeover in 1948 and its ousting last year.
Many others who emigrated had their citizenship revoked when they left Czechoslovakia.

Los Angeles Journal;   In a Smoking Ban, Some See Ashes
LEAD: Just three hours after two City Council committees voted Monday to ban smoking in all restaurants in Los Angeles, Michael Taix was back at Les Freres Taix, his 53-year-old family-run French restaurant on Sunset Boulevard, bemoaning the turn of events.


2 Nicaragua Currencies
LEAD: Two official currencies were in circulation today in Nicaragua, one on par with the United States dollar and the other devalued almost into oblivion.
The central bank announced today that it had devalued the old cordoba 7.2 percent, to 690,000 to the dollar from 640,000.
Black market dealers offered 740,000 old cordobas for $1.

How to Measure the Rain
LEAD: If the sound of rain falling on a tin roof is the best of all soporifics, then New Yorkers must be the best-rested people anywhere.
In the city, the rainfall drums down instead on air-conditioners, garbage cans, the hoods of cars.
Never mind.
Down it pours and on we sleep.


Taking Budget Offensive, Bush Accuses Democrats of Imperiling Economy
LEAD: Saying the budget impasse at home deserved the same urgent attention as the crisis in the Persian Gulf, President Bush today dropped his gentleman's agreement with the Democratic leaders in Congress and accused them of endangering the economy by playing politics with the Federal deficit.

LEAD: *
Ashton-Tate Co., Torrance, Calif., a holding company, said its board had authorized the repurchase of up to two million common shares in the open market to provide additional shares for employee stock option plans.


Loss Posted In 2d Quarter At Columbia
LEAD: The Columbia Savings and Loan Association, whose financial troubles have been related primarily to the plummeting value of its ''junk bond'' portfolio, reported a loss in the second quarter because of other factors, including problem real estate, the institution said today.


Retail Sales Up in July, But Outlook Is Negative
LEAD: Retail sales rose one-tenth of 1 percent in July from the month before, the Commerce Department said today.


CHRONICLE
LEAD: TAMMY FAYE BAKKER's church in Orlando, Fla., can hold services at its warehouse ministry on Sunday after winning a zoning dispute.
The Orange County Commission on Monday overruled the county zoning board 4 to 1, and said that the site of Mrs.
Bakker's New Covenant Ministries would not be unsafe for church services and a radio-television broadcast studio.


Confrontation in the Gulf;   Interest in Gulf High, A News Survey Shows
LEAD: The American public is ''riveted'' by news of the crisis in the Persian Gulf, according to a survey of public opinion by the Times Mirror Center for the Public and the Press.

Immigrants Help Others Lost in Maze
LEAD: Sung Soo Kim, a native of South Korea, does not know Esther Cartagena, formerly of Puerto Rico, or Philippe Wilson Desir, formerly of Haiti.
But in their adopted city, they each serve a similar role: helping to guide compatriots recently arrived from their homelands through the bureaucratic maze that governs social services, the education of their children and how they do business.

EXECUTIVE CHANGES
LEAD: *
Bank of America, San Francisco, a subsidiary of BankAmerica Corp., appointed Ed Hall senior vice president and head of marketing for its consumer banking group.
Sheryl L. Bartolucci, the director of human resources of its world banking group, was appointed senior vice president.
Erich Goodbody, director of the Orange County-San Diego region of its real estate industries division, was named executive vice president.

LEAD: The Securities and Exchange Commission today unanimously approved for public comment a new rule that would allow foreign banks and insurance companies to offer their stock and debt securities to American investors.


Federal Agency Moving to Stop Benefits for Dead Veterans
LEAD: The Department of Veterans Affairs is moving to stop payments it made to more than 1,200 deceased veterans, including about 100 who were dead a decade or more.

Dorothy Mackaill, Actress, 87
LEAD: Dorothy Mackaill, an actress who starred in silent and sound films in the 1920's and 30's, died on Sunday in her room at the Royal Hawaiian Hotel in Honolulu.
She was 87 years old.
She died of liver failure, The Associated Press said.
Miss Mackaill lived in Hawaii for the last 35 years.
She was born in Hull, England, and came to Broadway as a Ziegfeld girl and soon went to Hollywood.


Surgery for Mowatt
LEAD: Zeke Mowatt, the former Giant tight end who was signed in the off season as a Plan B free agent by the New England Patriots, is scheduled to have surgery on a ruptured tendon in his left little finger and may be lost for eight weeks.
The 6-foot-3-inch, 240-pound lineman injured his finger during practice on Monday.

Chemical to Add To Loan Reserves
LEAD: The Chemical Banking Corporation said in a regular quarterly filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday that in the second half of the year it expects to add more to its reserves for loan losses than the $151 million it added in the first half.

Home Improvement
LEAD: SO-CALLED flat roofs, which almost always slope slightly to facilitate drainage, should be inspected about twice a year.
Routine maintenance and minor repairs usually can be done easily by amateurs, but widespread or major damage should be handled promptly by a licensed roofer.


Mavericks Sign English
LEAD: To help fill the gap left by the loss of Sam Perkins, who signed as a free agent with the Los Angeles Lakers earlier this week, the Dallas Mavericks yesterday announced the signing of Alex English, the eighth-leading career scorer in National Basketball Association history.
English, who had been a free agent, averaged 17.9 points a game with Denver last season.


U.S. Speeding Arms to Arab Allies
LEAD: The United States is expediting large-scale arms sales already negotiated with Egypt and Saudi Arabia and is giving higher priority to new weapons requests from other Middle Eastern allies, the Pentagon said today.

He was 94 years old.

End to Beginning of CBS
LEAD: CBS Inc. said today that it had ended its operations at WCAU-AM in Philadelphia, the radio station with which William S. Paley began the CBS broadcasting network in the 1920's.
The network-owned station switched programming at 1 P.M. without notice to listeners or staff.
About 35 employees were laid off.


Gay Group Seeks More Data On Heat Treatment for AIDS
LEAD: The Gay Men's Health Crisis yesterday urged the National Institutes of Health and two Atlanta doctors who developed an unproven heat treatment for AIDS to make public more information about the experimental procedure, which the doctors say resulted in the recovery of two patients.

LEAD: A former executive vice president of the Montgomery National Bank was indicted on Tuesday in connection with what prosecutors said was a $10 million fraud that forced the New Jersey bank into receivership in June.


Ex-Officials Admit Drug Guilt
LEAD: Two former state prosecutors pleaded guilty to cocaine charges in Federal court today.
One of them, Michael Trant, a former associate deputy attorney general, pleaded guilty to one count of cocaine possession, and the other, Richard Guida, who headed the state attorney general's criminal division until 1986, admitted one count of cocaine distribution.


Two Fined in Insider Case
LEAD: A print shop worker and a stockbroker were ordered today to repay $28,655 and were fined $37,444 for engaging in a scheme to buy stocks based on articles read in Business Week before the magazine was on the newsstands.

Cambodian Devaluation
LEAD: Struggling to rebuild its economy amid war and international isolation, Cambodia devalued its currency to 460 riel to the dollar from 360 riel, the official press agency said today.
Cambodia's economy, virtually destroyed during the Khmer Rouge rule of 1975-79, has shown signs of improvement under free-market policies introduced by Prime Minister Hun Sen.

Critic's Notebook;   Spike Lee's Jews and the Passage From Benign Cliche Into Bigotry
LEAD: In Spike Lee's ''Do the Right Thing,'' there is a scene he refers to in the published screenplay as ''The Racial Slur Montage.'' One by one, a range of ethnic characters stare into the camera and spit out vicious, stereotypical descriptions of some other ethnic group.
The black man played by Mr.
Lee says, ''Dago, wop, garlic-breath''; an Italian comes back with, ''Gold-chain-wearing, fried-chicken-and-biscuit-eatin' monkey,'' and a Hispanic man sneers at Koreans as ''slanty-eyed, me-no-speak-American, own every fruit and vegetable stand in New York.

Closings at Ford
LEAD: The Ford Motor Company said it would shut down its plants next week in Atlanta and Kansas City, Mo., because of a shortage of dealer orders.
It said it had closed a plant in Lorain, Ohio, because of a shortage of interior trim materials.
The Atlanta plant produces the Taurus and Sable mid-sized cars, while Kansas City produces Tempo and Topaz compact cars.

Geoffrey Leon, Actor, 44
LEAD: Geoffrey Leon, an actor and lyricist, died Saturday at his home in Manhattan.
He was 44 years old.
He died of complications of AIDS, said a friend, Robert Poterelli.
Mr.
Leon graduated from the University of California at Santa Barbara in 1967 and moved to New York the same year.
He appeared on Broadway in ''Georgy'' and was a founder of a vocal group, Twentieth Century.

Oil Price Effect on Japan
LEAD: Higher crude oil prices will damp Japan's economic growth in the fiscal year starting next April 1 but will have little adverse effect in the current year, the Daiwa Institute of Research said in a report today.
If crude oil prices remain at about $25 a barrel after October, the growth of the gross national product in Japan in the 1991-92 fiscal year will shrink to 3.5 percent, the report said.


Sales Up, Inventories Off in June
LEAD: Business sales rose 1 percent in June for the second consecutive month, while inventories declined four-tenths of a percent, the Commerce Department reported today.

LEAD: The threat of lawsuits, an increased concern about child abuse and new evidence that minority and handicapped children are paddled more often than other students have combined to revive the debate about corporal punishment in schools.
In the last three years the number of states that have banned paddling has nearly doubled.

Toys 'R' Us Net Rises
LEAD: Increased sales of video game products and non-electronic toys raised the earnings of Toys ''R'' Us by 12.8 percent in the second quarter compared with the corresponding period in 1989, company officials said today.
Net earnings for the quarter ended July 29 were $26.5 million, or 9 cents a share, compared with $23.5 million, or 8 cents a share, for the second quarter of last year.

LEAD: It is quiet now near the little town of Mnok, on the rail line between Battambang and Phnom Penh.
On July 15, it was the site of one of the worst atrocities of this stage of the 20-year-old Cambodian war.

Conagra Finishes Deal for Beatrice
LEAD: Conagra Inc. became one of the world's largest food companies when it completed its $1.34 billion acquisition of the Beatrice Company.
The deal, completed Tuesday, unites some of the country's best-known food brands: Beatrice makes Peter Pan peanut butter, Hunt's and Wesson condiments and oils, and Conagra makes Banquet, Armour and Chun King foods.

Rentz Leads Met Open By 7 Shots
LEAD: Larry Rentz justified his reputation as one of the longest hitters in the area when he eagled two holes of more than 500 yards today en route to a sizzling seven-under-par 64 in the second round of the 76th Metropolitan Open.
Rentz's total of 132 gave him a seven-shot lead.
Rentz, in his second year as an assistant to Bob Miller at nearby Knollwood Country Club, eagled the 505-yard ninth and the 535-yard 18th to go with birdies on the 2d, 7th, 10th and 14th and a bogey on the 4th, a par 4.

LEAD: As reports mount that the nation's most widely prescribed antidepressant drug may spark violent or suicidal behavior in a fraction of patients, lawyers and former users of the medication are banding together to file multimillion-dollar lawsuits against the drug's maker.


Bridge
LEAD: There have been two Summer National Championships in the last month: Shortly after the American Contract Bridge League concluded its 10 days of play in Boston last month, the smaller American Bridge Association began 11 days of competition in Philadelphia, which ended on Saturday.


Hardware to Make Home More Homey
LEAD: With housing prices way down, the fear at the National Hardware Show, which ended here today, was that retailers and wholesalers would be in no mood to make big purchases.
So manufacturers resorted to the obvious: They displayed products that would allow homeowners to improve and beautify their existing properties.


Miscellany
LEAD: *
The Minority Advertising Intern Program, operated by the American Association of Advertising Agencies, had 54 interns participating at 32 agencies in 6 cities this summer.
The 10-week program, which began in 1973, has sponsored 570 interns to date, with about 25 percent going on to careers in advertising or related fields, the association said.

Fed Blocks Banks' Merger, Citing Concerns on Capital
LEAD: In the clearest signal yet of the importance the Federal Reserve Board places on banks maintaining high levels of capital, the nation's central bank today rejected a proposal by the Bank of New York to acquire a $2.7 billion Connecticut bank-holding company, citing concerns that the resulting institution would not have sufficient capital reserves.

LEAD: Florence Rubin Garfunkel, a social worker and a trustee of the Educational Alliance for 33 years, died on Friday at her home in Manhattan.
She was 83 years old.

Pilot Alcohol Rule Called Inadequate
LEAD: Federal regulations that prohibit pilots from flying with a blood alcohol level of 0.04 percent or more or within eight hours after drinking an alcoholic beverage are medically inadequate, a new study says.
Studies clearly show that that a pilot can conform to the rules and still be feeling the effects of the liquor while flying, according to research published in Thursday's edition of the New England Journal of


Yanks Help Langston Forget His Troubles
LEAD: The solution to Mark Langston's problems? Simple. Give him the Yankees.


Burmese Rights Abuses Reported
LEAD: An American human-rights group issued a report today accusing the Burmese Government of ''gross human-rights violations.'' It said atrocities had continued despite the Government's defeat in elections in May.


Saudis Are Dismayed by U.S. Servicewomen
LEAD: The following report was filed from Saudi Arabia yesterday and was based on the dispatches of a pool of reporters sent there under Defense Department auspices.
The ground rules prohibit the reporting of exact numbers of troops or weapons, their exact locations or the names of enlisted personnel.


Continental To Cut Fares
LEAD: Continental Airlines said today that it would cut fares for flights after Labor Day, matching reductions already announced by other carriers.


Kill the Fresh Kills Plan
LEAD: New York City's Board of Estimate is likely to reject a Dinkins administration proposal today that would help short-term revenues but hurt long-term garbage disposal capacity.
The board is on the right track; the plan is flawed and the city would be unwise to try to revive it later.

Watch Urged On U.S. Loan Agencies
LEAD: Federal auditors said today that the Government should sharply increase the regulation and supervision of Government-sponsored enterprises that lend money to home buyers and college students or else taxpayers might have to foot the bill in the future.


Close to Home
LEAD: TWO nights after it happened, I saw a nicely dressed young couple laying roses at the foot of the telephone booth.
There are many such shrines to the suddenly-departed all over New York - a name scrawled on a wall, a heap of flowers, a candle or two - but this was the first that I had seen.
The small mound of pink and red blooms was curiously reminiscent of the plaques on Paris buildings that commemorate someone lost to gunfire during the Liberation.

Reversal of 'Fair Use' Would Harm Authors
LEAD: To the Editor:


Teheran is Pleased
LEAD: Iraq took a dramatic step today to counter its growing international isolation over the invasion of Kuwait, offering to meet almost all of Iran's conditions for settling key issues persisting from their eight-year war.


Ambase Stock Plunges As Payout Is Omitted
LEAD: Stock of the Ambase Corporation, a midsized insurance company that invested heavily in high-risk ''junk bonds,'' plunged more than 63 percent yesterday in active trading after the company canceled a large special dividend it had been expected to pay.


Formal Dinner Is Victor
LEAD: Formal Dinner may be only the second- or third-best 2-year-old in D. Wayne Lukas's stable, but that was good enough to make him an easy winner over a very weak field today in the $92,100 Sanford Stakes at Saratoga Race Track.

LEAD: A listing in the calendar on the On Your Own page in SportsMonday this week misstated the site of the Fairfield County Sports Car Club autocross on Aug. 19.
It will be held at Southern Connecticut State University, Lot No. 9, in New Haven.

Yankee Executive Expected to Sue Vincent
LEAD: The chief operating officer of the Yankees will probably file a lawsuit in the next three weeks seeking to block a hearing scheduled before Commissioner Fay Vincent into his involvement in the Howard Spira affair, people close to the executive indicated yesterday.


Malaysia Oil Output Rise
LEAD: The Government-owned National Petroleum Corporation will increase its daily oil production by 10,000 barrels to meet the demand of countries dependent on Iraqi and Kuwaiti crude, Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad said today.
The Cabinet decided that half of the additional volume would go to members of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations and the balance to non-oil producing nations.


A Cat May Look at a Cat
LEAD: Over the past 10 years a New Yorker who is less a pet lover than an easy mark has housed five cats.
Not one of them was what the world calls a looker.
No oohs and aahs followed when these cats entered the room.
One with a little black goatee under her chin even evoked laughter.
Another was indistinguishable from every tabby that ever strolled the earth.

Meat Price Decline Seen
LEAD: Consumers will see some relief from record meat prices as production increases next year, the Agriculture Department said today.
Retail pork prices are expected to decline about 1 percent to 3 percent in 1991 from this year's record level, the department's Economic Research Service said.
Poultry prices may be down 4 percent to 6 percent.

LEAD: Experts on automobiles say technologies are readily available to make cars go much farther on a gallon of gasoline, reducing the demand for oil and therefore lessening the impact of events like the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait.

RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:
BASKETBALL
Puerto Rico Beats U.S.
Puerto Rico won a battle of unbeaten teams yesterday, defeating the United States by 81-79 at the world championships in Buenos Aires.
Both teams had already qualified for the semifinals tomorrow, in which the United States will play Yugoslavia, and Puerto Rico will play the Soviet Union.

LEAD: Starting today, New Yorkers who violate the city's year-old recycling law face fines that begin at $25 and rise to $10,000.


Castles in the Sand, For Fun and Profit
LEAD: Lucinda Wierenga and Walter McDonald, who live on South Padre Island in Texas, make a living building sand castles.
They aren't rich yet, they admit, but they say they are having a lot of fun.


Equity Panel Head Criticizes 'Saigon' Producer
LEAD: The chairman of the Commission on Racial Equality of Actors' Equity said yesterday that the producer of ''Miss Saigon'' had refused to allow Asian-American actors to compete for the starring role of a Eurasian pimp in a Broadway production of the hit London musical.


Colorado Voters Pick Candidates for Senate Race
LEAD: Josie Heath, a former Boulder County Commissioner, won the Democratic nomination for the United States Senate in a primary on Tuesday, easily defeating an underfinanced candidate whose campaign had centered on his attacks against the savings and loan industry.


Mostly Mozart to Perform 9 Concerts at Tokyo Center
LEAD: Lincoln Center's Mostly Mozart Festival will go to Tokyo next year to perform nine concerts at the Tokyu Bunkamura, a cultural complex that opened last September.


Rush Delivery Sought For Antidote to Gas
LEAD: The Defense Department has asked for rush delivery of kits containing the nerve gas antidote American troops would use in the Middle East, the president of the only American supplier of the antidote said today.


Calendar of Events: Convention of Quilters
LEAD: Patchwork, Student Center at Hofstra University, 1000 Hempstead Turnpike, Hempstead, L.I.; (516) 560-6925.


New Headache for U.S.
LEAD: If it lasts, the peace settlement shaping up today between Iraq and Iran, once its arch-enemy, could significantly prolong the stay of American troops in the Persian Gulf.
