LEAD: To the Editor:


When Guards Turn Lawless
LEAD: Nearly everyone connected with this week's ugly turmoil at New York City's Rikers Island jail has something to answer for: the guards, who let their legitimate grievances spill over into destructive lawlessness; the Dinkins administration, for letting the lawlessness drag on so long, and Mr.
Dinkins's predecessor, who allowed conditions at Rikers


People
LEAD: *
Michael V. Howe has been appointed president and chief executive of Young &amp; Rubicam's Detroit office, effective Sept. 1.
He succeeds John Sanders, who has been named chief executive of Wunderman Worldwide, the agency's direct-marketing subsidiary.


Man Indicted In the Slaying Of an Intruder
LEAD: A 19-year-old man who shot a knife-wielding burglar attacking a pregnant woman in an East Harlem apartment has been indicted on charges of second-degree murder and illegal gun possession, the Manhattan District Attorney's office said last night.


A Top Macy Executive Plans Early Retirement
LEAD: Herbert Yalof, the 53-year old president and chief operating officer of R. H. Macy &amp; Company's Northeast division, is giving up those posts and taking early retirement.


Penguin USA's Chief Quits
LEAD: In a move that took employees by surprise, Morton Mint resigned yesterday as the chief executive of Penguin USA.
The company's announcement attributed the move to ''policy differences'' over Penguin's future management.


The G.M. Strike, While Resolved, Reflects Many Workers' Unrest
LEAD: More than 20,000 General Motors Corporation workers are returning to their jobs after a six-day strike at a parts plant in Flint, Mich., that idled 16 other plants across the country.
But labor experts say deep unrest remains among the 300,000-member General Motors work force as its leaders negotiate a three-year contract to replace the one that expires in just a month.

LEAD: An American Bar Association survey has corroborated what has become increasingly apparent to lawyers, legal recruiters and psychiatrists: job dissatisfaction among lawyers is widespread, profound and growing worse.


Liberian Rebel Leader Hurt in Crash
LEAD: The leader of one of Liberia's rebel factions, Charles Taylor, was injured in an automobile accident today while traveling to meet a group of West African leaders to discuss a cease-fire in Liberia's civil war, a rebel spokesman said.
The talks were postponed.

Bloodstains Support Claims of Guards' Violence
LEAD: A Rikers Island jailhouse is said to have been found splattered with well over a dozen bloodstains, including palm and finger prints - evidence that strengthens allegations that correction officers retaliated against prisoners in the wake of an uprising on Tuesday night.

LEAD: In a blistering speech that condemned successive Indian Governments for creating ''a crisis of understanding'' in Kashmir, the former elected Chief Minister of the state accused Indian security forces today of repression, brutality and corruption in their efforts to end an uprising there.


Quiet, Please! Air Traffic Rerouted From U.S. Open
LEAD: As a result of the intercession of New York City's No. 1 tennis fan, players at this year's United States Open are less likely to be thrown off their games by the incessant roar of departing airplanes.
Fans at the National Tennis Center should benefit, too, by hearing the distinct thwock of each serve and volley, not to mention the full range of Monica Seles's grunts and Andre Agassi's groans.

Aspen Music Festival Appoints New Director
LEAD: Lawrence Foster has been appointed music director of the Aspen Music Festival and School for a three-year term beginning in October.
Mr.
Foster, who also recently became the music director of the Jerusalem Symphony Orchestra, will be responsible for planning the programs of the nine-week Aspen Music Festival.

LEAD: The ITT Hartford Insurance Group said it would continue to write automobile insurance policies, bowing to a threat from New Jersey state officials.
In January, shortly before the state passed a law intended to reduce driver premiums, Hartford's Twin City Fire Insurance Company unit said it would stop writing policies in New


Small Fire at Rodin Museum
LEAD: A small fire of suspicious origin broke out today in the loft of the Rodin Museum, but caused little damage.
The museum, a branch of the Philadelphia Museum of Art, houses the world's largest single collection outside Franceof the sculptor's works.
A piece of cloth apparently caught fire and set off an alarm, a museum spokeswoman said.


13 Are Charged In Theft of Data From Computers
LEAD: Thirteen people, including a 14-year-old boy who is a suspect in a computer break-in at the office of the Secretary of the Air Force, were arrested yesterday and charged with breaking into and stealing information from a variety of computers, the New York State Police said.

James River Plans A Restructuring
LEAD: The James River Corporation said it would restructure its operations, including the sale or shutdown of $1.3 billion in operations that have not been profitable.
The company said the move would increase the resources available for expansion and ''allow the company to simplify its structure so that it can concentrate on global growth opportunities.


Hugh Gladstone Koehler, Investment Banker, 60
LEAD: Hugo Gladstone Koehler, an investment banker, died on Tuesday at a friend's home in Manhattan.
He was 60 years old and lived in Manhattan and in Cos Cob, Conn.

Money Fund Assets Up
LEAD: The assets of the nation's 525 money market mutual funds increased $2.38 billion, to $404.48 billion, in the week that ended on Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.
The assets of the 169 institutional funds increased by $829.3 million, to $101.11 billion.
The assets of the 252 general-purpose funds were up by $469.9 million, to $140.4 billion.


An Editor Is Appointed At Esquire
LEAD: The Hearst Corporation yesterday announced the appointment of Terry McDonell, the founder and editor in chief of Smart magazine, to be the new editor of Esquire, the venerable men's magazine that helped establish both the ''new journalism'' of the 1960's and the ''new man'' of the 1980's.


New Orleans In New York As 2 Bands Share a Stage
LEAD: Music defines the cultural life of New Orleans, perhaps more than it does in any other city in the United States.
Whether it's a tribe of Mardi Gras Indians leading hundreds of people, singing and dancing, down the city's side streets, or Sunday brass bands that get entire neighborhoods to supply percussion accompaniment with bottles and cans, live music is part of the city's everyday existence.

Vandal Vessels Invade the Atlantic
LEAD: International outrage has squeezed drift-net fishing fleets out of the South Pacific and forced them to accept supervision in the North Pacific.
But there are signs that these vandal vessels are now shifting to Atlantic waters.
The fleets' host nations, Taiwan in particular, need to monitor their boats' behavior much more closely.

Lyme Disease Is Now Linked To Stroke in 20-Year-Old G.I.
LEAD: Two neurologists have reported that a 20-year-old man suffered a stroke as a result of meningitis brought on by Lyme disease.
Eleven similar cases have been documented in Europe, they say.

LEAD: One of the mysteries about ''Act of Betrayal'' is why it should take four hours to tell so simple a tale.

Ex-Official Pleads Guilty to Dumping Body
LEAD: A former assistant city commissioner pleaded guilty yesterday to illegally dumping the body of a woman who died in his apartment four months ago, the Manhattan District Attorney's office said.


Sax, Like Yankees, in Summer Slump
LEAD: The numbers aren't what they used to be.
Steve Sax's batting average has fallen 61 points from a season ago, and his on-base percentage has tumbled.
He isn't even breaking batting helmets with the same frequency: two this year, six in 1989. ''That's because they're making them tougher,'' he said.
The summer of Sax's discontent has paralleled the Yankees' dismal and unending slide.

Study Finds the U.S. Lags In Communications Goods
LEAD: A study of the nation's telecommunications equipment industry, released yesterday by the Commerce Department, has found that the United States is no longer competitive in markets for consumer products like telephones and facsimile machines and is losing ground in markets for business and telephone company equipment.


Housing Starts Fell 2.6% in July
LEAD: Construction of new homes fell for the sixth straight month in July, cutting building activity to its weakest pace in nearly eight years, the Government said today.

Our Towns;   Of Adult Homes, This One Ranks Among the Worst
LEAD: The Commission on Quality Care for the Mentally Disabled recently released a list of the state's 14 worst adult homes.
Their residents are mainly former mental patients or poor people unable to care for themselves.
Inspectors noted that many homes resembled old back wards of state hospitals.


Solzhenitsyn Cool as Moscow Confirms Offer
LEAD: Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn and 22 other exiled literary, scientific and cultural figures are on a list of people whose citizenship has been restored by President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, officials said today.

LEAD: Willie Mays of New York took a train and a cab here today to enjoy the day and the Ladies Professional Golf Association tournament at Wykagyl Country Club.

Wood Gundy Cuts Staff
LEAD: Wood Gundy Inc., a big Canadian brokerage, cut 21 workers today from its investment banking staff, reflecting a slump among investment firms in Canada.
Both retail and corporate investors have turned away from stocks in favor of more conservative investments after the stock market crash in October 1987 and decline in October 1989, analysts said.

Audit Shows Railroads Are Remiss on Payroll Tax
LEAD: A number of the country's major railroads and railroad-related businesses are failing to pay large amounts of payroll taxes to the Federal Government to finance the unemployment, retirement and medical benefits for the industry's workers, an audit indicates.


TRW to Shut Plant
LEAD: TRW Inc. said it would close its electronic products plant here and lay off 190 employees.
Up to 40 workers could be transferred to TRW plants in Colorado Springs or San Diego within five months.
TRW said its avionics and surveillance group, which includes the electronics plant, had consolidated because of declining military spending and increased competition.


Franklin Ebaugh, 68, V.A. Medical Official
LEAD: Franklin G. Ebaugh Jr., chief of staff at the Veterans Affairs Medical Center in Palo Alto, Calif., and a former dean of two medical schools, died on Aug. 7 at his home in Stanford, Calif.
He was 68 years old.


5 Months Later, Youth Set Afire Returns Home
LEAD: Five months after he was set on fire and almost burned to death, 12-year-old David Opont said yesterday, as he went to his family's new home in Brooklyn for the first time, that he was ''angry but not a lot'' at the older boy who the police say inflicted the agony.


Equity Reverses 'Saigon' Vote And Welcomes English Star
LEAD: Actors' Equity changed its mind yesterday and voted to permit the English actor Jonathan Pryce to come to Broadway to re-create his prize-winning portrayal of a Eurasian pimp in the hit London musical ''Miss Saigon.''

Clutch Hits Help Mets Defeat Dodgers
LEAD: The pitching was sharp and stingy.
The hits were clutch; the runs they produced both stylish and sufficient.
The defense was occasionally extraordinary and otherwise thoroughly adequate.


Ames Will Close Office in Syracuse
LEAD: Ames Department Stores Inc. said it would close its regional accounting office here in a companywide plan to consolidate jobs and cut costs.
The closing of the Ames downtown Syracuse office will put nearly 160 people out of work, a company spokesman, Bill Roberts, said.


Bumble Bee to Cut Jobs in Puerto Rico
LEAD: Bumble Bee Seafoods Inc., the nation's third-largest tuna canner, said it would cut 800 jobs at a plant in Puerto Rico as it reduces its production of light-meat tuna.
Bumble Bee said its plant in Mayaguez, P.R., would continue operating with more than 1,000 employees although a second shift would be eliminated.


Note to Readers
LEAD: The Op-Ed page welcomes unsolicited manuscripts.
Because of the volume of submissions, however, we regret that we cannot acknowledge receipt of or return articles unless they are accompanied by a self-addressed, stamped envelope.
If manuscripts are accepted for publication, authors will be notified within two weeks.


Tours of Manhattan: The Facts and the Fiction
LEAD: IT is not difficult to come to New York City and go away believing that Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis lives in a town house on ''Beekman Hill'' overlooking the East River, that the rules of baseball were made up in a building called the ''Republican Club'' at 62d Street and Fifth Avenue, that Mount Sinai Hospital is known for the face lifts it performs on movie stars, and that whites abandoned Harlem en masse in 1901 because somebody built factories across the river in New Jersey that year.

LEAD: Capitalists have recovered their confidence in Hong Kong.

To be successful, the work must be sufficiently provocative to engage an audience that is busy going about its own business.

The screenplay was written by Jill Mazursky, the 25-year-old daughter of the director Paul Mazursky (who is this film's executive producer), and Jeffrey Abrams, who is 24.

Bankers Trust
LEAD: The Bankers Trust New York Corporation said in a filing to the Securities and Exchange Commission that in light of current economic conditions, its problem loans might continue to rise in the rest of 1990.
In the first half of 1990, Bankers Trust's non-refinancing country cash basis loans rose $122 million, to $772 million.

Stock Plan Backed At Western Union
LEAD: Shareholders of the Western Union Corporation approved the reclassification of the company's preferred stock into common.
The vote, at the company's annual meeting, ''put us through the first step of a planned recapitalization,'' the company's president, Robert J. Amman, said.
The next step is Western Union's offer to exchange cash, common stock and new notes for the company's outstanding 19.25 percent and 16 percent notes.

Atwater Condition Worsens, Republican Officials Report

Advest Buyback
LEAD: The board of Advest Group Inc. approved a plan to buy back up to two million shares, or about 20 percent of the company's common stock.
The intermittent purchases will be conducted in the open market, Advest said.
The company is a regional brokerage based in Hartford.
Its shares closed today at $3.75, up 50 cents each, on the New York Stock Exchange.


Banc One Notes
LEAD: The Banc One Corporation offered $200 million of 20-year notes through an underwriting syndicate led by Salomon Brothers.
The 10 percent notes, which are noncallable for life, mature Aug. 15, 2010.
They were priced at $99.875, to yield 10.25 percent, 1.40 percentage points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's benchmark 8 3/4 percent 30-year bonds of 2020 at the time of pricing.

British Wages Up 10%
LEAD: Average earnings of British workers rose 10 percent in the fiscal year ended in June despite Government appeals to employers to hold down wages to fight inflation, official figures showed today.
In addition, unemployment increased by a seasonally adjusted 10,900 in July, to 1.63 million, or 5.7 percent of the work force.


For Children
LEAD:
SHOWS, NATURE, MUSEUMS
CENTRAL PARK ZOO, 10 A.M. to 5 P.M.
Monday to Friday (until 8 P.M. on Tuesday) and 10 A.M. to 5:30 P.M. on weekends; gift shop and cafeteria are open the same hours.
Admission: children under 3, free; ages 3 to 12, 25 cents; 65 and older, 50 cents; others, $1.
Information: 861-6030.

LEAD: South Korean students gathered today near the border with North Korea and fought with riot police blocking their way to the North.

Canadian Banks Cut Prime Rate
LEAD: Leading Canadian banks cut their prime lending rates half a percentage point today to 14.25 percent.
It was the first drop in the rate in almost three years.


Jury Weighs Drunken Flying Charge
LEAD: In the first criminal trial of airline pilots charged with flying under the influence of alcohol, a jury in Federal District Court today began deliberating the case of three pilots who flew a Northwest Airlines jetliner after a night of heavy drinking.


Study Says Alzheimer's Medicine Is Useless
LEAD: A study made public today concludes that the only medication approved by the Government for treating Alzheimer's disease is useless and may actually make the disease worse.


Pemex Adopts a Corporate Tone
LEAD: Since Iraq's occupation of Kuwait, many industrialized nations have looked nervously to countries like Mexico, one of the largest producers of oil outside the Middle East.
But Mexico's state-owned oil company, long past the glory days of the early 1980's when prices were high, will probably not be much help.

People
LEAD: *
Carol Lee Kelliher, the director of broadcast production at the San Francisco office of Hal Riney &amp; Partners, has been given the additional title of senior vice president and director of creative services.
Jan Carpenter, its vice president and controller, has been promoted to senior vice president and director of finance and administration.


Time Suspends Fortune France
LEAD: Time Warner Inc. has suspended publication of Fortune France, the French-language version of Fortune magazine that it has published since early 1988 in partnership with the Hachette Filipacchi Group.


His Enemy Is the World
LEAD: Saddam Hussein is squirming, but there's cruel logic in his harassment of foreigners captive in Kuwait, his bellicose threats to Washington and his startling overture to his archenemy, Iran.
He seeks to Americanize the confrontation in the Persian Gulf.
By pitting himself against President Bush, he plays shrewdly to Arab hunger for a heroic paladin of Arab grievances.

Power Is Back at Beekman
LEAD: The staff and patients cheered at New York Infirmary-Beekman Downtown Hospital yesterday as electricity was restored 3 1/2 days after a blackout in lower Manhattan forced it to rely on generators.
Consolidated Edison also restored power to street lamps and some traffic lights in the 30-block area around the South Street Seaport, said a utility spokesman.

Bubbles and Catcalls for Estimate Board
LEAD: With a champagne toast amid a chorus of catcalls and clicking cameras, the New York City Board of Estimate opened its last meeting yesterday and held hearings on a number of big development projects but, as it usually does, put off most of the big decisions.


Bank Faults Merger Plan
LEAD: Northeast Bancorp Inc. accused the Bank of New York Company yesterday of wrecking a planned merger between the two banks by failing to file a complete application with the Federal Reserve Board.


New Jersey May Scrap Tax on Trucks as Sales Plunge
LEAD: Gov.
Jim Florio, who has thus far resisted pressure to change any part of his $2.8 billion tax program, is prepared to rescind the sales tax on heavy trucks if the Legislature can find other sources for the $44 million in revenue that the tax was expected to produce, administration officials and legislative leaders say.

Corrections
LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about New York's efforts to dispose of low-level radioactive waste described two companies incorrectly.
The companies, NDL Organization in Peekskill and Radiac Research in Brooklyn, are the state's two largest brokers of the waste, arranging for its transportation and disposal.

Billboard Ridiculing Helms Is Removed by Company
LEAD: The controversy over artistic freedom and Senator Jesse Helms has now expanded to billboards.
A huge billboard rented by an artist to heap ridicule on the North Carolina Republican was taken down today by the billboard's owner, a subsidiary of Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing in St.
Paul.


I.R.S. Seeks $7 Billion From Exxon
LEAD: The Exxon Corporation said yesterday that it had received a bill from the Internal Revenue Service for nearly $7 billion for the years 1979 through 1982.
It said, however, that the amount in serious dispute was $2 billion, which grew out of an argument over how it priced oil it bought from Saudi Arabia during the oil crisis in that period.


Vincent Going to Italy
LEAD: Jay Vincent, a nine-year veteran of the National Basketball Association and a member of the Los Angeles Lakers last season, has signed a one-year contract worth $700,000 with Philips Milan of the Italian League, the team announced yesterday.
Vincent, 31 years old, played for five teams in his N.B.A.


Review/Film;   Having Mother For Dinner
LEAD: Raul Ruiz's 1981 film, ''The Territory,'' takes a theme that has haunted modern literature from ''The Heart of Darkness'' to ''Lord of the Flies'' - the savagery bubbling beneath the veneer of civilization - and gives it a bizarre comic twist.
In this variation, two American families on vacation in Europe metamorphose from sophisticated picture-perfect tourists into cannibals without much fuss during a camping trip in the South of


Big Cities Lag in Clean Air, U.S. Says
LEAD: More than half of all Americans live in cities that have too much ground-level ozone, the chief factor in the creation of smog, and a third live in areas with dangerously high carbon monoxide, the Environmental Protection Agency said today.

Confrontation in the Gulf;   Navy Begins Blockade Enforcing Iraq Embargo
LEAD: The United States said today that its naval forces in the Persian Gulf, the Gulf of Oman and the Red Sea had begun their blockade of vessels carrying oil, food and other supplies to and from Iraq and Iraqi-controlled Kuwait.


Results Plus
LEAD:
LITTLE LEAGUE
Jersey Team Eliminated
Jim Smith's bases-loaded single in the bottom of the eighth inning yesterday gave the Shippensburg team from Pennsylvania a 3-2 victory over Brick National of New Jersey in a semifinal game of the 1990 Eastern Regional Tournament at Bristol, Conn.
In the regional final tomorrow, Shippensburg will play Delaware, which beat Augusta (Me.) by 11-5.


Another Prized Theater For Art Films Is Closing
LEAD: The Bleecker Street Cinema, a popular Greenwich Village theater that has shown foreign and avant-garde films since 1962, will shut down on Aug. 30 because of a sharp rent increase, its owner said yesterday.


Biko's Friend Returns For South Africa Visit
LEAD: Donald Woods, a former newspaper editor who escaped from South Africa in 1977 after being banned for challenging the police account of the 1977 death of Stephen Biko, returned from exile today.

LEAD: An infant who was shaken into a coma when she was 3 1/2 months old died 18 months later, in February 1989.

INSIDE
LEAD:
Teen-Age Birth Rate on Rise
A two-decade decline in birth rates among American teen-agers has abruptly reversed itself, with the sharpest increase among mothers who are 15 to 17 years old.
Page A14.
The Disillusioned Lawyer
A new survey shows what many lawyers have long suspected: More and more of them are unhappy in their work, a trend especially strong among women.

At the Movies
LEAD: ''She's a wild little tidbit.'' That's Laura Dern talking about Lula Pace Fortune, the character she plays in David Lynch's ''Wild at Heart,'' which opens today.


Gomez Loses Poise, Tie Breaker, and Contest
LEAD: Andres Gomez lost his composure in a crucial tie breaker against Christo Van Rensburg today, and this may have cost him a berth in the quarterfinals - and perhaps even the final - of the Volvo International tournament.


New England Bank Weighs Bond Swap
LEAD: The Bank of New England Corporation is considering an exchange of all or part of its $700 million in bonds, which could reduce the value of its present shareholders' interest in the company, the company said in a Securities and Exchange Commission filing.


Sale of Co-ops for Late Payments Is Upheld
LEAD: In a court decision that may strengthen the hand of cooperative apartment owners in financially troubled buildings, a New York State Supreme Court judge yesterday upheld the right of the owners of a Greenwich Village building to auction off 106 apartments owned by a sponsor who is far behind in his maintenance payments.


Traffic Alert
LEAD: Because of the India Day Parade, Lexington Avenue will be closed on Sunday between 26th and 47th Streets from 1:30 to 4 P.M.
For a related street fair, Madison Avenue will be closed between 23d and 26th Streets from noon to 8 P.M.

BUSINESS DIGEST
LEAD:
THE ECONOMY
The Consumer Price Index rose four-tenths of 1 percent last month, a higher-than-expected gain that came despite a sharp drop in energy prices just before the Middle East crisis.
The increase was a sign of inflation's persistent grip on the economy. [Page A1.]
Housing starts fell 2.6 percent last month from June, the sixth straight monthly decline, cutting building activity to its weakest pace in nearly eight years, the Government said.


Paul M. Bernstein, 60, Partner in a Law Firm
LEAD: Paul M. Bernstein, senior partner of the Manhattan law firm of Bernstein Litowitz Berger &amp; Grossman, died on Wednesday at Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan.
He was 60 years old and lived in Belmore, L.I.

LEAD: The Iraqi occupation authorities today ordered 6,500 American and British citizens trapped in Kuwait to assemble at two hotels in the Kuwaiti capital and threatened to remove the foreign residents forcibly from their homes if they refused.

Restaurants
LEAD: In recent years, the Ambassador Grill, a cosmopolitan French restaurant next to the United Nations, has been a favorite haunt of people in the diplomatic community.
With its commodious setting, agreeable food and remarkably low prices, it has been an underappreciated find in this otherwise barren gastronomic domain.

LEAD: In a sign of inflation's persistent grip on the economy, the Labor Department said today that the Consumer Price Index rose by four-tenths of 1 percent last month, a higher-than-expected increase that came despite a sharp drop in energy prices just before the Middle East crisis.

LEAD: Buddy Fields is full of desperation but too full of good humor to blame others.

He feels trapped.
He doesn't even have the privacy in which to peruse his copy of Playgirl.
When he wants to masturbate without interruption, he has to get into the family's aluminum rowboat and go to the middle of the lake.

Taiwan's Indirect Trade
LEAD: Taiwan's trade with China grew nearly 5 percent in the first half of the year, the Government's Board of Foreign Trade said this week.
According to official figures, indirect trade routed through Hong Kong reached $1.83 billion in the first six months of 1990, up 4.7 percent over the corresponding period last year.

LEAD: There are many reasons for dismay, even anger, over this week's New York City jail guards' strike at Rikers Island.

U.S. TRADE DEFICIT LOWEST IN 7 YEARS
LEAD: The nation's trade deficit narrowed a surprising 35 percent in June, to $5.07 billion, its lowest level in seven years.
Exports surged to a record and a slowing economy at home cut imports sharply.
But economists expect rising oil prices and other factors to push the deficit back up again.

Protests Close Refinery
LEAD: Student protesters today forced an important oil refinery in India's northeast state of Assam to close and choked supplies of crude to three others, a state official said.
The Assam Chief Secretary, S. R. Sarwan, said in New Delhi that picketing by the All Assam Students Union in six state oilfields had forced the state-owned refinery in the state capital, Guwahati, to close.

LEAD: Imagine you are seated in a rustic railroad passenger car, near a majestic river.
The whistle blows, and you're under way - behind the nostalgic chuffing of steam power.

You emerge alongside the shore of a pristine reservoir, surrounded by wooded mountains, and skirt its banks for several miles.

LEAD: To the Editor:


Chrysler Offers A Buyout Plan
LEAD: The Chrysler Corporation said it had started an employee buyout plan for its hourly workers to reduce its work force by 600 without layoffs.
Employees who accept the offer will receive between $12,000 and $65,000, depending on seniority, to leave the company, Chrysler said.

Bridge
LEAD: One of the rarest plays in the game is the Devil's Coup, in which an apparently certain trump trick for the defense disappears in the endgame.
Equally rare, and just as satisfying, is the pseudo-Devil's Coup, in which the trump trick disappears but the defense has missed an effective countermove.

L. J. Hooker Stores
LEAD: The L. J. Hooker Corporation said it had received approval in bankruptcy court to close its three remaining retail stores in the Forest Fair Mall near Cincinnati.
The stores to be closed are B. Altman &amp; Company, Bonwit Teller and the Sakowitz specialty store.
Hooker had closed all other units in those three store groups, although it sold two Bonwit stores and the Bonwit name to Pyramid Companies, a developer in Syracuse.

LEAD:
A Volunteer Soviet Army?


In the Customs Service, An Open Door at the Top
LEAD: Scarcely three months after Carol B. Hallett took over as head of the 200-year-old Customs Service, Congressional overseers published a blistering indictment of her domain.


CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF: Energy Policy Trade-Off;   Dependency Is Price Of Years of Cheap Oil
LEAD: In the spring of 1986, George Bush traveled to Saudi Arabia to plead with the world's biggest oil exporter to stop flooding the market.
Mr.
Bush told the Saudis that their overproduction, by driving down the price, was jeopardizing the American oil industry, in turn undermining the nation's economic strength and security.

Mike Haynes Let Go
LEAD: The Los Angeles Raiders have relinquished all rights to Mike Haynes, a 37-year-old defensive back, making the 14-year veteran a free agent.
The Raiders did not protect Haynes after last season.
He was expected to re-sign with the team and report to training camp July 20.
But he and the Raiders never agreed on a contract.

LEAD: When 543 Albanian refugees marched off a ferry in Marseilles last month, many showed their delight to be in France by belting out a version of this country's national anthem.

Mortgage Rates Down
LEAD: Fixed-rate mortgages averaged 10.05 percent this week, down from 10.08 percent last week, according to a national survey released today by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation.
On one-year adjustable rate mortgages, lenders were asking an average initial rate of 8.31 percent, down from 8.39 percent last week.

Correction
LEAD: A review yesterday of the movie ''Wild at Heart'' misidentified the director of photography.
He is Frederick Elmes, not Mark Plummer.


Review/Music;   Reconstituted Little Feat Still Rhythm-Prone
LEAD: Try as it might, Little Feat can't escape the ghost of Lowell George, who died in 1979.
With Mr.
George as its main songwriter and singer, Little Feat brought wordplay and musical gamesmanship to 1970's Southern rock, skewing country with New Orleans polyrhythm and cutting blues with funk.
The reconstituted Little Feat, which has made two albums since 1988, still boasts a rhythm section that can swing, strut, boogie and kick in ordinary or odd meters.


COMPANY BRIEFS
LEAD: *
Accor S.A. of France accepted 53.2 million units of Motel 6 L.P. in response to its tender offer that expired this week, giving it more than 99 percent of Motel 6.
The remaining units are to be acquired in a merger at the tender price of $22.50 a unit.

The Right Time to Protect Banks
LEAD: Banks are not in the same mess as the saving and loan institutions.
But bank failures are uncomfortably frequent and the fund to protect deposits is shrinking.
Thus the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation's proposal to charge higher premiums is financially sound and politically savvy.

OBSERVER
LEAD: Julia Child says she is going to continue cooking and eating rich foods.
This is outrageous.
And what is the Surgeon General doing about it?
What is medical science doing about it?
They are doing nothing.
They are too busy stamping out smokers.
Stamping out smokers is good, to be sure.
We all feel better every time we come across another filthy smoker who has just been stamped out.

LEAD: The Government securities market stabilized yesterday after prices plunged and interest rates soared during the previous session.
Dealers described yesterday's relatively lackluster trading activity as a tug-of-war between market participants influenced by inflationary fears and further weakness in the dollar and those counting on a continuing decline of the economy.

Review/Theater;   Puerto Rican Double Bill Mixes Comic and Tragic
LEAD: Repertorio Espanol has constructed an improbable double bill at the Gramercy Arts Theater: a play about a family tragedy among Puerto Ricans in New York City today and a musical about rural Puerto Rico 130 years ago.
The fit is, at best, imperfect, but the musical has great charm and one leaves the pair, somewhat miraculously, with little emotional confusion.

Fan Roars
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:


Putting Lyme Disease Into Perspective
LEAD: DR.
MATTHEW L. CARTTER, an epidemiologist with the preventable diseases division of the State Department of Health Services, is in charge of surveillance for Lyme disease.
He was the editor of an edition of the Connecticut State Medical Society magazine last year devoted to the disease.Lyme disease was originally believed to cause only the characteristic rash and arthritis, but doctors now know that it can cause cardiological and neurological problems.


Safety Hazard In the Making
LEAD: A modification is currently being incorporated into the Southern State Parkway near the Suffolk/Nassau County line which will produce a very dangerous condition, and is bound to seriously endanger the public safety and the efficient passage of traffic on that highway.


Lifestyle: Sunday Menu;   A Sauce of Ripe Tomatoes Complements Grilled Fish
LEAD: For this meal, it is essential to have the best tomatoes.
If the tomatoes have no flavor, the sauce will have no flavor.


Home Clinic;   Leveling a Sidewalk Slab
LEAD: A CONCRETE sidewalk slab that has tilted because of uneven settling can usually be leveled.
Unless the slab is quite large (more than 4 by 4 feet) or thick, the job is fairly easy.
But two or more people are required, and at least one must be strong enough to pry up the slab with a lever, as described below.

Rhythm Surges to Win Travers
LEAD: Rhythm, a champion 2-year-old but a disappointing 3-year-old for most of this season, circled the field from last place and scored an impressive 3 1/2-length victory today in the $1,178,500 Travers Stakes at Saratoga Race Track.

LEAD: To the Editor:


More Power Restored to Lower Manhattan


On the Mend
LEAD: Just saying ''no'' nearly cost David Opont his life five months ago, when a neighborhood bully tied him up, beat him and set him afire after David refused to smoke a cigarette he thought contained drugs.
As he was released from a New York City hospital last week, the 12-year-old, who had initially been given only a 50 percent chance of survival, called on ''politicians and teachers'' to ''do more to make our children safe.

Jim Florio's response to critics of his tax program misidentified the chairman of the Democratic State Committee.
He is Philip Keegan.

Pastimes;   Chess
LEAD: There were only a few surprises in the Interzonal Tournament for world championship aspirants, which concluded July 14 in Manila.
For the most part, the competition went according to what the rankings of the International Chess Federation would have predicted.


Question Of the Week;   Do Tennis Players Start at Too Young An Age
LEAD: Child prodigies should be permitted to develop their talents and share them with the world from the moment those talents become evident.
The children should be encouraged, supported, nourished, nurtured.
Certainly any child with minimum talents should not be pushed to try to reach a goal that is impossible or unlikely.


Wood Wears Coats of Many Colors
LEAD: AS Betsy McManus and Jennifer Thurstan see it, a plain surface should not be left alone.
It can be painted, glazed, stenciled, stippled or maybe all of the above.
Wood can be made to look like marble or semiprecious stone.
Ordinary pine can be made to resemble exotic zebra wood.

On Spraying For Gypsy Moths

The True Cost of Energy;   Pay It: For Security, the Economy and the Air
LEAD: Saddam Hussein's plunder of Kuwait only dramatizes something Americans have long known from the bottom of their gas tanks: Oil dependency breeds vulnerability.


Wall Street;   Did the Short-Sellers Stumble?
LEAD: Nothing makes a short-seller more confident of impending disaster than a whiff of disappointment in a high-flying company's sales figures.
But the recent experience of Mylan Laboratories Inc., a brash leader of the $2 billion generic drug industry, suggests that the shorts are not infallible.


Weill's Odyssey: Part 1, Europe, Is Getting Its Due
LEAD: In his 90th birthday year, Kurt Weill remains an increasingly emblematic 20th-century composer.
Before most anyone else, he abandoned modernist dissonance and abstraction in favor of a style that delicately balanced formal integrity with popular appeal.


Recycling Measure: A Pleasant Surprise
LEAD: I recently returned to New Jersey after an absence of about 10 years.
It won't come as a surprise to anyone that I was met with utter amazement every time I told people where I was going, and that I was doing it by choice. ''But why New Jersey?
It is so dirty,'' was the general message.

The bride, 37 years old, will keep her name.

Campus Life: Maryland;   Diggers Unearth Clues to History Of Free Blacks
LEAD: Writers filling history textbooks with accounts of blacks in America's slave days often omit stories about the ones who were never slaves.
But the University of Maryland and the Historic Annapolis Foundation plan to piece together part of this forgotten history from broken glass, ceramics and other artifacts unearthed in a parking lot here.


Where There's Smoke There's Flavor
LEAD: THE idea of smoking fish and game to preserve them has been around since the discovery of fire.
But recently customers at the new West Street Grill in Litchfield, Conn. (203-567-3885) have been intrigued by the subtle, smoky flavor of unexpected foods such as tomatoes, corn and even lentils.


CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF    FOREIGNERS IN IRAQ WILL SHARE IN HARDSHIPS, BAGHDAD WARNS; SAUDIS TO INCREASE OIL OUTPUT;   CHALLENGE TO OPEC
LEAD: Saudi Arabia served notice today that it would increase oil production by two million barrels a day with or without the support of other members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries.
That would equal half the oil lost to the world market because of the international embargo on Iraqi and Kuwaiti oil shipments.


Sticking To Rules
LEAD: Although Japanese corporate interests have been buying golf courses and sponsoring tournaments in the United States in order to increase their visibility on television back in Japan, what happened this weekend at the JAL Big Apple Classic pretty much resembled a drive into a bunker.


Reappraising the Appraisal Industry
LEAD: ''THE party is over,'' said Eugene Albert, a real estate appraiser. ''The binging of the 1980's is finished.'' Mr.
Albert was discussing the excesses that characterized the 1980's real estate market and led to a recent law requiring state certification of real estate appraisers.

LEAD: Officials of California State University at Long Beach are hurriedly rearranging fall music-school programs after a recital hall roof collapsed and seven other buildings were closed because of concern that they were unsafe.

Recycling Measure: A Pleasant Surprise
LEAD: As chief environmental official for the Town of Babylon, Suffolk County, New York, I was dismayed to read in the article ''Recycling: New Report, New Debate'' that our town had abandoned its newspaper recycling program in order to provide the requisite amount of fuel for our resource recovery plant.


Fashion: On the Street;   Summer's Assertive Success
LEAD: At least once a season, it seems, a fashion item appears and almost at once asserts itself.
This summer that item is a cotton canvas jacket from the designer Isaac Mizrahi that comes in a variety of graphic black-and-white patterns: checks, diamonds, spots, stripes and abstract flowers.
Besides the boldness of its racing-pattern prints, what sets this jacket apart is its signature solid-black collar.

Question Of the Week;   Do Tennis Players Start at Too Young An Age
LEAD: Many over-ambitious parents, dazzled by visions of trophies and dollar signs, do push their offspring into tennis almost from infancy.
Such parents should be reminded that Stefan Edberg, the Wimbledon champion and the No. 1 player in the world, did not start playing tennis until the age of 7.
Throughout a normal childhood spent at home, not at a tennis academy, he continued to pursue many other sports, including soccer, hockey and basketball.

LEAD: IT is not sheer coincidence that the imperial city of New York is also the most pedestrian city in the country.

CHILDREN'S BOOKS: Bookshelf
LEAD: Additional titles of interest:


Review/Rock;   Cajun Singer Transcends Novelty
LEAD: In the mid-1950's, when the Cajun rockabilly singer Joe Cheramie was 17, he earned a contract with RCA records.
The company flew the singer, who called himself Joe Clay, from Harvey, La., to New York City, where he recorded with a group of New York's best black rhythm-and-blues musicians.
A rare early example of racial integration in pop music, the records, featuring two drummers who played simultaneously, are astonishingly hard.

Review/Jazz;   A Young Blues Guitarist Intent on Modernization
LEAD: About halfway through his set at Manny's Car Wash on Tuesday night, the young blues guitarist and singer Kenny Neal played ''The Things That I Used to Do.'' The song, which was written by Guitar Slim in the mid-1950's, has become a standard because of its originality, derived from a distinct guitar figure and the unusual rise and fall of its melody.

THE ANT MAN
LEAD: When E. O. Wilson got in trouble for saying that sexual division of labor in modern man may be an adaptive trait and that there may be a ''loose correlation'' between worldly success and genetically determined traits, Elizabeth Royte implies it was ''Marxist influence at Harvard'' that caused the subsequent uproar (''The Ant Man,'' July 22).

Tech Notes;   Computers Linked by Light
LEAD: In the past, computers were linked together by networks made of wire or fiber-optic cables that were placed under the floors and under the ground.
Now, engineers at the Photonics Corporation in Campell, Calif., are linking them with light.
The new networking system - Photolink (right) - works very much like the remote control unit of a television set.

LEAD: THE Bellport is made for summer.

It is a perfect backdrop for the season.

LEAD: Most people familiar with the oddly shaped, ''winged'' structure that straddles the Penn Central Railroad tracks on West 33d Street and 10th Avenue know it as the home of Sky Rink, Manhattan's only public indoor ice-skating rink.


Roderick Cook, Actor On Stage, Dead at 58
LEAD: Roderick Cook, the British-born stage and film actor who was perhaps best known for his 1972 Off Broadway revue ''Oh Coward!'' in which he adapted and performed the works of Sir Noel Coward, died on Friday at his home in Los Angeles at the age of 58.
Dan V. Fuller, his business manager, said Mr.
Cook died of what appeared to be a heart attack.

LEAD: Traveling West From Detroit about 200 miles along I-96, crack arrived in Muskegon County, Mich., late in September 1988.
Or at least that's when the prosecutor Tony Tague first started noticing that a crime rampage was rocking this hard-scrabble, blue-collar county - the kind of siege that supposedly strikes only the nation's largest cities.

LEAD: The flying disk slices through the air - whishhh - and Boe takes off after it.
His muscles appear in outline as he gains with each bound.
Forty, 50, 60 yards: it's within reach.
Suddenly he's flying - whooshhh - and he clamps down on the disk.
As he settles back to earth the crowd breaks into applause.

LEAD: Working in the jungle one degree south of the Equator, the heat on the set repeatedly hit 108 degrees.
At dusk, tropical downpours washed out key shots day after day.
Exotic ailments felled several of Hollywood's finest.
During one week of night shooting, the call sheet warned actors of ''insects and crawly things around the set.

Pastimes;   Coins
LEAD: Commerce in the Middle Ages was a strange affair.
Picture merchants in London adding 12 pence to a shilling and 20 shillings to a pound.
And then don't forget farthings, sixpence and guineas.
Then, just to complicate the calculations even more, picture them doing all the addition, subtraction, division and multiplication using Roman numerals.

A Lazzeri Vote
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:


Photography's Early Images Keep the Nation's Past Alive
LEAD: PHOTOGRAPHY was officially born with the daguerreotype in the Paris of 1839, but its birth pangs began as early as 1826.
In that year, Joseph Niepce (also in France) made an eight-hour exposure of the view from his house on a plate of pewter.
Then there was the Englishman William Fox Talbot, who, in 1835, produced the first image on sensitized paper, calling it a calotype and, later on, a talbotype, but not unveiling it until 18 days after the debut of the daguerreotype.


Fictional Policewomen Are Good Role Models
LEAD: Congratulations to the authors Lillian O'Donnell and Dorothy Uhnak, who share the field of policewoman-mystery genre and have helped to reinforce the image of the intelligent female sleuth (''Fans Keep Watch on Prolific Mystery Writer,'' July 15).
They both show policewomen no longer silenced and being recognized as equals to men, contributing to detective investigations and being inspiring role models.

The Quiet Side of the Delaware Shore
LEAD: A mosaic of marsh, woods and upland fields, Prime Hook National Wildlife Refuge on the southwest shore of Delaware Bay is a welcome relief from the crush of the Eastern Seaboard.
Its 8,800 acres of rich land draw tens of thousands of migratory birds and relatively few people.
Flocks of geese and ducks gather in the fall, shorebirds and warblers in the spring.

Review/Theater;   Learning to Love, Too Late
LEAD: During the blackouts between scenes in Ted Whitehead's play ''The Man Who Fell in Love With His Wife,'' excerpts of golden oldies ranging from Nat (King) Cole to the Beatles to David Bowie are played over the Quaigh Theater's sound system.
This hit parade from the past is the best part of an otherwise tedious tale of a Liverpool docker's midlife crisis, which he is handling rather badly.


A TASTE FOR SCRAMBLED ENGLISH
LEAD: We found illustrations of scrambled English in Barcelona.
The popular word there for jogging is el footing.
A Barcelona daily, Avui (Catalan for today), printed a feature on a new sport sweeping the United States, one that requires no teamwork, competition, special facilities or complex rules.
This new sport, one learns, is el fitness.

Home Clinic;   Leveling a Sidewalk Slab
LEAD: A CONCRETE sidewalk slab that has tilted because of uneven settling can usually be leveled.
Unless the slab is quite large (more than 4 by 4 feet) or thick, the job is fairly easy.
But two or more people are required, and at least one must be strong enough to pry up the slab with a lever, as described below.

LEAD: It happened.

Don't delay making plans for next spring's garden, and mail hardy bulb orders for delivery in early fall.

Ice Cream for La Dolce Vita
LEAD: Sometime during the Roman Empire an anonymous genius poured fruit juice over snow and ate it.

LEAD: A shabby, mice-ridden worker's cottage may seem an unlikely dwelling for a Romantic poet and his family, but such a cottage in the Somerset village of Nether Stowey was, during the final three years of the 18th century, the place where Samuel Taylor Coleridge's imagination took flight.
Or, rather, took to sea.

Systems for Students on the Move
LEAD: The college years are when music begins to occupy an eminent place in many lives.
During this time, nothing more effectively spurs incipient musical interests than a really good-sounding yet easily transportable stereo system.
Whether acquired with savings from a summer job or as a munificent back-to-school gift, such a system serves as an exploratory probe into still unknown worlds of music.

Home Clinic;   Leveling a Sidewalk Slab
LEAD: A CONCRETE sidewalk slab that has tilted because of uneven settling can usually be leveled.
Unless the slab is quite large (more than 4 by 4 feet) or thick, the job is fairly easy.
But two or more people are required, and at least one must be strong enough to pry up the slab with a lever, as described below.

On Language;   Medical Edibles
LEAD: Things are easier to remember when they are named after something familiar, and what could be more familiar than food?
It comes in every color, shape and size.
And everybody eats.
The father of modern medicine figured this out 2,400 years ago.
Noticing strange noises coming from the chests of some sick people, Hippocrates described the sound to his students as ''bubbling like boiling vinegar.

Reviews/Music;   'Tosca' With a More Human Scarpia
LEAD: The New York City Opera's sturdy production of ''Tosca,'' which returned to the New York State Theater on Saturday evening, makes some interesting points by toying with viewers' expectations.
We expect the corrupt Baron Scarpia, for instance, to be irredeemably evil, but he is introduced in an understated way that makes him more complex and at times more human.

Inmate's Death Not Linked To Clash, an Autopsy Finds
LEAD: A Rikers Island inmate who died Saturday ''suffered no physical injuries that either caused or contributed to his death,'' but instead died of kidney infection, according to preliminary autopsy findings released yesterday by the New York City Medical Examiner's Office.

LEAD: To the Editor:


Good Day for Yanks and Merrill
LEAD: With the game against the Seattle Mariners an hour away, Stump Merrill, manager of the Yankees, sat alone in his office yesterday afternoon, poring over the scouting reports and statistical breakdowns.
The silence was ultimately broken by the sound that over the years had amused, annoyed and forever haunted the men who had sat in Merrill's chair.

Tokyo Stock Prices Decline
LEAD: Stock prices fell in light mid-afternoon trading today as arbitragers sold the cash index to buy futures.
A surge in selling orders by a large Japanese brokerage after the midday break added to the swift decline, brokers said.

How Vulnerable Is Iraq?
LEAD: Short of food and dependent on imports for everything from auto parts to chicken parts, Iraq's economy is widely assumed to be exceptionally vulnerable to a trade embargo.
If the United States and its allies are prepared to stand up to Baghdad's threats over the weekend to cut off food to foreigners in Iraq - an indication that the embargo is indeed causing worry - the effects of the sanctions are likely to take hold quickly.

Shutdown at Ford Plant
LEAD: The Ford Motor Company will extend last week's shutdown of its Dearborn assembly plant through this week because of a shortage of 2.3-liter engines for the Mustang model.
A Ford spokesman, Jay Meisenhelder, said the shortage was a result of a switch to a slightly different 2.3-liter engine made in the company's Lima, Ohio, engine plant.

Russian Party Ranks Shrink
LEAD: The head of the Russian republic's Communist Party was quoted today as saying 162,750 members - 90,000 of them factory workers - quit in July, about 1.5 percent of the 11 million members.
The announcement by Ivan K. Polozkov, who was elected in June, was reported by the republic newspaper Sovetskaya Rossiya.

Let's Leave Oil Behind
LEAD: To the Editor:


Prices Up 9.8% in Britain
LEAD: Retail prices in Britain rose 9.8 percent in the 12 months that ended in July, the same rate as in June, the Government said Friday.
Some economists had forecast that the rate might break through 10 percent because of higher wage settlements and consumer spending.
Lower prices for seasonal foods in July left the figure unchanged from June.

LEAD: The Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Lauren Joy Bartner, the daughter of Mrs.

Norman Bartner of Closter, N.J., to Dr.
Joseph Asher Singer, the son of Hannah Singer of Forest Hills, Queens, and the late Abraham Singer.

Pro Bono
LEAD: *
The animated dancing raisins that represent the California Raisin Advisory Board will be used in a public service announcement this fall for the American Library Association.
The television spot, which will be the first public service announcement featuring the raisins, will have the characters performing a rap song encouraging children to read.

LEAD: Taiwan will reduce tariffs on 1,900 goods in a move intended to support its attempt to join the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, the Finance Ministry said last week.

Outdoors: Some Sedentary Seafood for All Seasons
LEAD: EVERY year when confronted by the dog days of August - a time when, for shore fishermen at least, such species as striped bass and bluefish are often difficult to locate along much of the Northeast coast - I begin thinking of other sources of food and fun, among them soft- and hard-shelled clams and mussels, critters that don't move about with the seasons.


Bridge
LEAD: The twists of international events that have made Washington and Moscow allies instead of antagonists have many parallels in the microcosm of the bridge world.
One day's teammate is likely to be the next day's opponent, and those who organize bridge events regularly switch from cooperation to confrontation.

LEAD: The sensuous music and movement in ''Voces de Acero'' (Voices of Steel) by the Pregones Theater, presented as part of the Festival Latino at the Public Theater, might make some viewers think the experience of prison is not all bad.

Foster Grant Bankruptcy
LEAD: The Foster Grant Corporation, the maker of sunglasses, filed for protection from its creditors on Thursday under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code.
In the filing in Tucson, Ariz., it reported total assets of about $25 million and liabilities of about $36 million, including nearly $19.3 million in unsecured debt.

LEAD: The Rolling Stones, once denounced by the former Communist Government of Czechoslovakia as a capitalist money-making machine, performed before an enthusiastic audience of 107,000 who ignored a heavy rain to attend an outdoor concert on Saturday, which both the band and the fans said they had been awaiting for years.

LEAD: The Cirrus and Plus automatic teller networks have agreed to make their machines available to the holders of each company's cards, Plus System Inc. said yesterday.

Correction
LEAD: Because of an editing error, an editorial on Saturday misstated the proposed increase in bank premiums for Federal Deposit Insurance.
The proposal is to raise premiums to, not by, 19 1/2 cents per $100 of insured deposits.

LEAD: In a further sign of weakness in the nation's economy, the number of people receiving food stamps and welfare benefits has jumped sharply this year.

Gooden Falters But Mets Win, 10-9
LEAD: Forget that the Mets won a game they had to win tonight when they outscored the San Francisco Giants, 10-9, and stayed two games out of first place in the National League East.
Forget that Kevin McReynolds knocked in six runs with two home runs and a single.
And, most of all, forget that Dwight Gooden won his 13th game of the season.


Banking Expert Criticized
LEAD: In an unusual move, the chairman of the House Banking Committee has suggested that a financial expert who is studying the health of the commercial banking industry's deposit insurance system for a banking subcommittee should be removed.


It's Kickoff Time For a New Game
LEAD: FACED with legal challenges, shifting alliances and a deteriorating relationship with the National Football League, college football is beginning the most significant season in its 122-year history.

Move by FundAmerica
LEAD: FundAmerica Inc., a buying club with 100,000 members, filed for bankruptcy protection from its creditors and asked the court to appoint an independent examiner to investigate various allegations against it.
The company, based in Irvine, Calif., is facing scrutiny from regulators in Florida and other states and is the subject of a $150 million class-action suit filed in San Francisco.

LEAD: ''I've been a character actor for, my God, 27 years,'' said Paul Benedict. ''I play a lot of really bizarre people.''

THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Group Restricts Billboard Ads
LEAD: The Outdoor Advertising Association of America, in response to growing protests by special-interest groups that want to ban the use of billboards for tobacco and alcohol advertisements, said the international children's symbol - a stylized figure of a child walking - would be used to mark billboards that will be off-limits to advertising any product or service illegal for sale to minors.


Review/Television;   Adventure With a Cause
LEAD: ''The Last Elephant'' is evidence for the proposition that good causes make bad art.
In pursuance of its honorable campaign to arouse indignation over the slaughter of Africa's elephants by ivory poachers, the National Audubon Society has come up with a show that poaches on countless B-movies but produces nothing as precious as ivory.

LEAD: *
Ralph Rydholm, a managing partner and chief creative officer at Tatham-Laird &amp; Kudner, Chicago, has been assigned the additional role of chairman of the agency.
Ian Miller, a senior vice president and client director at the Chicago office of Ogilvy &amp; Mather, has joined Tatham-Laird as president and managing partner.


Ms. Singer Wed to Frederick Weibgen
LEAD: Marcie Fried Singer and Frederick Hartmut Weibgen were married yesterday at their home in Teaneck, N.J., by Mayor Eleanor Kieliszek of Teaneck.
Mrs.
Weibgen is a daughter of Phyllis Dubetsky of Teaneck and Ralph Fried of Elizabeth, N.J.
Her husband is the son of Elisabeth Weibgen of Kronberg, West Germany, and the late Hans-Joachim Weibgen.

Armed Serbs Guard Highways in Croatia During Referendum
LEAD: Bands of armed Serbs blocked roads today in districts of the Croatian republic inhabited largely by ethnic Serbs, trying to prevent Croatian authorities from interfering with a ''referendum'' on local autonomy.

ABC's newscast ratings jumped the most.
Page D1.


Review/Pop;   Armatrading In the Mood For Rocking
LEAD: Not too many performing songwriters have Joan Armatrading's ability to put a personal signature on so many modes of pop.
Even though the West Indian-born English singer, who performed at the Beacon Theater on Tuesday evening, is something of a stylistic chameleon, moving easily from folk-pop to reggae to hard rock, she usually succeeds in bringing something fresh to each genre.


FOREIGNERS TRAPPED TILL U.S. LEAVES REGION, IRAQI WARNS; SAYS KUWAIT IS 'ARAB ISSUE'
LEAD: President Saddam Hussein of Iraq said tonight that he would free foreigners being held hostage in Iraq and Kuwait in exchange for a complete military and political pullout by the United States from the Persian Gulf region.

Atlanta Church Begins Inquiry
LEAD: The Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Atlanta said Saturday that Donald R. Keough, president of the Coca-Cola Company, would head an inquiry into whether Vicki Long had improperly received church money during her affair with the Archbishop Eugene A. Marino.


Mack Trucks' Projection
LEAD: Mack Trucks Inc. increased its projected loss for the year by 38 percent Friday, to $180 million.
Mack now expects sales to total $1.67 billion, compared with the $1.5 billion predicted earlier.
Mack originally predicted a loss of $130 million.
The truck maker lost $97 million for the first half of the year and went into default on its large bank loans.


Oil, Saddam Hussein and the Re-emergence of America as the Superpower
LEAD: The obituaries were a bit premature.


U.S. Evacuates 800 From Liberia
LEAD: United States Marines plucked about 800 people, most of them Lebanese, from Liberia's war-torn capital today and flew them by helicopter to neighboring Sierra Leone.


U.S. Consults U.N. on Use of Force As Navy Shadows 2 Iraqi Tankers
LEAD: With American warships shadowing two loaded Iraqi oil tankers in Middle East waters, the Bush Administration began a round of urgent diplomacy today in hopes of winning United Nations approval of its use of military power to enforce the international embargo on trade with Iraq, Administration officials said.


Nimitz Sailors Reprimanded
LEAD: Four sailors have lost their clearance to work on nuclear ships because they publicly questioned the safety of the nuclear reactor program on the aircraft carrier Nimitz instead of telling their superiors, Navy officials said.

B. F. Skinner, the Champion Of Behaviorism, Is Dead at 86
LEAD: B. F. Skinner, who studied human and animal behavior in ingenious experiments and hoped that his findings would foster creativity and curtail repression, died Saturday at Mount Auburn Hospital in Cambridge, Mass.
He was 86 years old and lived in Cambridge.

Results Plus
LEAD:
Horse Racing
Triple Crown for Izvestia: Izvestia yesterday captured the Canadian Triple Crown with a 6 1/2-length victory in the Breeders' Stakes at Woodbine in Toronto.
This was the second Canadian Triple Crown in a row for Kinghaven Farms, which swept the three races - the Queen's Plate, the Prince of Wales Stakes and the Breeders' Stakes - with With Approval last year.


Business and the Law;   A Favored Shield In S.&amp; L. Cases
LEAD: THE business judgment rule, the well-worn legal shield that protects those executives who are foolhardy along with those with foresight, is expected to play a large role in many negligence cases brought by the Government against savings and loan officials.


Reviews/Music;   Yevgeny Nesterenko With Songs of Home
LEAD: Every so often an occasion of sheer delight comes along to reward a weary critic in spite of his sins.
The recital this evening by the veteran bass Yevgeny Nesterenko in the Nicholas Music Center here offered that promise, but no guarantees.
The 52-year-old Russian had not appeared in the United States much of late, and recent reports of his vocal state were mostly discouraging.

Study in Dallas Finds Race Affects Sentences
LEAD: Killers and rapists whose victims were white got more severe punishment than those whose victims were black or Hispanic, according to a newspaper survey of sentencing in Dallas County in 1988.

LEAD: ''I just don't like taking questions on serious matters on my vacation.

And then when we're working, which I'm trying to do up here also, I'll work hard.''
- President Bush, on the 18th hole. [A8:2.]

Chris Silva, Swimmer, 29
LEAD: Chris Silva, a swimmer and a leading force in attracting blacks to American competitive swimming, was killed Sunday when the car he was driving crashed into a tree.

BKLA Bancorp In Shift at Top
LEAD: The BKLA Bancorp, parent company of the Bank of Los Angeles, said today that its president and chief executive, Gerald S. Weisstein, had resigned and would be succeeded by Mark E. Buchman, a former president of the Government National Mortgage Association.


Driver Convicted of Murder
LEAD: A man who drove through a red light and struck another vehicle was convicted of murder today in the death of an 11-year-old girl killed in the crash.
A jury convicted Stephen Padula, 21, of Oneonta, of second-degree murder and leaving an accident scene.
The police said Mr.
Padula's car was traveling faster than 70 miles an hour when it struck a car in which Eleanor Hosley was riding on July 11, 1989, in Oneonta, about 50 miles east of Albany.


Landmark Challenge: West Side Story
LEAD: New York City's Landmarks Preservation Commission surely means to do good on Manhattan's West Side - but so far its good intentions risk paralyzing the welcome development in the large area bounded by Central Park West and Amsterdam Avenue and 62d and 96th Streets.


Market Place;   Prospects for Quick Revival At Cetus Seem to Be Slight
LEAD: The Cetus Corporation, once a leader in biotechnology, is down for the count.
Late last month, an advisory panel to the Food and Drug Administration said data were lacking that would justify approving the company's flagship drug for marketing.
Last week, the company's chief executive, Robert A. Fildes, resigned under pressure and the company announced plans to reduce its work force of 950 by 100.

3-Year-Old Title: Best Race Around
LEAD: The best horse race this year began a few months ago and will not end until nearly Halloween.
That race is the one for the 3-year-old championship, and it is getting better all the time.

Love Nests
Animals and birds once thought to mate for life are engaging in all sorts of what scientists call extra-pair copulation.
Science Times, page C1.
Exit Steinbrenner
George Steinbrenner, after running the Yankees for 17 1/2 years, said he has signed a letter resigning as the managing partner.

He is John R. McKernan Jr.

Payola Trial Is Opening Today For Successful Record Promoter
LEAD: In a case that has already generated enormous alarm in the $9-billion-a-year record-and-music industry and forced changes in its business methods, one of the most powerful and successful record promoters of the 1980's is going on trial here Tuesday in Federal court, charged with racketeering and providing payola.


Eli Lilly's Spending Plans
LEAD: Eli Lilly &amp; Company said yesterday that it would spend $540 million over the next five years to build drug laboratories and plants near the company headquarters in Indianapolis.

LEAD: It is hard to think of a better group than the Hubbard Street Dance Company for Twyla Tharp to have approached about reviving some of her older dances.

Brazilian Capital Blacked Out
LEAD: Most of the capital, Brasilia, was without power today, and the Government said it suspected sabotage by striking electricity workers.
Officials said four of the five transmission lines serving the area of 1.8 million people were out of action, trapping people in elevators and disrupting businesses.


Beef on the Hoof in New York State? Let the World Know, Ranchers Say
LEAD: One hundred cattle ranchers gathered this weekend on one of the largest spreads in New York State here in the Hudson Valley to talk about improving their cows and profits.


Interco Announces a Plan To Revise Its $1.9 Billion Debt
LEAD: Interco Inc., a footwear and furniture maker, will ask its bondholders to exchange their bonds for 95 percent of the company's common stock and other considerations under a complicated plan announced today.


Merrill Officer Stepping Down
LEAD: Merrill Lynch &amp; Company said yesterday that William W. Moore, the senior vice president in charge of its municipal markets group, would step down from his post at the start of next year.


Top Taiwan Military Officers Among 18 Killed in Air Crash
LEAD: An aircraft carrying three Taiwan Air Force major generals and eight colonels crashed in central Taiwan today, killing all 18 people on board, military officials said.

By Design;   Where Is Sir Walter Raleigh?
LEAD: From Southampton to Saratoga Springs, summertime partygoers dressed for outdoor affairs have encountered an unexpected problem: a sea of mud under the tents.
With all the wet weather, the grass at outdoor parties, especially near the bar and the buffet, can turn into ooze, transforming all those well-dressed swells into literal muckymucks.

Warriors Sign Two
LEAD: The Golden State Warriors announced yesterday that Tom Tolbert, a restricted free agent, and Kevin Pritchard, a second-round draft pick, have signed contracts.
Tolbert, a 6-8 forward, agreed to a four-year contract, while Pritchard, a 6-3 guard, reached a three-year agreement with the team.
No other terms were released.

The Emerging Unipolar World
LEAD: It took the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait to reveal what should have been obvious all along to foreign policy experts: The bipolar, cold war world has given way not to ''multipolarity'' but to ''unipolarity,'' with the U.S. as the only pole left.


11 Killed Sleeping in South African Hostel
LEAD: Eleven people were killed as they slept in a workers' hostel in the latest eruption of fighting between black factions in South Africa's townships, the police said today.


BUSINESS DIGEST
LEAD:
THE OIL JOLT
After rising for seven days, the price of oil fluctuated before closing slightly lower in the first trading session after the announcement by the Saudi oil minister that his country would pump an extra two million barrels a day.
But gasoline prices kept rising sharply, and the market remained nervous.


Praise From Grambling
LEAD: On the day that George Steinbrenner was to step down as the managing partner of the Yankees, at least one man, the Grambling State University football coach, Eddie Robinson, chose to praise rather than bury him.
Quoting from Shakespeare's ''Julius Caesar'' to the effect that the evil a man does lives after him while the good is often buried with him, Robinson said he wanted to take the opportunity to credit Steinbrenner with saving the Whitney M.

RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:
TENNIS
Rubin Defeats Mandlikova
Fourteen-year-old Chanda Rubin, in her first match against a prominent player, yesterday defeated Hana Mandlikova, a former United States Open champion, 6-4, 6-4, in the first round of the Pathmark Tennis Classic in Mahway, N.J.
In the opening match, Peanut Louie Harper took the victory after her opponent, Sandra Cecchini of Italy, in obvious pain from an injury suffered during practice Saturday, decided to drop out of the match.

Orange Juice Prices Lowest In Nearly Eight Months
LEAD: Prices on orange juice futures settled at their lowest levels in nearly eight months yesterday after two Brazilian processors cut prices for the first time since a Christmas-time freeze shriveled the Florida orange crop.


Unix Pact Is Disclosed
LEAD: The Santa Cruz Operation, a software company based in Santa Cruz, Calif., which supplies a version of the Unix operating system for personal computers, will announce Tuesday that it had entered an agreement with the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and the Intel Corporation to produce a standard form of Unix for use on PC's equipped with Intel microprocessors.


Jury Misconduct Charged in Case of Agent's Death
LEAD: Lawyers for four men convicted of kidnapping and other crimes linked to the slaying of an American drug agent in Mexico challenged their convictions today, adding another strange chapter to a trial already complicated by unusual events.


Pepsico Official Gets A Top Toys 'R' Us Job
LEAD: Toys ''R'' Us, the world's largest toy retailer, named a Pepsico Inc. executive, Larry D. Bouts, yesterday to head its fast-growing international business.

Oil Prices Ease a Bit After Climb
LEAD: After rising for seven days, the price of oil closed slightly lower yesterday, the first trading session after the announcement by the Saudi oil minister that his country would pump an extra two million barrels a day, with or without OPEC approval.
But the price of gasoline continued to rise sharply, and both markets remained nervous.


Subway Improvements Will Be Delayed
LEAD: Repairs to subway stations and tunnels, train yards and other New York mass-transit centers will be delayed for at least a year, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority announced yesterday.

LEAD: As Iraq began moving Americans and other foreigners to military and industrial installations, President Bush declared for the first time today that those trapped in Iraq are indeed hostages.
He vowed that ''America will not be intimidated'' by Iraq's efforts to use them as shields against attack.


Net Up 2.1% At K Mart
LEAD: The K Mart Corporation said today that its second-quarter earnings rose 2.1 percent despite lower prices, mainly because of growth in apparel and seasonal hardware sales.

LEAD: For the sake of valuable musical instruments, if for no other reason, it is high time this meteorologically misbegotten season of outdoor music comes to a close.
By the end of the final concert of the Caramoor season in the Venetian Theater this evening, the instruments of the St.
Luke's Chamber Ensemble must have been thoroughly waterlogged.


Designing One Tough Turnstile for New York
LEAD: Grown men are beating turnstiles with sledgehammers, jamming them with paper, splashing them with water and Coca-Cola and exposing them to a gigantic vibration machine and to temperatures from 30 degrees below zero to 150 above in a special rain- and snow-making chamber.


U.S.-Russian Shoemaking Venture Set
LEAD: In a major consumer goods venture with the Soviet Union, a Long Island company has a preliminary agreement to help Russians produce 50 million pairs of shoes over the next decade.

LEAD: The Energy Department has recommended stepped-up production of ethanol, a corn-based moonshine that is blended with gasoline to make cleaner-burning gasohol.

Critic's Notebook;   How Network Reporters Cover The Gulf, or at Least Some of It
LEAD: Since the beginning of the confrontation between Iraq and the United States, network correspondents have been trying to break through interdictions on coverage by both sides.
All the big guns have been deployed: Dan Rather and Ted Koppel in Baghdad; Tom Brokaw and Sam Donaldson in Saudi Arabia; others in Cairo, Riyadh, Amman, Damascus, Dubai, Ankara, Aqaba, Jerusalem and other points east, moving as close as they can to the action, or at least the activity.

LEAD: Harry C. Piper Jr., a Minneapolis stockbroker who paid a $1 million ransom for the return of his kidnapped wife in 1972, died on Sunday at his home in Orono, Minn., at the age of 72.

New Victims of the Realty Slump: Insurers
LEAD: The insurance industry is starting to suffer from the slump in real estate that has already hurt many banks and savings and loan institutions.
The delinquency rate on mortgages for office buildings, hotels, shopping malls and other commercial properties held by the nation's insurance companies has increased sharply in recent months, leading to predictions by some in the industry that foreclosures on these types of loans could double over the next three years.


Mating for Life? It's Not for the Birds of the Bees
LEAD: AH, romance.
Can any sight be as sweet as a pair of mallard ducks gliding gracefully across a pond, male by female, seemingly inseparable?
Or better yet, two cygnet swans, which, as biologists have always told us, remain coupled for life, their necks and fates lovingly intertwined.

LEAD: CHEMICALS in cigarette smoke will switch on a gene in lung cells that then helps make those compounds far more likely to cause cancer, researchers have reported.

LEAD: A Federal judge today ordered the release of a secret agreement made in February between the Government and the Northrop Corporation.

CHRONICLE
LEAD: BARRY TUCKWELL, the French horn player, has written ''Duet for Harry and Barry,'' which he says is the only work for tuba and horn.
And he is to perform it tomorrow with HARRY SMITH on ''CBS This Morning.'' Mr.
Smith is a classically trained tuba player and the anchor of the program.
The two will rehearse together tomorrow morning at about the time most people are still snoring happily.


Chess
LEAD: Neither of the two youngest players hailed as having real hopes to reach the select circle of the top 11 in the Interzonal Tournament in Manila succeeded.
Joel Lautier of France, at 16 the youngest grandmaster currently, and Gata Kamsky of the United States via the Soviet Union, who at the same age lacks only the formality of that title, showed that despite their unarguable talent, they need more seasoning.

Review/Fashion;   To Sleep? Chances Are, to Dream.
LEAD: Take three avant-garde designers, ask them for their ideas on lingerie, and you're likely to get the unexpected.

Nightgowns that lace up the back.
A satin housedress.

Talks Aimed at Ending Salvador's Civil War Fail
LEAD: Three days of talks between the Salvadoran Government and leftist guerrillas here have failed to produce a cease-fire in their civil war.


NORTHWEST PILOTS ARE FOUND GUILTY OF DRUNKEN FLYING
LEAD: In the first drunken-flying conviction of professional pilots, a Federal jury today found three former Northwest Airlines pilots guilty of flying a jetliner under the influence of alcohol.


Time Squeezes Iraq
LEAD: A frustrated and besieged Saddam Hussein now makes a liar of his Foreign Minister and affronts law and Islamic custom by interning ''foreign guests'' in Iraq and Kuwait.
In fact, as President Bush said yesterday, thousands of innocent citizens are now hostages.
Small wonder that some Americans respond viscerally, urging armed reprisals or even a declaration of war.

New Direction in Physics: Back in Time
LEAD: THE possibility of traveling through time, of creating something out of nothing and even of spawning a new universe in a laboratory are notions ordinarily reserved to fiction rather than science.
But a rash of articles in some of the most prestigious scientific publications suggests that theoretical physicists have begun to take such outlandish ideas seriously.

LEAD: All but a single business among the 1,600 electric customers that lost power a week ago when a fire destroyed an electrical substation were back on by yesterday, Consolidated Edison said.

LEAD: By settling a racial discrimination lawsuit filed seven years ago by a black agent against the Federal Bureau of Investigation, Director William Sessions reaffirms his commitment to transform the bureau's culture of minority exclusion.


Success of a Horse Vaccine in China Raises Hope in Fight Against AIDS
LEAD: TWENTY-FIVE years ago, a viral epidemic was ravaging China's horse population.
Many horses had fevers and lacked energy, and a number died.
Other infected horses showed no symptoms, although they could transmit the disease by blood-to-blood contact and through sex.

LEAD: British Petroleum P.L.C. said it would auction off its gas exploration and production holding company in the Netherlands.

Breast Cancer Drug May Benefit the Heart
LEAD: TAMOXIFEN, a hormonal drug taken by thousands of women to help prevent recurrence of breast cancer, may also protect them against heart disease, according to a study reported in the current issue of the Journal of the National Cancer Institute.
The two-year study, conducted among 140 women past menopause, showed that the medication helped reduce their blood levels of cholesterol and especially of harmful LDL cholesterol.
