The Home Weatherman
LEAD: AMERICANS SEEM to be preoccupied with the weather.
There are frequent reports and forecasts on the radio and, on local television, the weatherman or woman gets star billing.
There is a special 900 telephone number if you can't wait for Willard or Frank, and even a cable television channel devoted to weather, 24 hours a day.


Review/Music;   Contrasting Styles in a Heavy-Metal Battle of the Bands
LEAD: Friday night's show at the Beacon Theater shaped up like a heavy-metal battle of the bands, with the headliner, Danzig, facing pressure from Soundgarden, the contender.
The audience wore its tribe membership in the form of strict all-black dress with tattoos or band T-shirts proclaiming allegiance to favorites like the Cro-Mags or Slayer.

We Can Afford to Fight Iraq
LEAD: While the cost of Operation Desert Shield will be high, it's nothing the U.S. can't bear.
And we can do this without placing a substantial additional burden on taxpayers and while still paring down the military.
But it will require some creative thinking about deployments as well as financial contributions from our allies.

LEAD: The 47 Americans in Iraq and occupied Kuwait who have been picked up and transferred to unknown locations are among a far larger group of foreigners, numbering in the hundreds, taken from hotels and residences and apparently placed in strategic military and industrial installations.

Topics of The Times;   Whistling a Whistle-Blower
LEAD: A lawyer named Michael Dowd helped prosecutors crack open the New York City corruption scandal in 1986 when he admitted paying kickbacks to city officials.
Mr.
Dowd has now been suspended from practicing law for five years.
His friends find the penalty excessive and fear it will discourage other whistle-blowers.


Gay Men's Chorus Audition
LEAD: The New York City Gay Men's Chorus will hold auditions for its 11th season on Sept. 11 and 12 at 7 P.M.
The 150-voice company will present concerts at Carnegie Hall and Alice Tully Hall during the 1990-91 season.
A prepared song is required, and applicants will undergo sight-reading and voice-placement tests.

Manhattan Man Is Arrested In Shooting of a Cabdriver
LEAD: A 27-year-old man was arrested yesterday in the shooting of a gypsy-cab driver, the police said.


Review/Music;   Bernstein Leads His Annual Tanglewood Concert
LEAD: Leonard Bernstein has long been the most intensely emotional, the most nakedly human of conductors.
That means all his concerts are suffused with a power of personality that focuses attention on himself.
In his youth, this insertion of personality could detract from the music; now, in his magisterial maturity - he turns 72 this Saturday - it usually augments the impact of his performances.


Messy Research Monkeys Vex Florida Keys
LEAD: More than a decade ago Bausch &amp; Lomb in a business venture put thousands of rhesus monkeys on two small deserted islands to breed.
For the State of Florida and residents of nearby keys, however, the breeding has been far too successful.


$300 Million Sale Of Carr-Gottstein
LEAD: An investment firm set up by a former partner in Gibbons, Green, van Amerongen, a prominent leveraged buyout firm, has acquired Alaska's largest food and drug wholesaler for $300 million.
The acquisition is the first by Leonard Green &amp; Partners, a private merchant bank set up to organize management buyouts.

Chip Manufacturer May Close Plant
LEAD: The National Semiconductor Corporation may close a computer chip plant and lay off as many as 2,000 employees in cost-cutting measures.
The company is considering closing its chip manufacturing plant in Puyallup, Wash., industry sources said.
The plant produces memory chips and logic semiconductors for supercomputers.

Venezuela Debt Accord
LEAD: Venezuela's public foreign debt will be lowered by more than 20 percent under an agreement reached with creditor banks, Venezuelan officials announced today.
The deal covers $20.5 billion of the nation's $26 billion of public-sector debt.
The country owes about $35 billion in public- and private-sector debt.

LEAD: A panel of experts told the White House today that smaller, simpler satellites that can monitor the Earth's climate should soon take priority over the huge Earth Observing System, an elaborate $30 billion array of six large satellites the space agency plans to place in orbit starting in 1997 or 1998.


Circle K Is Closing Unprofitable Units
LEAD: The Circle K Corporation has begun closing 201 unprofitable stores and will complete the job by the end of the month, Ray Cox, a company spokesman, said.


Chronicle
LEAD: QUEEN ELIZABETH II dusted off a rare honor and gave it to her baby sister yesterday.
The Queen invested PRINCESS MARGARET with the Insignia of the Royal Victorian Chain, as a personal honor on her 60th birthday.
ELIZABETH, THE QUEEN MOTHER, is the only other member of the royal family to have received the insignia.


European Bank Plan
LEAD: The European Community's executive body today endorsed a blueprint for forming tighter economic and monetary links that would include an American-style central bank in 1993.
It would also lead to creation of a single currency to be used throughout the dozen nations of the trading bloc.
The plan was offered to guide the nations at a special conference opening in December to make any needed changes in their founding Treaty of Rome to forge an economic and monetary union.

It has increasingly allowed its performers to stray into the early Romantic repertory, and occasionally beyond.
It has offered early-instrument concerts, and in recent years it has increasingly brought in outside orchestras to alternate with its resident ensemble.

Surgery Gives Man 2 Hearts
LEAD: A rare operation has left a man with two functioning human hearts and a clean bill of health, the University of Wisconsin Hospital said today.
Surgeons placed a human donor heart in William Rammer, 53 years old, of Kaukauna, on July 21 to supplement his diseased heart, said Dr.
Barry Fields, the hospital's chief heart transplant surgeon.

Efficient ARCO Gains From Its Price Freeze
LEAD: At an ARCO station on a busy corner in suburban Torrance, Calif., drivers are lining up this week to buy regular unleaded gasoline for $1.13 a gallon - 8 cents less than at the Exxon station across the street.
Throughout the West, people have been flocking to other ARCO stations to buy gasoline at prices 4 to 12 cents below those of competing stations.

Everything about this middle-class enclave seems typical of life in a Pocono Mountain resort except for one thing: nearly all the guests are gay.

Dick Strout's Two Lives
LEAD: In every sense, Richard L. Strout stood out in the innumerable press conferences he attended during his six decades as a Washington reporter.
Nobody could miss this six-footer with a bemused expression and guardsman's mustache.
Besides that, Mr.
Strout, who died Sunday at the age of 92, was a singular figure who led a dual journalistic existence and came to occupy an unusual niche in the nation's capital.

Close to Home
LEAD: THIS month I will have lived in my present home for 11 years.

From Tragedy to Absurdity With Finland's Prolific Upstart
Seventeen guys in dark glasses are playing electric guitars and keyboards on the stage of a small club in Finland.
All of these men are named Frank, and some of them have died earlier in the film, ''Calamari Union,'' which is not about a rock band at all, but about the Franks' meandering attempts to get to the other side of Helsinki.
Yet here they are, alive and singing what could be the director Aki Kaurismaki's anthem: ''Bad boys are coming to break all your toys.''
Mr.
Kaurismaki, who has written and directed eight mischievous, society-tweaking films in the last seven years, is the highly successful bad boy of Finnish cinema.
In fact, he and his older brother Mika almost are the Finnish cinema; each directs, and together they produce their own works and distribute foreign films.
Now Aki Kaurismaki's films are arriving in the United States in one great wave, and they demonstrate that, at the age of 33, he is more than a prolific upstart or a local curiosity; he is an original and commanding talent among international film makers.

LEAD: A militant environmentalist drowned in Keauhou Bay on Tuesday shortly after leading a flotilla of boats and surfboards in an anti-geothermal protest, the police said.

Errol Ishimine said.
Mr.
Cate, a Hilo High School teacher, was protesting state-backed plans for geothermal energy plants in Wao Kele O Puna Rainforest.

LEAD: WOODEN windowsills are designed to shed moisture, but unless they are regularly painted or waterproofed, snow and rain can penetrate them during long periods of bad weather.

Big Board Seat Is Sold
LEAD: The price of a seat on the New York Stock Exchange has fallen to a six-year low with the purchase yesterday of a seat for $301,000.
That price is the lowest since 1984 and a decline of $9,000 from the previous sale price of $310,000 on Monday, exchange officials said.
The record price for a seat, $1.15 million, was paid in 1987, before the stock market crashed that year.

Money Fund Assets Up
LEAD: The assets of the nation's 520 money market mutual funds increased $6.22 billion, to $408 billion, for the week that ended on Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.
At the 162 institutional funds, assets rose $1.15 billion, to $99.48 billion.
The assets of the 253 general-purpose funds were up $2.40 billion, to $142.45 billion.

LEAD: In a blistering opinion, a Federal judge today dismissed the lawsuit brought by Charles H. Keating Jr. to regain control of the failed Lincoln Savings and Loan Association.
The judge said that the Government seizure of Lincoln was ''fully justified'' and that the actions of Mr.
Keating and his associates amounted to a ''looting'' of the institution.

Review/Film;   Balladlike Wartime Tale Of Maturing
LEAD: Anne Wheeler's ''Bye Bye Blues'' has the tone and texture of a dreamy pop ballad from World War II spun out over nearly two hours.
Reflecting the wide-open spaces of western Canada where most of it was shot, the slow-moving, beautifully photographed film takes its time in telling the story of a young woman who finds self-sufficiency as a band singer during World War II while her husband is a prisoner of the Japanese.

Hussein's remarks, in Arabic, were translated by an Iraqi interpreter; some sections were inaudible.
The broadcast was recorded by The New York Times from Cable News Network.


U.S. Bank Quits Bahrain
LEAD: The Bank of America said on Wednesday that it was closing its operations in Bahrain but stressed that the Persian Gulf crisis had not been a major factor in the decision. ''We are winding down our Bahrain operations as a result of a continuing review of the bank's international strategy for business,'' said Zakir Mahmoud, a regional vice president.

LEAD:
Markets


Confrontation in the Gulf;   Shrinking Supplies of Food Evident in Iraq, Reports Say
LEAD: While the American-led military buildup in Saudi Arabia continues, another weapon, the withholding of food for Iraq under the United Nations trade embargo, is beginning to cause hardship, a variety of reports from officials of Western governments and food experts say.


Another Parting for Steinbrenner
LEAD: For all the elements of the agreement that removed him from the daily operations of the Yankees, George Steinbrenner was most concerned that the public understood he was neither ''banned,'' ''suspended'' nor put on any kind of probation.


Corrections
LEAD: The Advertising column of Business Day on Aug. 7 referred incorrectly to the origins of the Old Joe advertising campaign for Camel cigarettes.
The ''smooth character'' cartoon, the concept for the campaign, was created for the R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company by Trone Advertising in Greensboro, N.C.; the campaign was later developed by McCann-Erickson Worldwide.


T. W. McMahon, 69, Former Bank Executive
LEAD: Thomas W. McMahon Jr., a former executive at the Chase Manhattan Bank, died yesterday at Union (N.J.) Hospital.
He was 69 years old and lived in Union.


Vehicle Sales Drop By 4.7%
LEAD: Sales of domestically built cars and light trucks fell 4.7 percent in mid-August, a decline that analysts attributed to record high sales a year ago.


First Catch of Atlantic Salmon Documented in Alaska Water
LEAD: Biologists have documented the first catch of an Atlantic salmon in Alaska waters, raising fears that escaped fish from commercial farms will introduce diseases dangerous to the state's valuable native species.


3,000 West African Troops Leave For Liberia to Enforce Cease-Fire
LEAD: Six ships carrying 3,000 West African soldiers sailed from here today to enforce a cease-fire in Liberia, where a 10,000-man rebel army has rejected a proposed truce.

LEAD: While the Mets sleepwalk through the West, the Kid and the Mex are looking better and better, in retrospect.

LEAD: Stump Merrill, the manager of the Yankees, said yesterday that he had full confidence in the ability of Dave Righetti, the left-handed closer who will become a free agent at the end of the season, and that he couldn't or wouldn't imagine a bullpen without him next season.

Washington Talk;   How Old Votes Become New Political Liabilities
LEAD: Recorded votes in Congress have a habit of becoming campaign nightmares.
To avoid them, lawmakers often jockey for voice votes on controversial legislation, so as not to have to risk going on the record.

HORSE RACING: Notebook;   Best 2-Year-Olds May Bi in Hiding
LEAD: Talented 2-year-olds have been so slow to emerge this year that it seems possible the eventual champion juvenile has yet to make his debut.
It is more comforting to think that the best are yet to run than to pronounce the crop a dull one already, and there is a theory to support that notion.

LEAD: The regional airline subsidiary of the AMR Corporation will become the largest operator of ATR aircraft in the world with its order this week for $1 billion worth of aircraft.


Review/Art;   Long Island Art, a Refuge From the Whirl
LEAD: August comes but once a year to Long Island, and that may be as much as anyone can take.
The frantic whir of relaxation and hand-to-hand socializing fills the air, and the pesto intake skyrockets.
For those who need a break from the work of not working, the area's museums are one option.
They are generally cool, calm, a little underpopulated and, even better, the season's crop of summer exhibitions is unusually fine.


U.S. Already in a Recession, More Than 60 Percent Say
LEAD: Americans have turned decidedly sour about the state of the economy, with the perception that the country is in a recession now shared by 6 out of 10 of them, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll.

LEAD: Of all this summer's movies, ''Darkman'' is the one aimed most directly at the audience for ''Batman.'' CHRONICLE
LEAD: In a ceremony yesterday in Canberra, SIR GEOFFREY HOWE, the Deputy Prime Minister of Britain, handed over Australia's birth certificate, Reuters reported.
The document, with its faded writing on vellum, officially ended Australia's status as a British colony in 1901 and recognized it as a nation.
The country is a member of the Commonwealth.

The shares of Mack Trucks fell by $1.125 each today, to $5.25, in over-the-counter trading.

Activated Reservists Report for Gulf Duty
LEAD: As the call-up of reservists began, the Pentagon yesterday discarded a policy that had prohibited journalists from publishing or broadcasting the names and hometowns of enlisted men and women stationed in the Persian Gulf region.

LEAD: The Mets finally found their sense of timing tonight when they edged the Los Angeles Dodgers, 3-2, on the powerful pitching by Dwight Gooden and two home runs by Kevin McReynolds, and moved to within three games of the first-place Pittsburgh Pirates in the National League East.


Mortgage Rates Rise
LEAD: Fixed-rate mortgages averaged 10.29 percent this week, up from 10.05 percent last week, according to a national survey released today by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation.
It was the highest level since a similar 10.29 percent rate was posted last June 1.
On one-year adjustable rate mortgages, lenders were asking an average initial rate of 8.36 percent, up from 8.31 percent last week.


AN IRISH HOSTAGE FREED IN LEBANON
LEAD: An Irish hostage held for more than four years in Lebanon was released Friday night, in what could be a step by Iran's Islamic Government toward warmer relations with the West.


Uncovered Short Sales Decline 0.5% on Nasdaq
LEAD: The National Association of Securities Dealers reported yesterday that the number of shares sold short and not yet covered - or ''short interest'' - fell one-half of 1 percent for actively traded over-the-counter securities in its national market system for the four weeks that ended in mid-August.
The National Association of Securities Dealers reported yesterday that the number of shares sold short and not yet covered - or ''short interest'' - fell one-half of 1 percent for actively traded over-the-counter securities in its national market system for the four weeks that ended in mid-August.
A total of 255.5 million shares were held short and not yet covered in mid-August, the association said, compared with a revised total of 256.9 million in the period that ended in mid-July.
The August activity represents short selling in 2,335 stocks; in July the short selling was spread among 2,299 issues.
Short-sellers expect a stock's price to decline, so they sell borrowed stock in anticipation of buying back an equal number of shares later at a lower price, thereby making a profit.
Views of Analysts Differ
Some traders and analysts consider a large short position to be bearish, because it presumably represents a strong cumulative belief that the market will turn down.
Under this reasoning, a large jump in the position would also be bearish.

LEAD: In the first round of reserve call-ups, the Air Force activated units today in six states to augment flight crews shuttling cargo and equipment to the Persian Gulf region.

LEAD: Arizona's ban on prisoners' wearing beards has been upheld by a Federal appeals court over the objection of two Orthodox Jewish prisoners who contended that the policy discriminated against them.

Bridge
LEAD: A basic principle of bidding that is learned by beginners and observed quite strictly by experts is this: If your partner shows a five-card major suit and you have three-card support, you must show it, either immediately or on the next round, unless perhaps you uncover a good fit elsewhere.

LEAD: These are not easy times for the people charged with looking after Lenin's good name.
His theories are falling into disrepute, his historic role is being re-examined and now, in a half dozen cities around the Soviet Union, his statues are being dismantled, not by bands of hooligans but by local city councils.


Corrections
LEAD: An obituary of Pearl Bailey in some editions last Saturday and some on Sunday referred incompletely to her co-stars in the Broadway musical ''Hello, Dolly!,'' and a correction in this space on Tuesday misidentified the actor with whom she first performed the role.
Cab Calloway starred with Miss Bailey in a 1967 staging of the musical, and Billy Daniels appeared with her in a 1975 revival.


Syrian Gains Are Seen In the Shift Toward U.S.
LEAD: What has led President Hafez al-Assad of Syria, long viewed in the West as an intractable adversary, to align his nation with the United States in the Persian Gulf crisis?


The Oasis Crowd
LEAD: He had been the first to get into Baghdad.
That's why they called him Koppel of Arabia.
The name had weight.
Before he was Koppel of Arabia he had been just another Ted.


Corrections
LEAD: A report in the Pop Life column on Wednesday about the Neville Brothers misinterpreted a reference to Angola in ''Sons and Daughters,'' a poem by Art Neville that is on the group's new album, ''Brother's Keeper.'' The reference is to the Louisiana State Penitentiary at Angola, La., not to the African country.


RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:
LITTLE LEAGUE
Shippensburg Reaches Semifinals
Bob Shannon struck out 14 batters and Shippensburg, Pa., clung to the lead it took two days earlier to advance to the semifinals of the rain-interrupted Little League World Series yesterday with a 3-1 victory over Mobile, Ala., at Williamsport, Pa.


Offering by Sun May Be Halted
LEAD: Sun Microsystems Inc. said today that it might not proceed with previously announced plans for a stock offering because the price of its stock had declined as a result of the selloff on the stock market amid the Persian Gulf crisis.


U.N. Reviews Proposal
LEAD: The 15 members of the Security Council opened formal consultations today on a proposed resolution that would allow countries to halt ships suspected of violating the trade embargo against Iraq.


Gift to Regan Revives Debate on Business Donations
LEAD: Reports this week that the State Comptroller had invested state money on the advice of consultants who had given money to his campaign have raised questions again about the influence of campaign contributions in government decisions.


Data General To Cut 2,000
LEAD: The Data General Corporation said it would lay off more than 2,000 workers, or 4.9 percent of its work force, in the next several weeks.


Sematech Gains In Chip-Making
LEAD: Officials at Sematech, the private industry and Federal Government chip-making consortium, said yesterday that they were now making semiconductor chips with half-micron-wide circuit lines on American-made equipment.

LEAD: The General Electric Company said today that it would cut more jobs because of a shrinking military budget.

LEAD: Early in Chuck Norris's new film, ''Delta Force 2,'' the star, who portrays an Army colonel named Scott McCoy, casually beats up some skinhead bullies who have been menacing the owner of a Chinese restaurant.
When congratulated on winning the fight, he remarks: ''I didn't fight.
I gave a motivational seminar.

LEAD: A judge ruled today that the British heavy-metal band Judas Priest was not responsible for the deaths of two youths who committed suicide after listening to the group's album ''Stained Class.''


World Talks on Air Fares
LEAD: Major airlines will meet next week to discuss international fare increases in response to soaring fuel prices caused by the Persian Gulf crisis, an industry association said today.


Officer Is Cut in Face by Disturbed Woman
LEAD: An emotionally disturbed woman jabbed a broken bottle into the face of a police officer in Harlem yesterday, slashing his cheek, the police said.

LEAD: Harold Masursky, the former chief scientist of the United States Geological Survey's Center of Astrogeology and a leader in lunar and planetary exploration, died yesterday at his home in Flagstaff, Ariz.
He was 66 years old.

Telescope Construction Cleared Over Objections
LEAD: The United States Forest Service has authorized the University of Arizona to build three telescopes on Mount Graham after determining that the project's possible harm to an endangered subspecies of squirrel had been studied sufficiently.


Red Sox Edge Blue Jays in Ninth
LEAD: Mike Marshall's run-scoring single in the ninth inning broke a scoreless tie and the Boston Red Sox beat Toronto, 2-0, tonight to take a two-game lead over the Blue Jays in the American League East.


Going Private Is a Public Affair
LEAD: Under the plan of the Mexican Government to privatize its huge national telephone company, the winning bidder will have to agree to increase the number of household phone lines from 5 million to 10 million over the next four years; reduce installation time from 18 months to 6, and shrink the wait for a dial tone from 30 seconds to under 10.


Leading Executive and 2 in Family Are Killed in Boston Plane Crash
LEAD: A development company executive and his wife who were flying their daughter to meet a commercial flight at Logan International Airport crashed their twin-engine private airplane into a crowded residential neighborhood here today, setting two houses on fire.
The three people on the plane all died in the crash.


CHRONICLE
LEAD: Prime Minister MICHAEL MANLEY of Jamaica was released from a Manhattan hospital yesterday, nine days after doctors removed a benign growth from his prostate.


Putting Up Office Tower, Women Break Sex Barrier
LEAD: Vickie Barnes is putting up a 27-story glass and granite office building here with 43 other women and about 600 men.
An apprentice carpenter, she earns $13.62 an hour, enough to support herself and her 12-year-old daughter.


Wrong Fix for Public Schools
LEAD: Oregon's citizens are now considering a state constitutional amendment that would give parents more flexibility to choose schools.
While choice is to be encouraged, the Oregon plan would create a kind of free market among public, private and religious schools.
That's dubious public policy.


Guilty Plea in '88 Rampage
LEAD: A Bronx teen-ager pleaded guilty yesterday in State Supreme Court in the Bronx to eight robbery and burglary charges stemming from his part in murder, rape and robbery by five young men two years ago.
The teen-ager, Brandon Campos, who was 15 at the time, admitted helping to loot an apartment in Brooklyn after a group of companions strangled a construction foreman in the Bronx.


CHEMICAL ACCIDENT IN URALS HURTS 110
LEAD: An explosion at a chemical factory injured more than 100 people and polluted the drinking water of the city of Ufa in the Ural mountains, the Soviet press agency Tass said today.


To Insure Toy Safety, U.S. Shifts Its Attack
LEAD: The Federal Government shifted its strategy on toy safety this week, filing lawsuits against seven major companies in the United States that distribute or sell imported toys.


Man Suffocates As Intruders Hold a Party
LEAD: Four people, three of them teen-agers, were charged yesterday with murdering a mentally retarded man who suffocated inside a closet while they caroused in his Bronx apartment for nearly six days and sold his belongings, the police said.


500 Are Detained in Burmese Capital
LEAD: About 500 people have been detained for questioning by the military authorities in the last two weeks in the capital of Myanmar, formerly Burma, diplomats said today.


Patents;   Cork Has 2 Chambers To Purify Champagne
LEAD: Ernest Gladstone, a retired teacher in Brooklyn, has patented a two-chambered cork that he says makes it possible to purify champagne without exposing it to the air.


Arts Appeal Is Rejected
LEAD: The National Endowment for the Arts has rejected a request for an administrative appeal of the agency's decision last June to deny grants to four performance artists whose work has strong sexual content.


2 Court Rulings Prevent Release Of Mexican Doctor Held by U.S.
LEAD: A pair of court rulings in the last two days seem to assure that a Mexican doctor charged in the slaying of an American drug agent will remain in Federal custody while the Government pursues its appeal of a judge's order that he be returned to Mexico.


At Payola Trial, Primer on Forms and Mechanics
LEAD: Packets of cocaine hidden in audiocassette cases.
Thousands of dollars handed over furtively in the men's room of Hollywood restaurants.
Record album jackets stuffed with cash and shipped by Federal Express to radio station executives.


USAir Plans More Layoffs
LEAD: USAir Group Inc., which had already announced layoffs of more than 1,500 workers this month, said yesterday that it planned to cut another 2,100 jobs by the end of the year.
The latest reduction amounts to about 4 percent of the work force of the airline company, which is based in Arlington, Va.

LEAD: To the Editor:


COMPANY BRIEFS
LEAD: *
Amerifirst Bank, Miami, said it would eliminate 50 staff and management positions and would decrease its asset size.


Yankees Start Looking to Future
LEAD: In the final weeks of their dry season, the Yankees seem ready to begin laying more groundwork for the future.
They are talking with other clubs about trades, pondering the possibility of moving veterans and looking closely at prospects who might offer help as early as next summer.
They are also still losing.


Soviets Verify Big Oil Find
LEAD: The Soviet Union confirmed today that it had found two oilfields and the world's biggest offshore gas field in the Barents Sea, the scene of costly but until now fruitless exploration efforts in recent years.


2 Soviet Athletes Out
LEAD: Two female Soviet athletes - the former world high-jump champion Tamara Bykova and the heptathlete Larisa Nikitina - have been suspended for using banned drugs at the Goodwill Games last month in Seattle and will miss next week's European championships, the Soviet Athletics Federation said in Moscow yesterday.


Poles Tell of Americans Held at Iraq Chemical Plant
LEAD: Some Americans in Iraq are being held at a chemical factory near the Syrian border that also produces enriched uranium, according to Polish workers who witnessed the arrival of the hostages.


G.M. Sets Incentive Offer On Many of Its 1991 Models
LEAD: In a move that analysts said amounted to a concession that its new cars and trucks may be priced too high in a soft market, the General Motors Corporation said today that it was offering incentives on many of its 1991 models, including several that go on sale this month for the first time.


Convicted Northwest Pilots Plead Guilty to a 2d Charge
LEAD: Two of the three members of a Northwest Airlines crew who were convicted in a Federal court this week of flying their plane and its 73 passengers while drunk have pleaded guilty to a second charge growing out of the incident.

LEAD: A picture on the Law page yesterday with an article about volunteer prosecutors was published in error.


Football;   After Jets Tonight, Will There Be a Tomorrow?
LEAD: When the Giants play the Jets on Saturday night in the teams' annual preseason game at Giants Stadium, it may be the last or almost the last hurrah for one or both of the Giants' recent running-back heroes.

LEAD: Top American military commanders here are recommending that Washington respond to any Iraqi invasion of Saudi Arabia with a punishing, all-out attack against Iraqi military forces and installations.


Baxter Is Selling Stake in Genetics
LEAD: Baxter International Inc., the Deerfield, Ill., hospital supply concern, said it intends to sell its 7.3 percent stake in Genetics Institute Inc., a biotechnology concern in Cambridge, Mass.


Corrections
LEAD: A listing of museum hours in Weekend yesterday with articles about museums near Manhattan misstated the visiting days and the admission policy for the Newark Museum.
It is open from noon to 5 P.M.
Wednesday to Sunday, not on Tuesdays.
Admission is free, not $1.


Bucket Danger Warning
LEAD: Warning that household buckets pose a serious drowning threat to small children, Government and industry are making available labels alerting the public to the hazard.


G.N.P. Rate For 2d Period A Weak 1.2%
LEAD: In what many analysts see as a further sign of a weakened economy, the Government confirmed today that growth was listless even before the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait jolted oil prices.


John M. Karns Jr., 62, Illinois Appeals Judge
LEAD: John Marshall Karns Jr., a retired Justice of the Illinois Appellate Court, died Wednesday at Memorial Hospital in Belleville, Ill.
He was 62 years old and lived in Belleville.
His wife, Joan, said he died of lung cancer.


BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, AUGUST, 25, 1990
LEAD: The Economy


Tadzhikstan Declares Sovereignty
LEAD: The Soviet Central Asian republic of Tadzhikistan declared sovereignty today, becoming the 13th of the 15 Soviet republics to make some move toward greater autonomy, a news service reported.


Patents;   Simplifying the Output Of a Class of Compounds
LEAD: Researchers at the Celgene Corporation in Warren, N.J., obtained patent approval this week for a method of determining whether molecules are, in effect, left-handed or right-handed.


Dirty Minds, or Little Minds?
LEAD: There is a scene in Shakespeare's ''Henry the Fifth'' in which Katharine, the French princess, asks someone described as ''an old Gentlewoman'' for an English lesson.
The ensuing instructions, in schoolgirl French, are funny - and as anyone knows who has seen them performed with vivid gestures in Kenneth Branagh's movie version of the play, even ribald - a dazzling exercise in double entendre, even to one who doesn't grasp all the dialogue.


Hong Kong Outlook
LEAD: The Government of Hong Kong today cut its estimate of economic growth for the year and said conditions could deteriorate further, adding that a slowdown seemed likely even before the Persian Gulf crisis.


Corrections
LEAD: A headline yesterday about a New York Times/CBS News Poll on Americans' view of the economy referred incorrectly in some copies to the segment who believe the nation is now in a recession.
It was slightly more than 6 in 10, not ''nearly.''


Showing His Old Form, McEnroe Beats Gilbert
LEAD: For at least one satisfying match, on center court here in the quarterfinals of the Norstar Bank Hamlet Challenge Cup today, the 31-year-old John McEnroe looked like the McEnroe of old, serving convincingly, returning the ball effectively and volleying with authority.


Jefferey Bucholtz, Designer of Homes And Apartments, 33
LEAD: Jefferey D. Bucholtz, an architectural designer, died Thursday at the Davies Medical Center in San Francisco.
He was 33 years old.
Michael Goldblum, a colleague of his, said he had died of AIDS.


The World v. Saddam Hussein
LEAD: Cornered and desperate, Saddam Hussein now lashes out against diplomacy itself.
His troops lawlessly threaten foreign embassies in Kuwait while his regime detains U.S. diplomats and dependents who were promised a safe exit from Baghdad.
The most telling condemnation comes from Moscow, Iraq's longtime ally.

For a related street fair, Madison Avenue will be closed from 23d to 26th Streets from 3 P.M. to 8 P.M.

LEAD: B. DON MAGNESS, chairman of the Miss Texas Scholarship Pageant for 20 years, resigned Thursday night after reports of impropriety.
He told the pageant's board of directors that he was unfairly depicted in a Life magazine article as a dirty old man who made lewd comments to pageant contestants.

LEAD: Six ships carrying 3,000 West African soldiers arrived off Monrovia today, but did not attempt to dock as gunfire erupted in the port of the Liberian capital.

Southwest Boomed in 80's, Census Finds
LEAD: The five states whose deserts and canyons form the vast expanse of the American Southwest have seen some of the nation's sharpest increases in population in the last decade, preliminary 1990 census figures show.
A boom in the Las Vegas area raised Nevada's population by nearly 50 percent.


Pretoria Takes Broad Steps To End Factional Fighting
LEAD: In a crackdown on factional bloodletting that has claimed more than 500 lives in 11 days, South African authorities today designated 27 black townships ''unrest areas'' and gave the police wide powers to arrest and search people without warrant and to seize weapons.


Sergei Dovlatov, 48, Soviet Emigre Who Wrote About His Homeland
LEAD: Sergei Dovlatov, a leading Soviet emigre writer noted for the laconic irony and graceful irreverence of his stories about his homeland, died of heart failure yesterday at Coney Island Hospital in Brooklyn.
He was 48 years old.


Roosevelt Watson, A Freed Defendant In 70's Slaying Case
LEAD: Roosevelt Watson, one of five black youths who won dismissal of murder charges in a widely publicized case in rural Dawson, Ga., in the mid-1970's, died Tuesday at his home in Albany, Ga.
He was 34 years old.


Oil May Affect Price of Tires
LEAD: Further jumps in crude oil prices could push up retail prices of American-made tires in coming months, a trade official of a rubber trade group said today.


Congress Gets Bush Pay Plan
LEAD: President Bush today sent Congress his recommendation that Federal employees receive a 3.5 percent pay rise on Jan. 1.
Congress has until the end of September to approve the plan or substitute its own.
The House has approved a 4.1 percent raise.
The President's advisers had recommended raises of 22 percent to 40 percent to keep Civil Service pay abreast of salaries in the private sector.

Currency;   Pressure on the Dollar
LEAD: Another week and another milestone for the dollar.
First, the dollar set a new low against the German mark on Aug. 14.
Then, last Thursday, it fell to a low against the Swiss franc, 1.2560, and set another low aganst the mark, 1.5444.
At the same time, the weary dollar fell further against the three popular high-yield currencies that are backed by high interest rates and are also net energy exporters, making them less vulnerable to the Persian Gulf crisis.

Tech Notes;   Getting Photographs From Medical Imaging
LEAD: First there was medical imaging - electronic devices that produce video pictures of structures deep within the body using X-rays, sound waves or magnetic resonance techniques.
Now there is a way to directly convert these electronic images into high-quality, instant, black and white photographs printed on film.

LEAD: This year the United States Open promises to be a quieter tournament than usual: along with the temporary banishment of La Guardia Airport's jet stream from the sultry skies above Flushing Meadows, there is the absence of a contender for a 1990 Grand Slam on both sides of the draw.


Talking: Oil Tanks;   New York's New Rules On Storage
LEAD: Until recently, people with free-standing fuel-oil storage tanks in their basements or beside their houses did not have to worry about rules designed to avoid environmental contamination.
Spills from these above-ground tanks are not likely to seep into ground water or waterways because even a small leak is immediately visible and can be cleaned up before becoming an environmental hazard.

LEAD: FORSAKING friends, family and familiar surroundings, four New Jersey residents packed their bags and headed north to the White Mountains of New Hampshire to take part in the actor's annual rite of passage known as summer theater.


One Hat Too Many
LEAD: Elected officials are supposed to put the public good ahead of narrow partisan interests.
That is the common-sense reasoning behind a provision in New York City's new Charter that bars key officeholders from holding party jobs.
But a disappointing court decision now casts doubt on whether that ban against political moonlighting can be enforced.

Thrown Out
LEAD: The lawsuit brought by Charles H. Keating Jr. to regain control of the failed Lincoln Savings and Loan Associaton bounced like a bad check last week.
In what Federal officials called ''an extremely important victory,'' a Federal judge dismissed Mr.
Keating's suit, accused him and other Lincoln executives of pillaging the Arizona institution and said the Government was ''fully justified'' in taking over Lincoln last year.


33 Are Hurt at a Rap Concert
LEAD: About 40 youths scaled gates at an amphitheater during a concert by the rap group Public Enemy on Friday night and randomly assaulted concert-goers and security guards, the police said.
Thirty people were treated for minor injuries at first aid stations and three others were treated at a hospital, the police said.

Ground Covers Go Beyond Pachysandra
LEAD: SOMETIMES ground covers other than grass are the best solution to protect bare earth.
If soil is not covered with something, weeds move in rapidly.
The goal is to plant cover that will establish itself quickly.
This is especially true for areas like slopes or heavily shaded patches under mature trees.

State Stewards Guard Adirondacks' Alpine Flora
LEAD: Alix Cleveland did not think that climbing to the top could become so routine.
But this summer, as one of New York State's first ''summit stewards,'' she climbs 5,344-foot Mount Marcy five days a week.


Pastimes;   Around the Garden
LEAD: For This Week: Plan for next spring's flower garden; mail orders for hardy bulbs.
Feed 'mums to support oncoming bloom.
Last call to dig and divide bearded iris.
Keep after weeds.
Repair weak, established lawns and seed or sod new ones.
Spray rosebushes with a fungicide to protect them from black spot.


New Yorkers, etc.
LEAD: Visualize a room with plenty of capacious, comfortable, welcoming sofas and chairs, not all of them occupied.
In this room there are, too, a few straight-back chairs and someone is sitting in one of them.
Someone with a bad back?
Wrong guess.
This person has a wonderful, healthy, much-to-be envied back.


A Travel Nut's Library
LEAD: Old travel books occupy so many shelves in my apartment that a visitor might take me to be some kind of antiquarian nut.
I am merely a travel nut, and the books are artifacts of that hobby.
Just looking at their sonorous titles (''Forbidden Sands,'' ''Monsoon Seas,'' ''Dead Cities and Forgotten Tribes,'' ''They Reigned in Mandalay''), I am taken back to places in many parts of the world that I traveled far to see.


Streetscapes: 316 East 59th Street;   New Role for 'Gnomes' Home'
LEAD: Storefront design bubbled with vitality in the 1920's and early 30's as small shops sought an identity amid a rising group of chain operations and department stores.

Coming To America...And Staying
LEAD: I ARRIVED in the United States on Sept. 5, 1965.
I had come as a foreign student in a Ph.D. program at a major American university and intended to return to India, my native land, after obtaining a doctorate.
I stayed on to enjoy the freedom, an organized way of life and the creature comforts that were not available to me in my old country.


Discovered Along the Flowered-Silk Route
LEAD: When it comes to antiques, whether they be furniture or textiles, their history bespeaks a world of fashion and a way of life that affected the owners as well as the makers.
But rare is the exhibition of antiques that takes this factor into account; if an exhibition does, objects appreciated for their beauty alone can also tell a story of commerce.


Corrections
LEAD: An article on Aug. 5 about Pullman, Ill., rendered the name of the writer incorrectly and misstated his hometown.
It was written by Karl Zimmermann, who now lives in Norwood, N.J.


Connecticut Q&amp;A: Gaetano Ferro;   Contemplating Divorce? 'Be Reasonable.'
LEAD: CHANGES in society and in the law have brought changes in divorce, says Gaetano Ferro, a lawyer in Westport.
Reasons for divorce as well as settlements and child-custody arrangements are changing, he said, yet many people are still dissatisfied with the process of of dissolving a marriage.

LEAD: Gov.
Mario M. Cuomo has been campaigning vigorously across the state.
He has political advertisements on the radio.

LEAD: As jurors in New York City weighed the fate of three teen-agers charged with the rape and beating of a Central Park jogger, a jury 300 miles to the northwest heard the gruesome details of an attack on another jogger raped and left to die.


Renting A Cotswolds Cottage
LEAD: For years I had wanted to rent a cottage in the English countryside.
I had a clear, if idealized, notion of my requirements: a thatched-roof cottage in a sleepy English village; a rustic stone fence bordering pastures and meadows; honeysuckle and roses by the front door; a pub just a short walk down the lane, and easy access to London should all the above ever become boring.

An Irish 'Toy House' For Two (or More)
LEAD: For a simple, undemanding and not-too-foreign week removed from the ruts of home and disciplines of office, renting a cottage in Ireland seemed ideal.
After all, Ireland is about as close as Europe gets to America, the people speak our language, and my wife and I personally share, across uncertain generations, elements of the culture.

For an Egyptian Father, The Joy of Sons' Escape
LEAD: Outside the Mourci cafe on a dusty Cairo back street on Friday, Mohammed Gamal was all smiles.
In a telephone call from Nuweiba, a port on the Sinai peninsula, he had learned that his five sons had returned safely to Egypt on a ferry from Jordan, after a grueling 1,200-mile bus journey from Kuwait.

Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number.
We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

Pitfalls for the Obliging Gofer
LEAD: I'm in London standing in Harrods lower-level market - not the fabled Food Halls that take up maybe a quarter of the ground floor, but the much less touristy lower-level market.
I'm staring in dismay at the tea display, which, to my eye, can be no less than 20 feet wide and 6 feet high.


Correction
LEAD: Because of an editing error, a review on Aug. 5 of A. N. Wilson's ''Eminent Victorians'' misidentified one of the subjects of Lytton Strachey's 1918 book of the same title.
He was Thomas Arnold, the educator, not his son Matthew Arnold, the poet and critic.


Pastimes;   Stamps
LEAD: It used to be that no one would submit a game for the brilliancy prize if he knew that his opponent had a drawing line.
The ideal was for the attack to feature a string of inescapable combinations leading to victory. ''But you cannot restrict yourself that way anymore,'' said the Oakland grandmaster Nick De Firmian.


Food;   THE CAPER CHASE
LEAD: Traveling to Aguilas in the Southeastern corner of Spain to learn how the caper finds its way from plant to table, I came away knowing how, but wondering why.
Even as a lifelong fan who values the caper's sharp salinity in dishes of all sorts, I marveled, once again, at the trouble people go to for this tiny culinary adornment.

Pretoria's Forces Impose Tense Peace in Towns
LEAD: The battles have ebbed today in these bleak townships on South Africa's gold-mining reef, where more than 500 people have died.
And the lines of competing black factions have been frozen in place by a deployment of the police and soldiers in trucks intended for bush warfare and now imposing a kind of civilian peace.


Correction
LEAD: A picture caption in The Times Magazine on July 29 with an article about Detroit misidentified a downtown street that appeared deserted in the early evening.
It is John R Street, not Brush Street.

COMPANIES
More on the Trump Saga
For savings and loan bailouts, the Resolution Trust Corporation must approve.
For Trump bailouts, it takes the New Jersey Casino Control Commission.
On Tuesday, the commission approved Donald J. Trump's package of $65 million in new bank loans, with casinos as collateral.

Pastimes;   Bridge
LEAD: Like most other aspects of life in the Soviet Union, bridge has been affected by perestroika.
The number of tournament players in Moscow has more than doubled in the past year from 400 to 1,000.
The progression is expected to continue.

Righteous Rock: Issues You Can Dance To
LEAD: It used to be easy to spot the rockers with good intentions.
They had earnest expressions and dull wardrobes, and they put across their messages with an almost puritanical disdain for embellishment, clutching acoustic guitars as talismans of sincerity.
A serious song might allow itself a singalong chorus, but it couldn't be seductive or sensual - that might seem too frivolous for important subjects.

The Stars of Autumn
LEAD: Legs have it.
The short skirts, leggings, jodhpurs and snug boots that are everywhere prove it.
So do the taut bodysuits, dark or dazzling with patterns.
Fabrics laced with stretch certainly have it, as do those that smolder to the touch - velvet, cashmere, spongy tweeds, mohairs and meltons.
And sequins, paillettes and false gem stones never lost it.


Q and A
LEAD:
Right to Co-op Documents
Question: I am a real estate broker specializing in residential loft sales.
The lawyer of a client who is interested in a co-op requested access to the financial records but the board refused to comply.
Doesn't Section 624 of the New York Business Corporation Law gives prospective buyers the right to see these documents?

The family has cried foul.

Ground Covers Go Beyond Pachysandra
LEAD: SOMETIMES ground covers other than grass are the best solution to protect bare earth.
If soil is not covered with something, weeds move in rapidly.
The goal is to plant cover that will establish itself quickly.
This is especially true for areas like slopes or heavily shaded patches under mature trees.

IN SHORT: FICTION
LEAD:
MEXICAN BOLERO.
By Angeles Mastretta.
Translated by Ann Wright. (Viking, $19.95.) The Mexican journalist Angeles Mastretta's debut novel is part of Latin America's literature of political repression: in ''Mexican Bolero,'' a young girl loses her innocence while corrupt politicians, generals, labor leaders and peasant bosses jockey for power in the years after the Mexican Revolution of 1911.

How to Install a Dimmer Switch
LEAD: DIMMER switches allow adjusting lighting levels; they also save energy and extend the lives of light bulbs.
Most often, dimmer switches are used for controlling incandescent ceiling lights.
Installing one is easy.
The job involves simply replacing the conventional wall switch with the dimmer.

England

Ground Covers Go Beyond Pachysandra
LEAD: SOMETIMES ground covers other than grass are the best solution to protect bare earth.
If soil is not covered with something, weeds move in rapidly.
The goal is to plant cover that will establish itself quickly.
This is especially true for areas like slopes or heavily shaded patches under mature trees.

Citizens arming themselves.
Racial tensions at a boil.
Critics bewailing a ''carnival of murder.'' So it went in the New York City of the 1860's.
Today's alarming crime rate and fearful populace have clear parallels in earlier eras of city history, although historians say they have to go back to the 19th century and earlier to find them.

LEAD: The United States and Japan have already traded places in the global financial hierarchy.

How to Install a Dimmer Switch
LEAD: DIMMER switches allow adjusting lighting levels; they also save energy and extend the lives of light bulbs.
Most often, dimmer switches are used for controlling incandescent ceiling lights.
Installing one is easy.
The job involves simply replacing the conventional wall switch with the dimmer.

LEAD: HONG KONG TASTE, a new Chinese restaurant in Westport (formerly the Beansprout), is a benchmark of sorts: it does not bear the word Sichuan or Hunan in its title, and it presents the dishes of Hong Kong with Parisian flair, in a stylish setting as sophisticated as the presentations.
With service as polished as the decor, each platter is set before you as a work of art, before being removed to a side table and dished up in individual servings.

Postings: Going Up in Hartford;   Sweat-Equity Affordables

Eighteen other families, including smaller ones, will be considered for 18 two-bedroom condominiums with no sweat equity, but requiring down payments of $3,088 and $120 monthly association fees.

The blackout served to demonstrate how important it is for companies to have a reliable backup power supply for their computers.

LEAD: TORNADO ALLEY, by Craig Nova. (Delta, $10.95.) '' 'Tornado Alley' is the kind of book one takes to the beach or to the mountains for the purpose of total immersion,'' Andrei Codrescu said here last year.

There is, after all, another Garden of Eden in Syria, and nobody can be sure where the real site is.

Guest.

Nor has she slept a full night since the evening of June 23, when a Saturday shopping trip with two of her daughters ended with her 10-year-old ''baby,'' Shaniqua, bleeding in her arms from a fatal gunshot wound to the chest.

Mr. Dinkins Clears the Air
LEAD: Tennis fans and players alike will notice some changes at the United States Open, which begins tomorrow at the National Tennis Center in Queens.
Chris Evert, now retired, won't be there.
And for the first time in over a decade, neither Jimmy Connors nor John McEnroe are among the seeded players.
But the biggest and most welcome change will be the absence of the incessant roar of planes.

The Essential Chatham
LEAD: Like other towns much visited by tourists, Chatham, Mass., reveals its many faces only to those who take time to look below the surface.
To casual travelers who leave their cars in the public parking lot after surviving the summer traffic jam, a stroll along its gently curving Main Street with elegant low-key shops, restaurants and inns unobtrusively tucked into sea captains' houses, conjures up the picture of Olde New England charm, even when T-shirts are being sold.

Cool Eating During Kyoto's Dog Days
LEAD: In the deep green pockets of Kyoto, in temple gardens and the groves surrounding Shinto shrines and the lush park enclosing the Imperial Palace, short-lived cicadas raise their shrill, mournful voices.
The overcast and intermittently cool rainy season ends (almost always) by the middle of July, and from then well into August are the dog days of Japan's summer.

How to Install a Dimmer Switch
LEAD: DIMMER switches allow adjusting lighting levels; they also save energy and extend the lives of light bulbs.
Most often, dimmer switches are used for controlling incandescent ceiling lights.
Installing one is easy.
The job involves simply replacing the conventional wall switch with the dimmer.

Climbing Mount Fuji By Night
LEAD: It's 3 A.M. on Mount Fuji as we grope our way up a massive scree slope in the dark.
In this hour of reckoning, thin air and night silence fuse with exertion, exhilaration and lack of sleep.
We're high.
The objective is to be on top of the sacred peak at sunrise.
The trail is indistinct but there's enough light to be aware of the elevation and the infinite black space that is not rock.


Facts and Feelings About Dresden
LEAD: I was quite moved by the heart-rending description of how a family physically and emotionally survived the bombing of Hiroshima 45 years ago in ''Stories My Parents Told Me, From the Horror of Hiroshima'' (Westchester Opinion, Aug. 5).
The oral testimony passed down from one generation to another is an important link to the human impacts of historic events -- impacts that are usually not described in the history texts from which our children learn of the past.


IN SHORT: NONFICTION
LEAD:
CHRONICLE OF A REVOLUTION: A Western-Soviet Inquiry Into Perestroika.
Edited by Abraham Brumberg. (Pantheon, $24.95.) Just how the Soviet Union will emerge from the tumultuous events that are still shaking that country is still anybody's guess.
But ''Chronicle of a Revolution,'' a collection of highly readable, provocative essays edited by Abraham Brumberg, a visiting scholar at Georgetown University, suggests that most of the changes that have swept across the country over the past five years were predictable.

Business Digest
LEAD:
The Oil Jolt
U.S. officials said economic sanctions against Iraq, while starting to have some effect, will probably not have a decisive impact for months. [Page A1.]  Oil prices have jumped because of what may turn out to be a modest interruption in supplies.
The forces of supply and demand are slow to respond to changes in oil prices, and neither producers nor consumers are likely to make changes that would restore an equilibrium.

U.N'S DIPLOMACY WELCOMED;   A Little Oil Means a Lot
LEAD: The price of crude oil jumped more than 70 percent since the beginning of July, the financial markets have plunged, and the economic future of the industrial world has been thrown into question, all because of an interruption in supplies that may turn out to be quite modest.
A host who bought two cases of beer for a party and broke one bottle would face about the same degree of shortage.

INTERNATIONAL
A2-10
Economic sanctions against Iraq, while already having some effect, will probably not have a decisive impact for months, U.S. officials said.

CHRONICLE
LEAD: MEL TORME has finished ''Traps, the Drum Wonder,'' his biography of Buddy Rich.
The singer started it in 1975, put it aside for his own autobiography and completed the manuscript last month.
It has been submitted to publishers by STERLING LORD, who says that one will be chosen by mid-September.


Business Scene;   Mexico's Vibrant Untaxed Sector
LEAD: EIGHT blocks from Mexico City's ancient central plaza and historic cathedral is a major shopping district.
The streets are as packed with shoppers as Fifth Avenue in New York before Christmas.
The shops are mostly makeshift sidewalk stalls, but they display a huge variety of clothing, shoes, household wares, toys and electronic products.


Market Place;   Reviewing Deals After the Invasion
LEAD: THE best of Wall Street's merger experts in the 1980's specialized in determining how much debt their target companies could take on in a leveraged buyout.
To do so, they made assumptions about the future, including the direction of interest rates, economic growth, inflation, even oil prices.
But none of them figured on Saddam Hussein.

Corrections

Treaty Oak Pruning Planned
LEAD: The historic Treaty Oak, a centuries-old tree that was poisoned with a powerful herbicide early last year, will be severely pruned later this year in an effort to save it, the city forester says.
The pruning will leave only one living section, he said.
The tree is supposedly where Stephen F. Austin, founder of the American colony in the Mexican territory of Texas, signed a treaty with the Indians.

RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:
GOLF
Olazabal Wins by 12: Jose-Maria Olazabal started out with consecutive birdies yesterday and went on to a 12-stroke victory in the World Series of Golf in Akron, Ohio, shooting 18-under-par 262.
The 24-year-old Spaniard's edge was the largest margin in 15 years on the PGA Tour.
After going 12 in front on the second hole, Olazabal turned the last round into a victory lap over the Firestone Country Club course, which he dominated as no one ever had.


Question Box
LEAD:
Runners Left Stranded
Q.
When the Dodgers beat the Atlanta Braves, 5-4, a month ago in Los Angeles, they left 25 players on base in the 12-inning game.
What team holds the mark for runners left on in a regulation game of nine innings?
A.
The National League mark is 18, shared by nine teams going all the way back to Boston in 1897 and a short trip back to Atlanta in 1986, also in a game against the Dodgers.

The shutdown this week was attributed to the parts shortage.

LEAD: United Airlines will increase its air freight rates 5.3 percent on all domestic flights effective Oct. 1 to cover rising jet fuel costs, the airline announced Friday.

LEAD:
An AIDS Mystery Unravels
Scientists in the United States, Africa and Europe have found explanations for varying rates by which the AIDS virus spreads among heterosexual couples.
Science Times, page C1.
Sun Belt Boom Charted
The census shows just how big the Sun Belt migration of the 1980's was, with California gaining 23 percent and Florida 31 percent.


E-Systems Pleads Guilty In Army Radio Fraud
LEAD: The manufacturer of the Army's main combat radio, E-Systems Inc., pleaded guilty today to conspiring to defraud the Government by falsifying test results on the radios.
It agreed to pay $4.65 million in fines and restitution to settle the civil and criminal charges.


Rig Count Up in Week
LEAD: The number of rigs exploring for oil in the United States rose by 15 last week, to 1,002, according to the weekly report of drilling activity released today by Baker Hughes Inc.
A year ago the count was 909, the Houston-based oil toolmaker said.
At the height of the oil boom in December 1981, the rig count reached a peak of 4,500.

Note to Readers
LEAD: The Op-Ed page welcomes unsolicited manuscripts.
Because of the volume of submissions, however, we regret that we cannot acknowledge receipt of or return articles unless they are accompanied by a self-addressed, stamped envelope.
If manuscripts are accepted for publication, authors will be notified within two weeks.

Keeping Track of Time
LEAD: THE computer in our one-person office used to share the desk with an alarm clock, a desk calendar and a to-do list.
We added the alarm clock because we often forget to look at the desk calendar and to-do list in time to remember the scheduled events we so diligently write down.
It was not an elegant solution, but it was less expensive and intrusive than an office assistant.

A Safe Emergency Landing
LEAD: A United Airlines jumbo jet with 323 people aboard skidded to a safe emergency landing today at Los Angeles International Airport when it was unable to get its front landing gear down, the authorities said.
The passengers and crew safely evacuated the Boeing 747 by the emergency chutes.
The aircraft was on approach when the crew notified the tower it was unable to get the landing gear down, said Fred O'Donnell, spokesman for the Federal Aviation Administration.

LEAD: President Bush is right to be skeptical that Saddam Hussein will withdraw from Kuwait soon.
But he is also right not to block talks with Baghdad.
Washington cannot appear to oppose efforts to promote a peaceful resolution of the Persian Gulf conflict.
What it can do is stress the minimum conditions for a settlement - that Iraq withdraw from Kuwait unconditionally, and stop threatening the region.

Review/Art;   San Francisco Revolution in Style Recalled in a Traveling Exhibition
LEAD: In the early 1950's, when Abstract Expressionism was first gaining widespread attention and the New York art scene was heating up, a quieter revolution was taking place in San Francisco.
The Abstract Expressionist style, already embraced by many of the city's forward-looking painters, was being abandoned for a return to figuration that was heavy on the use of raw color and muscular paint handling, and light on traditional drawing.

At Last, an End to Supreme Court Activism
LEAD: It is a measure of just how political the subject of the Supreme Court and the Constitution have become that it took Saddam Hussein to get Judge David Souter off the front pages.

Corrections
LEAD: An article and an illustration in Science Times yesterday about alternative energy sources misidentified the maker of an electric-powered van that is to go into limited production next month.
It is Vehma International Inc. of Markham, Ontario, a subsidiary of Magna International Inc. of Canada.
The General Motors Corporation supplies the van bodies.

LEAD: THE narrow, twisting road down to Peter Cox's house at the end of Indian Point in this little community is like a path back to another era.
It dips and winds between salt marshes on one side and the long reach of Sagadahoc Bay on the other.
The tang of the ocean is all around, and when the car stops to let an ancient truck cross an even more ancient bridge, the clean smell of the tide drifts through the window, mingling with the fragrance of balsam fir from the woods and rock roses along the shore.

ABOUT EDUCATION
LEAD: Five years ago, a group of teachers met on this idyllic site in the Green Mountains to recall how six weeks of intensive study here at Bread Loaf's School of English, a graduate division of Middlebury College, had changed their way of teaching.
But while praising the Program in Writing for what it taught, they also celebrated the liberation it offered from their isolated lives in rural communities or small towns.

U.S. Foreign Trade Deficit Declined by 14% in Quarter
LEAD: The gap between United States imports and exports shrank to its lowest level in six and a half years between April and June, the Commerce Department said today, but the improvement was largely caused by cheaper oil imports that have since shot up in price.

That was notable: in recent years, elected officials took to sending surrogates to listen to the speakers at public hearings and to cast votes according to their masters' wishes.

LEAD: Two summers ago the Gate Theater, Dublin, jolted New York audiences with the festering, dark-brewed, tragic reality of its ''Juno and the Paycock,'' a brief Broadway tenant courtesy of the New York International Festival of the Arts.
Now the Gate is offering Londoners an equivalent thrill with its visiting production of ''The Three Sisters'': a stunning collaboration between Ireland's acting dynasty -Cyril Cusack and a trio of his daughters - and the English director Adrian Noble, the newly named artistic leader of the Royal Shakespeare Company.

Oil-Freeze Plan in Italy
LEAD: Italian finance officials proposed today that prices of petroleum products be frozen for three months to combat rising inflation resulting from the Gulf crisis.
The Treasury Minister, Guido Carli; the Finance Minister, Rino Fomica, and the Budget Minister, Paolo Cirino Pomicino, will ask the Cabinet on Friday to approve a freeze that would be in effect from September through November.

HOME IMPROVEMENT
LEAD: VIRTUALLY all building codes now require that the outlets in new and remodeled kitchens, bathrooms and garages be protected by a ground-fault circuit interrupter, usually called a G.F.C.I. or G.F.I.
This protection is recommended for all outlets in damp locations.
A G.F.C.I. protects you from shock by shutting off the power to an outlet when it detects a leak in the flow of electricity, as when a faulty appliance or cord touches a wet floor.

Inside the bus it is cold, but outside heat is rising up from the sidewalks and pushing down from the sky.
The people streaming into Penn Station are jacketless if they are men and bare-armed if they are women, and the boys on bikes are stripped to singlets and shorts.

British Record Set

The grandfather was not E. R. Squibb but Theodore Weicker, one of three partners who founded the Squibb Corporation.

LEAD: Three thousand people have been called as prospective jurors for the September trial of a man charged in the slayings of 11 women.
The man, Arthur J. Shawcross, 45 years old, will be tried in Monroe County in the murders of 10 of the women.
He faces a second trial in neighboring Wayne County in the 11th slaying.

LEAD: The dollar moved mostly higher in United States trading yesterday after a mixed performance overseas as currency dealers began adjusting their holdings ahead of the long holiday weekend in the United States.


U.S. Inquiry of Dumping
LEAD: The Government decided on Wednesday to investigate whether some equipment made by Japanese electronics companies is imported at less than fair value into the United States, threatening the domestic industry.
The International Trade Commission ruled that there was reasonable indication that imports of some electronic display screens used in computers and their sub-assemblies materially injure the American industry.

LEAD: DeWitt Stetten Jr., a biochemist and former deputy director of the National Institutes of Health who in the 1970's headed a committee that drafted guidelines on genetic engineering, died Tuesday at the Fernwood Nursing Center in Bethesda, Md.
He was 81 years old.


Goodyear Layoffs
LEAD: The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company said it was cutting production and laying off a total of about 800 workers at three North American plants.
The company attributed the moves to a sluggish market for cars and a desire for balanced inventory levels.
Goodyear said that its plants in Union City, Tenn., and Valleyfield, Quebec, would lay off 270 and 530 employees, respectively, and that production at its operation in Danville, Va., would be reduced for a week.

LEAD: A growing number of experts are questioning the usefulness of the animal tests used to decide whether chemicals cause cancer.

LEAD:
TRACK AND FIELD
East German Woman Gets 2d Gold
Katrin Krabbe of East Germany sprinted to her second gold medal by winning the women's 200 meters in 21.95 seconds at the European championships yesterday at Split, Yugoslavia.
She won the 100-meter dash on Tuesday.
The holder of the world record in the pole vault, Sergei Bubka of the Soviet Union, lost his first major event in seven years when he failed to clear 19 feet 1/4 inch.

LEAD: The question was never whether Marvin Graves was going to be the starting quarterback at Syracuse University, not after his displays of arm strength on the practice field and his willingness to spend hours as a student of the game.
The only question was when.
And the bold answer is now.
Dick MacPherson, the coach of the Orangemen, selected Graves, a freshman in his second year with the Syracuse program, over Mark McDonald, a junior, as the starter against Southern California on Friday night.

LEAD: When Mayor David Dinkins of New York appointed a commission in April to investigate a black boycott of two Korean grocery stores in Brooklyn's Flatbush section, cynics suggested the move was merely a device to diffuse responsibility for an intolerable display of racism.
The commission's report, issued yesterday, makes even the cynics look starry-eyed.

LEAD: Here on the fishing docks in this seaside village near the Rhode Island border, stacks of empty lobster traps bake like driftwood in the noonday sun. Money Fund Assets Off
LEAD: The assets of the nation's 520 money market mutual funds decreased $542.2 million, to $407.45 billion, for the week that ended on Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.
The assets of the 162 institutional funds decreased by $772.5 million, to $98.7 billion.
The assets of the 253 general-purpose funds were up by $931.9 million, to $143.38 billion.

LEAD: The Bank of New England's stock tumbled today after a Congressional candidate said, and the Federal Government later denied, that regulators had recommended liquidating the struggling bank.

Mohawk-Canada Accord Collapses
LEAD: An agreement between Mohawk Indians and the national and Quebec Governments to dismantle barricades across a main bridge in Montreal fell apart today as Indian leaders complained of continued harassment by the police.

TV Weekend;   '20/20' Plumbs Depression's Depths
LEAD: Tonight's edition of ''20/20'' at 10 on ABC is given entirely to ''Depression: Beyond the Darkness,'' a report on a still mysterious illness that takes different forms and may affect 20 million Americans a year.
It's an informative hour.
Through interviews with sufferers and their doctors, the program describes the main forms of therapy now being used to control an often incapacitating affliction that sometimes ends in suicide.


Review/Art;   Was It a Love for TV? Or the TV Repairman?
LEAD: Since its infancy in the late 1960's, video art has had to contend with a contradiction.
As art, it aspires to be taken seriously, but as a relative of television it needs to entertain.
This may explain why some of the most memorable examples of early video art - William Wegman's tapes of his dog's deadpan performances, Vito Acconci's risque monologues - use humor as an esthetic device.


Healthiest S.&amp; L.'s Show Sharp Decline In Latest U.S. Data
LEAD: Providing troubling evidence that the savings and loan deterioration is worsening, the Government reported today that even the healthiest segment of the industry has sharply declined in the last three months.

LEAD: The Eastman Kodak Company has scheduled news conferences for Sept. 18 in New York, Tokyo and London to introduce ''a new photographic system designed to increase the use and enjoyment of pictures.'' Kodak declined to provide details.
Analysts speculate Kodak may be introducing devices or methods to electronically manipulate conventional photographs.

LEAD: Chile will formally bury former President Salvador Allende Gossens next week in a ceremony that has revived the controversies surrounding his Government and his death in a military coup nearly 17 years ago.

LEAD: To the Editor:


Loss of Paychecks From Kuwait Makes Families Hostages of Crisis
LEAD: Saying the Persian Gulf conflict has eliminated its only source of income, a Texas company has cut off paychecks to the families of six oil workers who are hostages of the Iraqi Government.


Sutton Still Seeks Deal With DeSoto
LEAD: The Sutton Holding Corporation, a New York investment firm, said it was still interested in acquiring DeSoto Inc., even though the company was liquidating most of its assets and distributing the proceeds to shareholders.
Since July, DeSoto has sold its industrial coating and solvent business to a unit of the Union Carbide Corporation for $200 million and its consumer-paint business to the Sherwin-Williams Company for $80 million.


Topics of The Times;   T-Shirt Readings
LEAD: A New Yorker who begins her day with the astrology column and spends much of it knocking on wood went out looking for omens recently.
The weather was fine, too fine for anyone to be stuck in an office, and she was in search of something that would tell her to go home.
She found that something.
Thrice.


Washington Talk;   Fiscal Indecision Makes Retirement Look Better
LEAD: The Federal Government is an adroit procrastinator, ever ready to postpone such routine chores as balancing the budget.
If Uncle Sam saw a therapist, he would surely be told that the habit is self-destructive.


Rimington Waived
LEAD: The Philadelphia Eagles yesterday waived Dave Rimington, an eight-year center who was a two-time Outland Trophy winner at Nebraska and a first-round draft pick by the Bengals in 1983.
Cincinnati waived him during the 1988 preseason, after which he was signed by the Eagles.
He started every game in 1988, but he started just one regular-season game last season.


New York Fights Back With Computer's Help
LEAD: New York City bgan a statistical, legal and political counterattack to prove that there are more New Yorkers than the Census Bureau's figures indicates.


Gerald L. Norman, 78, Administrative Judge
LEAD: Gerald L. Norman, a retired administrative judge for the Workmen's Compensation Board, died on Sunday at Downstate Medical Center in Brooklyn.
He was 78 years old and lived in Brooklyn.
He died of lung cancer, his sister, Winifred L. Norman, said.
Mr.
Norman served as a judge for the Workmen's Compensation Board for several years before he retired in 1980.


2 Advances Are Cited in Tracing Mystery Disorder
LEAD: Two advances in tracing the cause of a mysterious blood and muscle disorder linked to consumption of the food supplement L-tryptophan were reported yesterday by Federal health officials.


Beijing Journal;   The Tears of the Helmsman and Other Scuttlebutt
LEAD: Mao Zedong's image was one of half-emperor and half-god in the days when he presided as Great Helmsman of nearly one-quarter of humanity.
But now it turns out that his wife could reduce him to tears.


ARMENIA DISARMS A VIGILANTE GROUP
LEAD: The new Government of Soviet Armenia said today that it had faced down and disarmed the leaders and scores of guerrillas of a vigilante group that has alarmed the republic with factional violence.


SHUTTLE COLUMBIA IS DELAYED AGAIN
LEAD: The space agency late tonight delayed the launching of the space shuttle Columbia for at least four days to repair a broken part on its astronomical payload.


New Twist In Taylor Talks
LEAD: Negotiations over a contract extension for Lawrence Taylor stalled today, and Joe Courrege, Taylor's agent, said the Giants had given him permission to shop Taylor to other teams.


Why Open Can't Leave New York
LEAD: From the top row of the tennis stadium, you absolutely cannot tell how much topspin is on the ball.
But once the weather clears, you can surely see the New York skyline, shimmering a few miles to the west.


Japanese Markets Rally After Central Bank Raises Rate
LEAD: The financial markets here reacted positively to Thursday's increase in the Bank of Japan's discount rate, but a number of economists warned that it was unlikely to be the last such jump in Japanese interest rates because of growing inflationary pressures.


GERMAN VOWS LIMIT ON THE NEW FORCE
LEAD: In a ''binding declaration'' that will be recorded in the Conventional Forces in Europe Treaty, Foreign Minister Hans Dietrich Genscher of West Germany said today that a united Germany would limit its ground and air forces to 345,000.

LEAD: Jesse Jackson met with President Saddam Hussein of Iraq today to discuss the Persian Gulf crisis, the official Iraqi News Agency reported.


Bulk of $94 Million in Special Interest Gifts Goes to Incumbents
LEAD: Always more inclined to spend money on the campaigns of proven winners than on risky newcomers, political action committees have donated 12 times as much to incumbents as to challengers in this year's Congressional elections, said a study made public today.

LEAD: The National Football League, upon determining that the changes made to shorten the length of games had gone too far, yesterday announced a modification of the timing procedure after kickoffs.

LEAD: Charles Shackleford, who spent two troubled seasons with the Nets, was waived at his request yesterday and will play in the Italian League this season.

LEAD: After following more than 2,000 leads, interviewing dozens of suspects and consulting astrologers, the police are tempering their approach to tracking the so-called Zodiac gunman.

LEAD: Opportunities for creative non-labor in the three-state region this holiday weekend include gazing, giggling, browsing, buying, hurling, and making ice cream.

LEAD: Perrier mineral water, having weathered a storm early this year about contamination of its water, now faces another blow: bowing to government pressure, it can no longer call its water ''naturally carbonated.''

LEAD: Mullen Advertising Inc., Wenham, Mass., scored a victory and a loss yesterday.

John K. Frost, a physician and researcher who specialized in early detection and diagnosis of lung cancer, died on Wednesday at the Johns Hopkins Hospital in Baltimore.

All-Stravinsky Concert
LEAD: Paul Zukofsky will conduct musicians from the Juilliard School in Stravinsky's ''Fanfare for a New Theater'' (1964), ''Epitaphium'' (1959), ''Orpheus'' (1948) and Symphony in C (1940) at the Sculpture Garden of the Museum of Modern Art, 14 West 54th Street, tonight at 7:30.
The program will be repeated tomorrow evening at 7:30.


Short-Term Treasuries Advance
LEAD: Prices of Treasury securities were mixed in light trading yesterday.
An 85-cent rise in oil prices, to $26.77 a barrel, helped persuade bond traders to sell securities, but anticipation that the Federal Reserve Board might be on the verge of easing monetary policy helped push up prices of shorter-term notes and bills.


Ex-State Senator Beatty Slain in Storefront Office in Brooklyn
LEAD: Vander L. Beatty, a flamboyant former State Senator who was convicted of vote fraud after he ran for Congress in 1982, was shot and killed yesterday in his storefront campaign headquarters in Brooklyn.

LEAD: An article in Business Day yesterday about Donald J. Trump misstated the portion of a $65 million bank loan package that was for interest payments on one of his casino bonds.
