LEAD: The dollar gained against all major foreign currencies in domestic trading yesterday, even against the Japanese yen, despite the Bank of Japan's decision to raise its discount rate.


California Firm on Internments
LEAD: An effort to revise what California schoolchildren are taught about the internment of Japanese-Americans during World War II was soundly defeated Tuesday by the State Legislature.


Chronicle
LEAD: SERGEI N. KHRUSHCHEV, son of the deposed Soviet leader, is to spend a month this fall at the John F. Kennedy School of Government at Harvard University in Boston.
Theresa Donovan, a spokeswoman for the school, said Mr.
Khrushchev, a 55-year-old engineer, would use the libraries and talk to the faculty while conducting research for his second book, the theme of which has not been disclosed.


Explosions at Lebanese Barracks Kill 10 Soldiers
LEAD: Two powerful explosions ripped through an army barracks belonging to Gen.
Michel Aoun east of here overnight, killing 10 soldiers and wounding 30 others, as warring Christian factions battled with mortar guns and tanks, shattering a three-month cease-fire, security officials said.

LEAD: Emmet V. Murray, a lawyer who had retired from the Caltex Petroleum Company, died yesterday at his home in Quogue, L.I.
He was 64 years old and also lived in Gulf Stream, Fla.


Irwin A. Lewis, 68, A Pioneer in Polling At the Voting Booth
LEAD: I. A. Lewis, who in the late 1960's was one of the first poll takers to predict election results by surveying voters leaving polling places, died Aug. 18 at the Glendale Adventist Medical Center in California.
He was 68 years old and lived in Los Angeles.


Williams Is Bitter
LEAD: Doug Williams, the only black quarterback to start in the Super Bowl, says that racism is still common in the National Football League.

LEAD: One of three armed men who led the police on a car chase through the Upper West Side of Manhattan was shot and killed last night by officers while trying to flee into a subway tunnel, the police said.


Airline Group Assails Long Customs Delays
LEAD: International passengers at 15 airports in the United States routinely waited two hours or more to clear customs this summer, the president of an airline trade association says, calling for action by the Government to correct the problem.


Factory Orders Up 1.6% in July
LEAD: Orders to factories for manufactured goods grew 1.6 percent in July, the Government reported today.
But analysts said the fluctuating performance so far this year suggested an anemic industrial economy even before the Persian Gulf crisis.


Luigi Beccali, 83, Olympic Champion
LEAD: Luigi Beccali, a prominent and popular long-distance runner in the 1930's and the gold medalist in the 1,500-meter run at the 1932 Olympic Games in Los Angeles, died of natural causes Tuesday in Rafaello, Italy.
He was 83 years old.

It's Carnival Time As New York Turns Caribbean to Dance The Weekend Away
LEAD: EVERY Labor Day weekend, geography warps to place New York City unmistakably in the Caribbean.
This weekend brings a West Indian carnival tonight through Monday in Brooklyn, featuring calypso, steel-band and reggae music; a major salsa concert on Sunday at the Brendan Byrne Arena in East Rutherford, N.J., and a marathon of Dominican merengue tonight at Roseland in Manhattan.


Wayne Newton's Libel Award Against NBC Is Overturned
LEAD: A Federal appeals court today overturned a $5.2 million libel award to the singer Wayne Newton against the National Broadcasting Company, ruling that the network's news reports suggesting links between Mr.
Newton and organized crime had not been shown to be deliberately or recklessly false.


Auctions
LEAD: When office workers dunk a lonely tea bag in a paper cup or a ceramic mug of hot water, they are participating in a tradition that modern life has reduced to the barest essentials.
In the good old days, especially in 18th- and 19th-century England at the high end of the social scale, afternoon tea was a ritual of considerable substance and extensive accessories.


U.S. ENERGY POLICY TO STRESS OUTPUT AND CONSERVATION
LEAD: Energy Secretary James D. Watkins said today that the Bush Administration was responding to the Persian Gulf crisis with a ''short-term strategy'' for stabilizing oil markets by raising domestic production and encouraging conservation.
It will not speed up a new national energy policy now being developed, he said.


Loss on Campeau Loan
LEAD: The National Bank of Canada said today that it had written off an $80 million loan to Robert Campeau's private company, with the provision for the loss split equally between the bank's third and fourth quarters.

LEAD: The deputy chairman of the British Petroleum Company said today that he expected the new OPEC production agreement to keep oil prices in the mid-$20's.

LEAD: Among New York's veteran cabaret performers, Barbara Lea is the only one of note who continues to carry on a sultry Southern-flavored pop-jazz tradition popularized by Ethel Waters and embellished by Mildred Bailey, Connee Boswell and Lee Wiley.
Like her forerunners, Miss Lea is understated when it comes to dramatizing song lyrics.

LEAD: Last year Americans reported 1.5 million cars stolen, a startling 42 percent increase since 1985.

Brazil Stops Debt Interest
LEAD: The president of Brazil's central bank announced today that the country would not make any payment this year on overdue interest owed on its $114 billion foreign debt, the largest in the developing world.

Market Place;   Fund Investors Remain Steadfast
LEAD: THE Iraqi invasion of Kuwait, and the subsequent plunge in stock market prices, drew a surprisingly muted reaction from mutual fund investors, several mutual fund companies said yesterday.
Some managers said investors even stepped up their purchases of stock funds.


Corrections
LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article last Friday about the National Endowment for the Arts misstated the origin of an anti-obscenity pledge required by the agency from grant recipients.
John E. Frohnmayer, the endowment chairman, instituted it last year after Congress amended the endowment's appropriation to prohibit Federal support for art considered obscene.

LEAD: WITH the East Village to the north and SoHo to the south, Houston Street is downtown's great divide.
As wide as a river, it has sprawling four-way intersections that dwarf the twinkling traffic lights above.
The most interesting storefront is actually a lot stocked with funky secondhand furniture.

LEAD: The Hewlett-Packard Company said its engineering applications group would phase out of the business of developing electronic design automation software, which allows the computerized design of chips and circuit boards.
